item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
On Second Life today, I heard from an aquaintance about "NaNoWriMo".

I've heard of this mysterious "NaNoWriMo" in forums and chat gatherings all over, but, to tell you the truth, I never really understood what it was. I just recognized it.

That's why when I learned about what it actually is, I was estatic.

NaNoWriMo stands for "National Novel Writing Month", and is a competition based on the production of prose.

The thing is though, is that you have to write a 50,000 word story in a month. It's all about quantity, not quality, and that's what makes it fun. Even if you're some Joe Schmo that writes like a cat tied to a stick, you can compete with other artsy-fartsy posh-posh writers. I've always wanted to write a story, but I always quit after the eleventh page. Now that there's a competition where you can submit crap and still win, I'm interested.

Perhaps I'll take a stab at it.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I must be going blind.

I can't see what's ahead of me anymore. Since I've started using my PDA as a personal information manager/calendar, I've been confused on things going on. Having a machine let you be stupid and lazy, well... does just that.

It makes you stupid and lazy. I realized that in my math class today. I forgot my calculator, and bad things happened. I ended up asking the people around me how many 7's were in 21 and how to multiply 7 by 9. Flailing madly and cursing, I somehow managed to finish my homework without a trusty little computer to do all the busywork for me.

Situational irony can be found in the fact that I am now using my graphing calculator to help me memorize vocabulary for French. Now, isn't that funny.

To tell you the truth, I didn't think it was that amusing either.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I took the third sip.

A sip of a liquor so foul that one cannot drink it without conjuring up images of hellish fires.

No, I was not drinking antifreeze. Yes, I was drinking apple cider.

I open the fridge to smell the alluring scent of spiced apple. My hand snakes its way toward the fragrant container of brown liquid. I stop myself.

I know that this apple cider is old, and possibly nausea/food illness inducing. But, the smell, it forces me to pick up the container. The cool air from the refridgeration unit makes me even more mindless. To think, I've drank this liquid twice before, and twice I have suffered the wrath of foodborne illness.

Time is running out. I'm reaching a crossroads, where I have to make a decision. Will I trudge on with false hope that somehow this apple cider magically turned new again, or will I run away, cowering in terror from the horror of it all? The cold air in the fridge turns tepid. Time to choose.

I take the container out, and I pour myself a glass of apple cider. The fragrance continues to tempt me, pull me toward my ultimate doom. Like a primal instinct taking over, I pick up the glass.

I take the third sip.

And bad things start to happen. My digestive system goes haywire, and it's curtains for me.

Lesson learned: Apple cider does NOT magically turn new, however much you want it to.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
It was a gut feeling.

The kind of feeling that I would immagine a suicidal person would feel.

It's something queer, this feeling, overwhelming the mind, body, spirit.

It comes from the gut and rises, to the lungs. Choking your air supply. Then, to the throat, where heat, congestion, and pressure is felt. Then to the eyes, which start to water. And finally, the mind. This feeling numbs the mind, yet puts it in the highest sense of alert. Like the pounding of drums, the sensation makes its way into every last neuron, shutting down synapses. Controling me. Overwhelming me. The feeling encompasses all pain, suffering, and fear and puts it all into one universal experience.

Breathing becomes sporadic. Motor control declines. Eyes cannot focus, as tears are starting to form. The mind tries to divert attention. Perhaps I should look at the floor. I look toward the floor. This does not help. I look at the wall. This does not help. Someone looks at me in a funny sort of way. Heart rate increases. My hand starts to shake, perspirate. Body temperature increases, but inside, I feel cold, dead. A medley of suicidal thoughts and emotion-control protocols rush through my mind. Chaos continues to rage within my small, idiotic head. The walls seem to expand and contract, my mind, restricting my breathing. I close my eyes.

A few seconds pass. But, the feeling does not go away. Terror starts to sweep through my body, pulsating, flowing through me as if it somehow fused with my soul. My mind turns to panic for answers. No answers come. Only inquisitive thoughts on how to end one's life appear where solutions were before.

I look down.

62%.

I turn the paper around.

I find that I did not realize there was a back side to the test. I restrain my urge to vomit.

And to think, there's two more years of this to come.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Doh!

RS

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Being the token outsider, I remained quiet.

Today, I joined a few members of the Robotics Club to venture to the mystical land of Pleasantview Elementary School. Our mission? For many, it was to get out of classes. For others, it was to teach children how robots work. For me, it was to get to know the team members, and to understand each person's personality, working style, and values. I also went to attempt to establish myself as part of the team.

The ride on the little white bus wasn't exceptionally terrible. Besides being awkward, me not knowing anyone on the team, it was as peaceful ride. Once we got there, things changed.

Pleasantview Elementary School is a small, ten-room school in the country. Some of these kids live in real farms. The kind one sees on the television, with cows, chickens, and mad-cow disease paranoia. The first thirty minutes went smoothly, as I didn't have to interact with the children. We spent the half hour demonstrating the robots, and letting the children drive the robots. I found out today that kindergarteners are surprisingly human.

The essence of human seemed to seep out of these little children. You could clearly see the facinating group dynamics, as some kids were leaders and others were followers. Yet others were disturbers of the peace, and others were nearly silent. These dynamics start to disappear as one ages. With age, comes social responsibilty. With little children, there are no rules. One can sit in the corner and cry without being labled as a depressed sociopath.

Thirty minutes pass.

The kids are starting to get bored. The VEX robots are starting to fall apart. The kids are starting to run around and kick the robots. The VEX robots continue to fall apart. The team scrambles to grab stray nuts and bolts. The kids are starting to become violent.

The quintessence of the human. The purveyor of chaos, the animal from which all destruction stems.

And, we continue to repair the robots.

Finally, someone breaks out "plan B".

Time to build "robots" with the kids. These are no ordinary "robots", I must inform you. These are "robots" that are made of wooden dowels and rubber bands. I have no idea how they are supposed to be built, I'm as oblivious as the children. The rest of the team knows how. I feel like an outsider.

Team members begin to be paired with the children to ensure successful completion of the aforementioned activity. Slowly, each child is paired with a member of the robotics team. Some of the members get two or three kids. I'm paired at the end. Naturally, I get the firebrand.

"Jonathan" is supposedly the class "math whiz". I consider him more of an inquisitive, hyperactive nipper. We begin the build. I pull out the wooden parts from his plastic bag for him. He smiles at me. I freeze up. I don't know what to do. The smile, so foreign, something that could only come from a child. I put on a weak smile and gave him a wooden dowel.

He hesitates.

I nod.

He nods back and takes the dowel.

I felt a deep connection with this little child. Such a primal form of communication, yet the transmission of information was so clear. Like some sort of primitive, instinctive form of link, our minds were linked together for that fraction of a second. I've never experienced such a primitive, yet effective form of bonding with someone else, a stranger, like this before. Only a small child is socially daring enough to smile and nod to a complete stranger. If only this kind of human compassion could be retained, but alas. People like me have lost all pathos to humanity. I can hardly smile or look at strangers. People like me? Are there people like me?

We build a robot. We engage in primitive small talk. He asks if I'm going to stay for "snack time".

I sit there stunned.

I'm amazed that someone would actually want me to join them for a snack. I remember when I was a child, no one ever invited me to snack time. I was alone. But now, something inside of me, was given life again. I was no longer alone. My inner child, perhaps? Or is it something more?

I say, "Perhaps... What do you have for snack?"

The small talk continues until we finish the "robot".

He seems a bit disappointed. I can understand why. When I think of "robot", I think of giant mechs with rocket boosters, and I suppose that's what he thought of too. What we ended up with was a pair of wheels mounted onto a simple wood chasis. The only thing keeping this chasis together was friction. I felt like I let him down.

But, he wasn't let down. Soon, forgetting about the dinky "robot", he walks over to the supply table. He pulls out a wood cylinder. A small one, small enough to fit in one's pocket. He asks if he can keep it. I tell him that he can keep it forever, for the rest of his life.

He says, "It's gonna' be my pet. A guinea pig!"

To him, the dowel represents a guinea pig. Nothing wrong with a bit of immagination, right? I tell him to keep good care of it, and soon I'm back on the bus, back to school, back to a building lacking in what these children excel at.

Human compassion.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I wish upon a shining star...

That my old Linux computer will someday be able to connect to my wireless network.

Well, besides my silly wishes, I'm practicing to pass the amateur radio exam that I'm going to be taking tomorrow morning. The books I've borrowed from the library have either called the exam extremely hard, or extremely easy.

I'm almost, but not quite, sure that I'm ready. I've taken practice exams on the Internet, and I can pass them. If I pass the exam tomorrow, I will be satisfied with myself, which is a pretty big step for my crushed ego.

I must continue studying, so I bid thee farewell for now.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
It's a quaint October morning as we cruise down a country road to a little town called Frankfort.

My mother and I are driving to the public library there so I can take the technician's amateur radio exam. I'm voraciously studying questions from a book.

We hit a bump, and I look up. Big American trucks and old farmhouses whiz past my window as I peer out into, what seems like, a completely peaceful world. The trees sway in the wind, the leaves fall into small man-made lakes. An old, rusty windmill juts out of the ground.

I begin to notice an increased number of antennas in the country. Each abandoned farmhouse appears to be attached to some kind of giant antenna tower, with a yagi and television antenna. Most of these towers are bent, rusted, and falling apart. But, every few miles or so were new antennas. Antennas for cellular companies and FM radio broadcasts. If you look carefully, it's quite a challenge to find an area that doesn't have metal clips that jut into the air.

Our arrival to Frankfort is signified by giant, dilapidated storage silos for who know's what. The metal luster is long gone, the sheen worn off by the elements. Only shells of what they once were, these vacated grain mills cluster the landscape as we approach the little town of Frankfort.

The inner city of Frankfort consists of old churches and deplorable car lots, with the occasional pharmacy or dollar store. The roads are empty, and the only thing that seems to thrive here is the cold wind. Houses in this town can be lumped into two general categories. One of them being "urban, ghetto houses" and the other being "old trailer houses".

The library appears. It sticks out like a sore thumb. Although it is not an eyesore in itself, it contrasts with the cracked sidewalk and old trees. The modern-esque, new building looks like it was dropped here from the sky by some higher being (Which I assume is really some kind of artsy-fartsy modern architect).

Old, run-down houses and old groceries surround the library. The sky is gray, and the air is crisp. Crisp enough to be uncomfortable. I zip up my coat and walk to the door, and it opens by itself with a ker-klunk. The rest of the town is eerily silent.

I enter, and I see no one. I begin to doubt the validity of the "Open" sign that was on the door behind me. I glance around, and catch a glimpse of some stairs. Why not?

I climb the stairs and take a left. In the hallway, I see someone walking. Slowly, I follow the man until I'm greeted by two old men. The kind of old men that probably lived through the depression. A warm smile appeared on their faces.

They motion to a room in the back, a small door no larger than a bookshelf with a little paper sign on it.

"VE Testing", it says.

I find myself hesitant, but I manage to take a breath, summon up some courage, and walk in.

I find a old, rustic table and a few chairs. Two other men are sitting at the table, taking the test. three very old men sit at another table. I assume that they are the Volunteer Examiners and that they are probably in their 70's. The men at the testing table look 30-ish. One of the testing men is wearing dark, hunting boots and a camo jacket. The other is wearing big sunglasses. The men at the table shuffle their papers, and I stand there. Pausing for a bit to let it all soak in. I stick out.

I walk to the table and hand one of the men my $14 to take the test. He hands me a form, a test, and a pencil. I sit down and take the test. This is the easy part.

The questions whiz past, everything on the test just as I had immagined. After tripple-checking my answers, I walk up to the desk.

I realize that I forgot to write down my FCC CORES number down on the form. I take out my number out of my pocket and scribble it on the form. I mumble to the old men that I forgot to write down this number. One of them is hard of hearing, so I tell him again, louder. He nods, but I don't think he understands. Nonetheless, I hand them my papers and sit down. They grade.

After a few minutes, one of the old men walks up to me and puts a piece of paper on the table. I look up. He smiles.

He points to a spot that is marked "Applicant Signature-->". I sign it.

"So, this is it?", I say.

The old man says, "Welcome" and puts out his hand for me to shake. I fluster for a bit, surprised by this offer. Coming to my senses, I shake his hand. It should be noted that I shook it firmly, as I have practiced effective hand shaking at QuizBowl.

I start to walk out the door. Out of the corner of my eye, the other two old men at the table stand up.

I think to myself, "Something must be wrong. Maybe I failed the test. Perhaps they graded something incorrectly."

Turning around to see what the movement is about, the two old men put out there hands for me to shake. Again, I'm surprised, but manage to shake both of their hands. The last old man to shake my hand looks me in the eye and says, "Good luck".

I look back at him in the eyes for a fraction of a second, and even though his worn face is stuck in a firm, stern expression, I caught the slightest hint of acceptance in his eyes.

I muster a weak "Thanks" and walk out the door with my certificate and hopes for a license arriving in the mail in a month or so.

I walked out the door with something else too.

A feeling of acceptance.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Today was one of those dismal days.

The kind of day where one gets into a shower and tries to forget the day even happened. The kind of day where one feels like a worthless sack of old potatoes.

I'm really feeling like a worthless sack of potatoes today. I've been working all day, for projects that aren't even worth all that many points. I've been studying for tests that never are there, yet when they do come up, I fail miserably on them. I'm trying to understand my math and chemistry, but all I can do in my horrible state of mind is haphazardly turn pages and stare at pages with glazed eyes. Tonight, breathing comes with a dull pain that I assume is from all of my pointless stress. I can't concentrate, but I'm having trouble sleeping because of my incessant paranoia of school. School means French and Chemistry. French and Chemistry mean feelings of shame, failure, and teenage anguish. School is every day of my life, even the weekends now. So, now my life is filled with miserable sensations of failure.

And I continue wonder about how the end of a gun would taste, or how much 2 liters of blood really is, but I can't help it.

Dismal, dismal, dismal. That's what life was, is, and will be.

For now at least.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The tension is mounted, and all I need is a trigger.

A trigger to set me off on some sort of wild rampage. I don't know what kind of rampage it would be. I suppose if I was to not deviate from the stereotypical rampage, I would have to bring a firearm to school, kill many innocent people, hold a few of them hostage, and in the end, kill myself. But, of course, I'm not much of a social conformist.

My kind of rampage would probably involve playing Super Smash Brothers Melee for hours on end, not stopping for food or water. I would probably end up dead on the floor, eyes twitching from the television, hands still clutching the controller. I would be a cold, dead body. But, a cold, dead SSBM master, no?

Well, another rampage I suppose would be possible would be a French and Chemistry paranoia rampage. In this rampage, I would mindlessly scream expletives while intensely studying either French or Chemistry. Or both. Also in this rampage, I would end up dead in the end, most likely from exhaustion or dehydration.

Yet another rampage would be a rampage involving a hunger strike/homework binge. In this sort of rampage, I would lock my door, refuse to eat, and do the whole year's homework. Every night would be a long one, with me shaking from the stress, under the spell of insanity and homework-induced crazyness. Again, I would probably find a way to kill myself with my usb network adapter and a cheap roll of tape.

And, now, it's time for my prophecy of tomorrow.

I predict that tomorrow will be hellishly full of homework and extracurricular activities. My life will suck like no other, and I will be the quintessence of raving lunatic.

You can tell how optimistic I am, can't you?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I'm really not used to this "stay up really late and homework binge" thing that I'm doing tonight.

After drinking that 2 liter of soda, I felt like I could take on the world, but now I'm thinking of vomiting all over my chemistry, which is still sitting there with one molecular structure empty. I can't really think in this state of mind. It's sort of a dream/trance-like state in which I'm actually half asleep. I think it would be really disorienting if I didn't go to sleep at all tonight. The morning would come along, and it would be time for school again, even though I just got home from a band concert and was working on homework.

In other news, I still have to study for various tests. Wish me good luck, and maybe I'll get finished by 2AM.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
To tell you the truth, I'm having trouble thinking again.

I suppose it's because of my lack of sleep.

This afternoon, I turned in my Chemistry lab, even though I did most of it wrong. I assumed that the teacher wouldn't really catch the little errors that I made. I hope my assumption turns out to be correct, because if it turns out to be incorrect, those hours of pulling my hair out late at night would be in vain. Too bad I turned off the timestamps on these posts, because then you could see how little sleep I'm getting.

In other news, I'm obsessed and romanticizing about Starfox and the crew again.

Something to put on the "to do list": Make a "Falco Lombardi is my Hero" T-shirt.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
*Note: I have added a link to my SL Snapshot album.

Today involved a long bike to a friend's house. This ride of 1.5 miles was quite painful. I underestimated the power of cold, dry wind. After biking about one fourth of the way there, I was trying to convince myself to turn back, but I somehow managed. With each rotation of the pedal on my bike, the pain increased. The cold, stale air ripping the moisture and heat from my lungs and throat. The wind continuing to pull the life out of the tips of my fingers and ears. By the end of the ride, I was out of heat, water, energy, and sanity.

Tomorrow, I am going to Chicago. Hopefully, I will come back alive.

And another thing. I talked to an old friend from Alabama today. We had a 90 minute long conversation.

He said, "Are we still friends?"

And ever since we hung up a few hours ago, I've been thinking. What makes a friend?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Going nuts over chemistry isn't going to help me live longer, that's for sure, but it's just so hard to be so fearless in the face of such a dangerous subject.

Chemistry itself isn't dangerous, but the homework issued and grading structure is a minefield of lethal risks and perils. Any false step will result in a large chunk of my grade being exploded into nothingness. Any forgetful mistake will land me in mental shame and agony. Any wrong choices, and I'm done for.

So, what's the fuss? I mean, it's high school. How hard could it be?

Well, that's just it. It's not really all that hard, but I just make it seem like such a hazard that I spend hours glaring at my book, pulling my hair out, turning the music up louder, trying to make the words on the page vibrate away. But, they never do, and I always end up having sleepless nights of fear. Not the kind of fear that's just an adrenaline spike in your blood. Not that kind of quick, energetic fear. This is the kind of fear that's more of a elongated, expanded sort of worry. The kind of fear that dwells deep inside of one's gut, slowly expanding to eventually constrict the abdomen, and then the throat. The dark, slow pain. Dull pain.

And so, tonight will be just like all of the rest. Another semi-sleepless night. Kudos to you, Chemistry.

You've done your job beautifully.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Oddly enough, I look back on my walls of little notepad-sized art ditties, and I'm ashamed. Kind of funny really. Once upon a time, I was proud of drawing those. But, now I look at them and shudder, picking out things that went wrong, lines bent the wrong way, line art that went bazooks, eyes that aren't lined up. It's so obvious to me now.

And this is a great thing, because it reveals to me that I have advanced, even ever so slightly. Change is beautiful, and I can't believe that I can see my crappy art looking worse every day and this makes me happy. But, it's true, and it's kind of an positive note. The positive note being that I've taken up randomly scribbling in my "Sketch Diary" again. Perhaps I'll start reserving an hour or so every night to sketching, just as in the summer. That would be just wonderful.

It's something to look forward to, this quiet time at night, when I can just browse art forums and sketch something from an obscure reference. One could even call it refreshing. And a definite plus to this hour of "relax-time" is that it takes my mind off of my mental insecurities and my chemistry.

The only problem about publishing the things I do on paper to the Internet is that my scanner is downstairs in the living room. My parents still don't know that I draw, and I'm a bit fearful of letting them know. I've always been ashamed to let them known I've done something, especially art, because the reaction is usually negative.

When my family is away, I can usually sneak down a few sketches and scan them in quick. Editing is another story. Editing takes time, lots of time with my artwork on the screen of the computer. This means that my parents must not be near the computer when I edit. This is difficult, with my scanner and monitor being in such a public place. When editing, I usually lean very close to my computer monitor so any possibly visible portions of my art are obscured by my head.

And, now that I look at what I'm doing... Why am I obsessively hiding my artwork from my parents? Who knows. Must be my insecure mind acting up again. And insecurity means weakness.

And you know what they say about the weak.

"The weak will not survive the purges."

And so, perhaps I should stop being paranoid about my parents finding my art. Perhaps I should stop taking extreme measures to monitor who comes into my room. Perhaps I should stop hiding my sketch pad in absurd places, for no reason.

Perhaps not?

Well, to tell you the truth, my art sucks.

I have no idea why I've just wasted my bloody post for such a sucky topic. My "art" isn't even worth mentioning. Bah, to hell with my "art"!

In other news, I have chemistry tomorrow. This means I will experience another one of those "not-being-able-to-sleep-because-of-chemistry-homework" nights.

Just fantastic.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
It's the kickoff of NaNoWriMo today, and I've written 2400 words so far. You can check the button I added to the bottom.

In other news, my life has been beseiged with projects. I'm drawing, writing, thinking, doing tedious homework, and going nuts! Time is my enemy, and as I write this, everything has a deadline, and some things are going to have to be postponed, to my dismay. Things like, my drawing, for example. You can't really call it "my" drawings though, since I just use references. I feel bad when I use references, but I think I learn through repetition and copying the masters.

Bah, back to drawing and writing. Things must be sacrificed!

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My life is tiring, even if I get home early because I don't have extracurricular activities.

Today was a day like that. I didn't have any extracurricular activities. Wednesday is the only day off I really have. The weekends are reserved for English class projects and misc. homework studying and test review. All other days have an extracurricular activity and lots of homework. Wednesday is no exception for the ammount of homework I have, but I get back home two hours earlier than usual, which is fantastic.

Fantastic until I realize how many things I have to do. Basically, I walk off of the bus, open the door to my house, eat a very early dinner, take a very early shower, trudge up the stairs, dragging my enormous, green backpack up with me, shut the door to my room, turn up the music in my room, do homework, and study. After schoolwork is done, I write my daily quota for NaNoWriMo and draw something. By the time I finish my drawing, it's usually 8:30PM and I'm ready to type up a post for this blog. I take a half hour doing that, and I sleep.

Rinse and repeat for 365 days.

And it continues, and I know it's going to get even tougher in the future. Like I mentioned earlier, yesterday or something, things will have to be sacrificed.

I think that's really sad because I like doing everything I do (save the English class homework and projects) and I don't want to sacrifice anything, but I suppose that's how life is. Dreams will be shattered and protective walls will be knocked down.

I'm exposed on all flanks as is, and what am I supposed to do? Stop writing and drawing? What would be the point in living if I did that? Stop all of my schoolwork? I can't do that, because then I'll end up being an second-class non-citizen. Stop my extracurriculars? Well, what will I put on my resume? Actually, it's not like I have a resume to put all of these things on. I'm not a citizen, so I can't work, so it's hopeless.

Life without hope isn't life at all. So, I suppose the above statement, when I said, "it's hopeless" is false.

At least, I hope it is.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Ryo, I must say a few things. A. don't worry about getting a job if our...southern friends can find one with ease. B. u get home abotu 3 and take till 8:30 to do homework...nerd. Common man, i bust out a 4.0 and spend minimal time on homework. C. You need to get out more man. Live a ltitle. As Peter Griffin would say " Ha Ha Ha, i'm just kidding; Hop in, were goin to a skin bar.". Ya u know what im talkin about.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The QuizBowl team suffered a crushing defeat today, and it was all too sad.

It wasn't a failure of the team structure itself, but a failure of a few key individual members, me being the prime example. I blatantly failed. I don't see why Andrew didn't take me out of the game and replace me, but it happened like it happened. It's just that, I'm an idiot, but for some crazy reason, people like to keep me in because they think that I know everything, and I don't.

And so, we were defeated from the nerds from far away because I failed, and it's really my fault, particularly because I voiced support of a category that killed us.

Enough about QuizBowl, because talking about it always makes me feel bad, just like talking about my future, or talking about English and/or French class makes me feel bad.

Bad is such a general word, but right now, I'm using "bad" to describe the dark, unpleasant feeling that one experiences after a failure.

I suppose the "bad" feelings were compensated when I came home and discovered a letter on the counter that was from the FCC.

I finally got my paper license, and that was the bright point of my day. I'm planning to go laminate it at Kinko's or somewhere else this weekend. Too bad Christmas is so far away. I'll just have to satisfy myself by reading reviews of 2-meter handheld radios until the holiday arrives.

Yes, that will be the day.

Until then, I'll be radioless.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Until then...

YOU WILL BE WRITING A NOVEL!!

Radioless huh? Well.. that won't do. Until you get some hardware, let the software do some work: www.echolink.org.

Be sure to read, know, and follow all safety rules when working with your power tools.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
If my homework was this hand, this is what I would like to do to it.

Particularly my English homework.

That is all.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
To relieve myself of stress, I like to look at bloody pictures. Excuse me for my habit. I speculate that it must be all of the gory medical magazines my father has lying around all over the place. Ever since I was a little kid, I've seen bloody, intensely gory pictures of all kinds of "accidents" and diseases. I suppose one could call me "desensitized".

Today I went to the local sports bar to meet up with my QuizBowl team. It may just be me, but I think that's the most crazy place to spend a Friday night. Crazy in the fact that we're a QuizBowl team, and crazy in the fact that I'm socially inept and can't deal with so many people. The atmosphere isn't all that great either.

The place is basically a big room filled with televisions and projectors that show clips of sporting events. This big room is also filled with chairs, too many people, and lots of smoke. The smoke bothers me, because every time I take a breath in there, I can feel the soot accumulating in my throat and lungs. It irritates my respiratory system, and I don't enjoy that very much. Because of the smoke, I try not to talk as much, and this leads to social exclusion, which leads to a not-so-fantastic team bonding experience.

I always feel like an outsider whenever I meet up with people as a "team". I just can't compete with everyone else's intellect and wit, their outgoing personalities, and their plain articulation. It just so happens that I am a stuttering moron. No matter how hard I try, it doesn't matter. I'll always be at the bottom of the social pecking order.

And, so, I still don't understand why I still attend these occasions, besides needing to satisfy my thirst for being "part of something".

I suppose I'm being selfish, and, in the long run, am being punished for it.

It doesn't really matter to me now, because I'll have to think about it later. I'm too busy trying to finish my homework.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Don't worry Ryo, you have all your other socially inept friends to count on whenever you feel like something is going wrong.

We shall be with you through thick and thin; through peanut butter and mustard; that's my mentality for the day right there.

G2G

-JV

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My accomplishment of the day is being listed on a high-profile website. Today, more accurately, yesterday, a picture of my secondlife self was shown on secondlife.com.

If you look at the picture shown above, you'll see a wolf holding a gun, with a pirate hat on in front of a communist flag. That wolf is indeed me. I was checking out the socialist headquarters, and I snapped some pictures of myself in front of the flag.

The administrators probably thought that was quite cute, so I got shown on the frontpage of their site. How wonderful.

And guess what. While exploring the Socialist HQ, I happened to run into the chairman of the commies. "Lenin Camus", the chairman of the Second Life Socialist Party (SLSP), decided to give me an exclusive office and a title. Now I'm Comrade Forcet. I'm scheduled to attend a political discussion on Wednesday.

Political power in cyberspace? I think, yes!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Lucky! You get to have all the fun when it comes to taking over the internet with an idealistic way of government!

Still, that's awesome.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Apparently, my photo has caused some controversy among SecondLife forumites. Oh no, not the flamers!

I'm surprised people were offended enough to post things about my picture.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Wow, that's hilarious. And where on Earth did that person get "25 million?" That's a REALLY big number. Oh well, have fun.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes I feel like I'm inadequate.

From previous posts, it's pretty obvious that I'm a very self-doubting person. I can see how one can derive humor from the irony in this situation, as I'm a very "I don't care about what other people think about me" kind of person on the outside, but on the inside, I'm a "I'm a failure because everyone else is better than me" kind of person. It's silly how I obsess over these things, that don't really have any true value. I want the buck to stop here, but unfortunately it's not. I hate to say it, but I'm hardwired to hate myself, and I'm trying to accept it.

In other news, I talked to Alex today, for longer than usual, which gets me +3EXP for social skills. One could say that I'm climbing the social ladder, but I suppose everything to this sort of thing is relative. He's such a hopeless machead, but then again, I'm just plain hopeless. Methinks I need a role model.

What else? Well, I'm still in a not-so-very "cool beans" mood about my chemistry. Especially since my results seem to be skewed. Not so fantastic.

I laugh like a duck sometimes. Does that make people think I'm weird?

Otherwise, I'll just keep living my life. But, alas (Yes, I said alas).

Blogger is acting up again and not posting my text, so I'm having to save crap to my hard drive, and I hate doing extra work (well, maybe not always). Blogger will die soon, I think. Within the next... hmm... decade at least. I've got all of my post backed up on multiple floppy disks and hard drives, so complete data loss is very unlikely. Which is good, because losing all of my writings, although they suck, would be very disheartening for me.

On a side note, after school, I helped teachers build their own websites. Lots of people thanked me for my itty-bitty contribution, but the the true reward for the whole event was the feeling of accomplishment. I truly felt good about how I helped in my own little way, and it was a fantastic feeling.

But, to tell you the truth, right now, as I type this, I can't help feeling hopeless again. The euphoric feeling of accomplishment has worn off, and now I feel worthless. I should have drawn something today. Drawing always makes me feel like I've accomplished something, This is probably true because drawing results in tangible results. The kind of results you can hang on your wall, or ink, or color, or scan, or show off to your friends. Writing stories on NaNoWriMo or helping teachers make websites isn't very tangible to me, so the feeling doesn't last as long.

I'm just being greedy and trying to quantify this feeling that isn't even supposed to be quantified. Things like this are supposed to be priceless, but I'm attempting to beg to differ. I'm assigning values to things that do not need or have values.

Why am I ranting on like this? Am I trying to make myself feel better by typing more? If that's the case, I'm sorry, and now I feel like I've wasted your time and I'm hopeless. Stop coming here, I feel so guilty for wasting your time.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Hello.

Blogger is not publishing with Opera, and can only be published using IE for some reason. Firefox crashes on my laptop, so I have to use IE. And I detest that.

My gig of ram should be in a box in front of my door tomorrow. I'm excited for that. I really want to run more than one data-intensive application for once in my life. This gigabyte of RAM will boost my total RAM to 1.5 gigabytes, and that makes me happy, because, hopefully, this will make everything as smooth as glass. I hope after installation things will, as Alex says often, “just work”.

To tell you the truth, I'm not so fantastic with the technical stuff. Sure, my hands are tiny and can get in small places, but I'm very clumsy and not fit for dealing with physically precise things.

I'm not quite sure if this is caused by my heredity, environment, or just chance. But, I shake. I hold a phone to my head, and my arm shakes. I try to hold a pencil still on a piece of paper, but I shake and make zig-zag lines by accident. I try to carefully hold a vial of acid, but my hand shakes, and some of it comes out and spashes onto my hand. I cannot control my shaking. Even when speaking in front of my class, my legs and hands shake, the notecards trembling with my hands, vibrating. If I'm making a speech my voice wavers nervously. It continues to embarrass me, but I can't control it. I try to continuously move, in one way or another, by making hand gestures so my shaking is not so evident. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.

Bah, but what is with me and finding every defective thing about me.

This website isn't going on my resume, that's for sure.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I'm glad to say that I'm typing from a computer that is not chained to the slowness of hard drive-stored data. I'm glad to say that I'm free, at least for now, of waiting for things to load. I'm free!

The RAM installation went easily and now I get to open lots of programs and not have to wait to change between them. This is very comforting, and soothing. I'm also glad that crucial.com was nice enough to give me 2nd day priority air mail for free. Ordering something on the weekend and getting it by Wednesday, for free? That's fantastic. I applaud you, Crucial.

In other news, I'm starting an initiative to get to sleep faster, and wake up earlier. I believe that this habit will improve my mental status in the mornings, and thus boost my sagging French grade. I theorize that what has been causing my French follies is a combination of my lazy/paranoid studying habits, and my lack of sleep. If I sleep earlier, more sleep will be obtained, and I will be able to function less crazily. That is my plan.

But, otherwise...

Things are "just working", and I smile to that kind of tune.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The RAM is working, but my onboard graphics processor isn't being so happy.

I suspect the cause of my frequent crashing is due to my onboard graphics processor driver. Rolling back to an older driver causes even more crashing. Thus, I will just wait until Intel decides to update their drivers for their graphics processors. Until then, I'll just have to deal with crashing every five hours or so.

I took my chemistry test today. When I took my chemistry test, I was stressed. As I took it, I was stressed. And when I finished it, I was, you guessed it, stressed. Considering that I didn't study for extremely long, I think my actual performance on the test was higher than average. But, it was close. Knowing that getting the test done on time was the key issue, I started the test with a bang, rushing through questions at full speed, not wasting a second to stop to think, just killing off the questions I knew in my head, skipping those I had doubts about. After about thirty minutes of this high-intensity answering, my ears were red from the excitement and effort. The muscles in my hand were a bit sore, to tell you the truth. I'm not a weak person (this statement can be debated liberally), but my hands were red with furious writing.

So, I sigh a concerned sigh. I take a peek at my watch and realize that I only have ten minutes and a good bit of the test still needing to be answered. I write. Write hard.

Ten minutes pass, but the bell rings on the eighth minute. My estimation of time was inaccurate, so I suffered for it. With the last, long question half-way done, I try to paraphrase my answer, and shove it in the stack of tests on the teacher's desk. I rush to the door and take a fateful left. I don't kill anybody, and so I celebrate this luck by rushing, weaving, and pushing my way through the crowd to get to my class.

Practice really does make perfect. After so many months of having to find a way through masses of people, I can easily manage to get to classes, even in the densest of human crowds.

And so, that's how my testing went.

My ears still hurt.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Things to do this weekend:

1. Worry.

2. Be paranoid about chemistry class.

3. Overcome my paranoia by living my Second Life.

4. Feel guilty from being on the computer for so long.

5. Try to overcome guilt by drawing.

6. Feel disappointed from my crappy art.

7. Think about chemistry class again.

8. Worry.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
It goes without saying that I'm not a comformist.

Then why do I care about what other people think about me?

I don't.

Or at least, that's what I tell myself.

But if one pried open my senseless mind, one would find large deposits of self-consciousness.

Alex emailed me about how attending a little meeting this morning would influence my future on the team. I suppose going to the meeting would preserve my "team integrity". I feel guilty about not going to the meeting because of Alex's indication to me that my inate Robotics Club teamness would be sacrificed to my lazyness. But, truely, there would be no purpose for me to go to the meeting. I don't see how I could help in any way, contribute in any way. If going to some meeting for no purpose is supposed to establish myself as a valid member of the club, then I might as well burn the school down and call my homework done.

But, maybe there would have been something for me to do at the meeting. And this is the recurring thought that keeps me in a waking paranoia, the overwhelming guilt that keeps me from relaxing and enjoying life. There's always something that keeps me from being happy. Good things happen to me, but I'm too focused on how bad I am to notice.

And so, as I go to sleep tonight, I wish the fear, the guilt, and the dread would just go away.

But, my tonight my wishes will remain unanswered.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Ryo, I didn't say that your worth as a team member was dependant apon your attendance. I said that your ability to travel with the team is based apon your attendance, which is something that Purdue FIRST Programs places on the team. As experience has shown me, some people can be at every meeting throughout the build season and spend who knows how many extra hours working on things, but have added nothing to the team. I have seen this before and we will certainly be seeing it on our team. Merely being there does nothing, it is what you do that makes all the different.

Everyone who attended the presentation Saturday besides Tyler, John, the advisors, and myself have any experience on a robotics team. The majority of our team has no clue what's going on, and that's fine. It's the rookie year! So, don't worry about it. Be there when you can and learn what you can. Do the best you can do, and that will be all we ask of you.

FIRST isn't about what you know. It isn't about how well you do. FIRST is about the journey and being simply the best you can be.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: *Note: Crikey Duck added to list of links in the comic links section.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Right now, as I sit here in front of my trusty, aged laptop, past my designated sleeping time, I'm experimenting with FurryMUCK.

I've heard stories of intense obsession with this primitive form of a massively multiplayer online game. I've found that there are 330 people on right now, but I've yet to understand how this is all supposed to work out.

MUCK stands for... Well, I know that it's Multi-User-somethingsomething. MUD stands for Multi-User-Dungeon, and I'm assuming FurryMUCK and MUD's are basically the same thing.

I want to explore this furry fandom subculture further, and I think the only way to do so is to delve into the darkness of primitive chatrooms and ages old online forums. But, alas, I've found the holy grail of Furry Fandom. The FurryMUCK.

And so, I should be getting to sleep soon. But, tomorrow, I will venture into the FurryMUCK and see what I can find. If I deem it awesome, I'll put a link up.

*Note: I updated my art.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I had a dream about forgetting to write various papers for English and Chemistry class.

It was fearful.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My sister plays an oboe.

She is very loud and obnoxious. The noise that comes out of that thing is not fit for human ears.

But, she's so very lucky, because she has something that I didn't have back when I was her age.

She's not bashful about playing. She even has the audacity to be proud of the "music" that comes out of her instrument.

And, while listening to her make the whole house vibrate with obnoxious, out of tune notes is frustrating, it made me think.

Back in the day, when I first got my clarinet, I was excited. Like any immature little kid, I played a lot just to... well, show off.

But, the difference between my sister and I is that I stopped being so enthusiastic about my instrument after a week or two. After a week of playing in band, and listening to other clarinets, I learned that I was a horrible instrumentalist. I learned what a true clarinet was supposed to sound, and I learned that I was not capable of emulating that sound. I also learned that the world is cruel, and that there are lots of people who are better than you and aren't afraid to tell you. So, after a few weeks, I began to only play in my room. Practicing became sporadic, as I became more paranoid about other people hearing the junky noise that spewed out of my room. I knew that I was inferior in my skills, and was terribly afraid to admit it, or even confront the challenge that faced me. I hid from the challenge, avoided it at all costs. I ran away from the challenge of being able to play my clarinet.

Even today, I do not know what the names of all the scales are, and have trouble naming the notes by letter. It's a miracle that I've gotten through the public school band program unscathed so far. And I still shy away from practicing, from fear that someone will hear me. I never practice because of it. I'm embarassed to even carry my clarinet case up to my room, because I'm so irrationally afraid that my parents will see the case, and pay special attention to the noise coming from my room.

This obscene paranoia about people criticizing me is somewhat covered up by how I act at school, but my habits say a lot about who I reall am.

I do not scan pictures into my computer and edit them unless my whole family is out of the house.

My family does not know of this website. I hide it from them, deleting all traces of it on my computer every week so my parents will not find it.

My sketchpad is hidden under a secret nook in my wall, behind my desk.

I find ways to steal pencils from my sister so my parents won't think I'm a wasteful person when I lose a pencil.

If I mess up the home network because I pressed a wrong button, I blame it on my ISP.

I prop up a small piece of cardboard onto my door to monitor any traffic that enters my room.

And my life somehow continues to be lived like this. It's one mindless situation, trick, and lie after another.

And the whole situation never fails to confuse me further. My sister has no problem sitting in front of everyone in the living room and blowing out horrid noise that fills a five meter radius with bad vibes. And for some reason, I don't like my sister for this.

She has courage to face social antagonism. I do not have this courage.

I am a coward. A paranoid one at that.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Ryo, we all share your hatred towards the Oboe. And we wish it should die.

Yet again, I play the bassoon, it's older cousin who continues to hate it.

-down with oboes

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I got my Time magazine today, and I found this issue to be about this year's "most amazing inventions".

Immediately, I thought to myself, "Not another stupid article about over-hyped, useless inventions designed to make the layperson excited about the future."

But, it seems this week's issue is indeed about over-hyped, useless inventions.

And as I was reading through this magazine, I was disgusted with the choices of inventions to showcase. The graphical showcase of inventions is a prime example of irrational orders of priority.

Let's see what's on the cover of the magazine. The biggest picture undoubtedly goes to the cloned dog. That makes sense. I approve of this "invention".

The second biggest picture is of a robot developed by Toshiba. What does this robot do? Well, according to the description, the robot follows people.

No, really. That's all it does. It doesn't come with a new fandangled media player, it doesn't come with life-saving emergency medical equipment, and it sure doesn't come with a back up battery. So, what's the point of a robot that follows you? Well, I'm sure there's a reason for it existing, but what I find absurd is that this "follow me" robot gets a bigger spot than a number of truely useful inventions that should have taken top spot.

Other things on the cover page include a foldable keyboard, a satellite radio player, a concept-vehicle, a robotic hand, and a plastic mask.

Yes, a plastic mask. It's shaped like a happy face and basically, the only thing you can do with it is put it on, look into your bathroom mirror, and realize how stupid you are for calling it one of the "most amazing inventions of 2005".

No where on the cover page is the "LifeStraw" that is mentioned in a tiny, 1/5 page blurb deep in the article. This is a straw that filters drinking water to make it safe for drinking.

2 million people die of waterborne illness a year. This $3 straw could save these people. And the "follow me" robot and the idiotic plastic mask are shown more than this!? It's absurd that someone would celebrate such an idiotic "invention", if you can even call it that, like a plastic mask shaped like a happy face.

The happy face mask has no chance to save 2 million people. The "follow me" robot has no chance to save 2 million people. Even the cloned dog has no chance to save 2 million people. But, this amazing "LifeStraw" can! Why is it pushed aside in the article to make room for big pictures of the "Xbox360" and the "PSP"? How can one value game consoles with a higher esteem than a life saving device!?

I'm sickened by this. We, the people of the post-industrial world are too busy gawking at robots and playing console games to help dying people in pre-industrial nations.

And that is absolutely unacceptable.

Time magazine, shame on you.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: The happy face mask is actually a funnel and it is featured in another section of the magazine, The Web Shopping Guide, and presented as a gift idea for someone who likes to cook. It is not one of the most amazing inventions. Just thought I'd clear that up.

Then why the fuck is it on the front cover along with a number of other "amazing inventions"?

Nevermind, you're right.

Either way, it's still absurd that the plastic funnel mask gets more coverspace than the LifeStraw.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I believe that I can safely say that my biological clock has been trained correctly, to correspond with my "wake-up early" initiative I started awhile ago.

By setting my alarm to play NPR early in the morning, I have trained my mind to wake me up a few seconds before the alarm goes off, so I can enjoy the morning news. I tested myself this morning by turning off the alarm function on my bedside clock. To my delight, I woke up a few minutes before the designated awakening time, and managed to push the "on" button that resides on the clock, manually triggering my alarm to wake me up. This was quite an accomplishment, as now I can breathe easier, knowing that if my alarm fails, my mind will not.

I am anticipating great chaos and homework-filled agony tomorrow, as I will have a QuizBowl meet that will last much too long for my tastes. Hopefully, I'll repress my tendancy to have a nervous breakdown in the face of homework that does not make sense to me.

The only thing I can do now is wait and hope for the worst, as I often do.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I find slight humor in the trends that apply to the taking of tests. Well, at least in my schedule, tests seem to come in giant waves of ultimate destuction and doom. For example, tomorrow will mark the day that I take 5 tests. And of course, because I got home late because of a QuizBowl match today, I have not studied adequately for these five tests. Thus, I theorize that my grades will falter in the coming days because of the situation I am in now. If I stay up and do some hardcore studying, I won't be awake enough to even take the tests, but if I do not do any more studying, the grades I get on the tests will seem like I haven't even taken them. It's quite a hopeless situation, but my gut instincts usually keep my test scores higher than they should be.

French, AlgebraII, World History, English, and Personal Law. These tests.

And you know what? I feel not so fantastic.

By the time you know it, I'll be in a mental institution.

Until then, I'll manage.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I added some colorful buttons to spruce up the page. These buttons are there to describe who I am, what I use, and misc. things about me. Clicking on the buttons will lead you to more information about that aspect of who I am, albeit on a third-party site.

Anyways, I'm up late, looking for an encyclopedia for my iPAQ, but I'm not coming up with anything. I remember, a year ago, I had an encyclopedia for my older model, but it all got erased in the "Great Hard Drive Crash of 2004". Yes, it was a horrible moment. Wait, maybe it was the "Great Hard Drive Crash of 2003". I can't quite remember, but I do remember a hard drive crashed, and the trauma that followed.

For three days now, Alex and I have been conversing via email, and it's been very neat. This is the first time someone like me is out there, someone who has no problem having a conversation over email, someone who's prompt and articulate. For the first time in my life, I feel like I'm really talking to another human over email.

Previous emails in my life were usually one sentence long back-and-forth nonsense. It was mindless bantering that went no where, and had no purpose. Each email sent was basically a witty counter-comment to the email recieved. For the longest time, I accepted this as a fact of life. I accepted it that I would never be able to find someone who checks their email more than once every two hours. I accepted that everyone used netspeak, everyone used email to forward junk. The sad thing is, I was never, until now, able to find someone who uses email so avidly as I do. Previously, it seemed that the only reason everyone used email was to occasionally send a text file or song, but not for deep conversation. The topics I'm discussing with Alex right now may not be the most deep, but it sure is something new. It's like rediscovering your favorite toy, finding it in a dusty corner of a closet, putting fresh batteries in it, and being delighted by its newfound glory.

Alex seems to be the key to my email salvation.

And so,

Email will rise again.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Some thirty-ish or more people, Iraqis and Americans, died today from people who seem to have a knack of blowing themselves up.

And what are you doing about it? Perhaps you're reading a nice book. Maybe you watched television, or maybe you went to a little party with your friends. Maybe you're sitting content at home, in a nice warm chair, enjoying the comforts that this society can provide you.

And so, what is the value of human life? Some people see existance on Earth as only part of what is to be experienced. But, for people like me, who believe that if one dies, one dies, and does not exist at all, fails to ever again be in a conscious state, what is the value of life?

I value life, human life, very highly. But, I especially value my life over all else. I can't immagine dying, or what happens during death. My memories come from my mind, which handles information that only comes from a conscious state. One cannot experience death truely, unless one dies. But, what happens after that? You can't figure that out until you actually die.

So, those people who are dying overseas, what do they experience during and after death? I would imagine there would be little pain involved in an explosive death. In an instant, your brain and body would be chunks flying through the air. The physical destruction of the cells would end life in a flash.

Is life that fragile? The life that we all hold dear? Isn't it facinating how something so important and mysterious could be taken away in a flash?

And, it's all so odd, that it's a given that more people will die tomorrow. You would think that people would learn to stop killing each other eventually.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Today was one of those days where one gets mad for no apparent reason at an innocent person.

And so, I feel bad. I was very rash in what I said to this person, and I shouldn't have said what I did. I acted like an all-American firebrand. For my personal ego-boosting, I said what was in my mind at the time, and that was a horrible mistake. I sit here and smack my hand with my fist because I feel like such a terrible person. I've been what I've hated for the longest time, an elitist, egotistical, irrational jerk. And, the longer I think about it, the more I start to want to jump off of a high place.

But, guess where I live. In an area that is very flat. The tallest thing I could probably get access to would most likely be my window. The fall would at the very most sprain my ankle. It's a jump from a second story window onto concrete. Even if I jumped head first, surviving would still be a possibilty. And sometimes, when I'm in class I think of running to the roof (3rd story) and jumping, just to freak out the kids in the social studies classes in the front of the school. These classes have big windows that show the whole front of the school, and I think it would be pretty darned hilarious if the class witnessed a body impacting the ground with a damp thud. The school corporation would have to go all out with the trauma counselors and everything. The media would have a party, and think of all of the messed up kids, thirty or so, maybe sixty if someone jumped right between two classes. Am I the only one who finds humor in this?

Truthfully, I'm not suicidal, but I do find humor in morbidness. I figure it's either the desensitization from all of the gory images in medical journals or it's genetic, or perhaps a combination of the two.

Back to the guilt trip I was taking earlier, but attempted to ignore because I'm such an narcissistic jerk.

So I was riding in the car, and I was being hotheaded. I said things, perhaps not directly hostile, but in a manner that conveyed the anger that was not supposed to be expressed. And it continued for fifteen minutes. I drop the person off, still angry at some undefined object, and I go home.

Later, I get to a restaurant and the server gives me a kid's menu. My rage from earlier is just growing. I look at the kid's menu.

"Ages 10 and Under"

And I think to myself, "What the fuck, I'm fifteen and these imbeciles give me a kid's menu?"

For a few minutes, I use my creative imagination to not-so-tastefully envisage a scene in which I beat the server to a bloody pulp over and over again with some blunt object.

It helps a bit.

And I calm down after getting bored of imagining the server's massive head trauma.

I pick up the glass of water and drink the whole thing, and get dizzy.

It helps even more.

But, I'm so inherently evil. Even now, I know I'm storing trace ammounts of that anger, and I know it's going to find one way or another to come back.

This bothers me.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I lost my new pen today.

Between lunch and fifth period, my pen mysteriously vanished out of my pocket. Upon discovering this, I frantically opened up every one of my many pockets, emptied them all out, and asked the people around me if they had seen a pen. It was to no avail. My pen is now MIA, and I've given up hope on recovering my dear writting buddy.

Although a pen may sound insignificant to you, the loss of this crucial writing instrument is not only injuring my productivity, but the loss is also injuring me emotionally. It was going to be my favorite pen, as I spent the whole week before I bought it thinking about buying it. As the last of my old Pilot G-2s began to run out of ink, I fantasized about new pens.

And at the store where I bought my new pens, I went in as a man with a mission. Running to the pen section of the store, I examined the large array of pens of every size and shape, fitting for every budget. I see the trusty G-2s, and beside them is a sight to truely behold. The Pilot Precise V5's stared me down, and I stood in awe. They looked godly, and as my mother gave me a twenty dollar bill to buy school supplies with, I decided to splurge and buy six of them, totaling eight dollars.

I get home and immediately rush up to my room. I rip the packages open, neatly arrange the pens on my desk, and test them out on a notepad. As I suspected from the awe-inspiring moment at the store, they write beautifully.

And, so I go to school and lose one, and it's like losing a new best friend. The emotional toll is staggering. I feel guilty for losing such a great pen, because it was all my fault that I kept it in such a risky place, clipped to my pocket.

From this event, I've learned a valuable life lesson.

Never become best friends with a pen.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I have a purple pen you can borrow..

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Today was definitely a work day.

Lots of work, and homework, and more work, and some more work on top of that. It really is enough work to shake your red, commie fist at.

Right now, I really can't think of anything to say.

Besides being ripped off by the Motorola customer service reps, for the fifth time, I can't think of anything particularly outstanding today.

Wait, actually there is something that stood out today.

At DDR club today, there were 3 people who told me that I looked very sad. I know that at the time, my body was in a critical low-blood-sugar crisis. To curve my intense hunger and dizzyness, I bumbled my way to the nearest vending machine and bought some toaster pastries. I ate them, and got a headache. Too much sugar never helps. The artificial taste of the starchy "bread" part of the pastry did not help my condition.

And so, while in this state of calamity, I apparently looked sad.

The "lesson" learned? (This lesson is the lesson that I usually make up to justify living for one more day)

Hungry people look sad.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I heard something on NPR a few days ago, three days ago to be exact, and it has been bothering me since.

The radio program was an interview of a man who was trying to understand and write an article on what "philanthropy tourism" was, and so in his quest to discover what "philanthropy tourism" was, he went to a village in a poor African nation. This nation I cannot remember, but I do remember what this man spoke of, and his recollection of his experiences.

He went to Africa not really knowing what he was getting into. He really didn't think all that much about it until he was a few minutes away from the village, in a humanitarian aid van.

So, he gets there and makes a speech to the people of this impoverished village. He reminds them, at the aid workers' request, that not all white men would come with cash. And still, he didn't know what he was getting himself into.

While in the village, he found an injured, old man who had trouble walking and moving around because he was severely injured and infected in the leg.

The man being interviewed decided to pay for an operation that the injured, old man needed. The operation cost $100. These 100 dollars would give back the injured man mobility, hope, and purpose. Basically, these 100 dollars would give him life.

Now, this is the thought that struck me so. If a life is worth 100 dollars, are we, as inhabitants of post-industrialized nations, spending our money wisely?

Think of everything in your house that costs more than 100 dollars. Your computer, your television, your excess clothing, jewelry. There are quite a bit of these kinds of things in everyone's home, I imagine. Then, picture each of those things that are worth 100 dollars or more as having a face. Having life.

Those faces are the faces of people who could have lived, but didn't because humanitarian aid did not get to them fast enough. These are the faces of people who are not poor because of their performance as humans, but poor by the luck of draw. These are the faces of people who ask for so little, but recieve even less.

And so I look at myself, and I feel sick to my stomach. I bought 20 dollars worth of pens and markers. And to think, that was one fifth of a person that could have lived, but didn't. I have a computer, nice clothing, and a television. That's 10 people that could have been saved. There are a number of things all around me that I really don't "need".

I say I "need" them, but when you look at everything relatively, isn't life the most important object, if you can even call it that? Isn't sheer existance the driving force in everything? What would be the world if you were dead? What would be a broadband connection after death?

I understand that money can't necessarily buy life, or happiness. One can throw infinite money at any third world country, and it'll most always be diverted to corrupt officials, or wasted in meaningless inefficiency. But, sometimes, money can buy life. Like the man who gave 100 dollars to the ailing man in Africa. As odd as it may sound, he bought back the old man's life.

And, in the same way, money can buy happiness. When you play a video game, doesn't that make you happy? When you turn on the television and watch your favorite show, doesn't that make you happy? When you put on nice clothes, you must feel happy.

But, which would you rather buy? Someone else's life, or your own happiness?

I'm sick of everyone, including myself, buying the later of the two.

This nation is full of people who would not think twice about buying a new gadget or gizmo for 100 dollars or more.

We call life priceless, so why are we ignoring the starvation and pestilence of those overseas?

Is the only "priceless" life our own?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
And Thanksgiving comes to an end.

And no, I did not eat turkey.

What I did today?

Well, for one thing, I learned how to navigate and edit, move, rename, and change user settings from the UNIX terminal in my old Linux computer.

And, I'm learning how to use Blender, a 3d rendering tool. Alex says its user interface bothered him, but I think if I'm going to choose between rough open source and pretty $700 software, I'm going to choose the rough open source. There are even video tutorials for free!

How much better can open source get?

Plans for Black Friday: I'm planning to go to RadioShack to get me one of those cheapo $10 usb webcams. Hopefully, they'll still be there by the time I get there. I really hope so, because I remember last year, when I snatched that last $20 from a crate at the back of Best Buy. It made me feel bad that I took the last one, with all the people lined up behind me, but the early bird gets the worm, right?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Gee willikers...

Today was a fun-work day. This means Black Friday shopping mania, going over to do a movie project, and making things in Blender.

Well if you don't know about Blender already, I'll probably add a button link as soon as I get some sleep.

I feel guilty, but I'm going to not write anymore on the basis that I'm sleep deprived.

Deal with it.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I walk into the bookstore.

It's a chain, so there's no artsy-fartsy social antagonism going on. There is no snazzy jazz music, no roundtable discussions between literature aficionados. There's no fear, because in chain stores, security is guaranteed, service is promised, and there is nothing to get excited about, everything's the same in every store.

That's what I thought.

Through the rows of CDs I walk, and I catch a familiar noise. Nonchalantly stopping and turning toward the CDs, attempting to look inconspicuous, I listen in, trying to figure out what the sound was, and where it was coming from. I think hard, and the sound comes back, from the right, about two rows of CDs between me and the audio source. And then I identify the noise as the sound of someone speaking.

It's so familiar, like a tune one can recognize from afar, the kind of tone that is as familiar as one's own home. This person keeps talking, and slowly, I come to the conclusion that it is someone I know, a female.

I don't believe myself. She couldn't be here, not her. But, I keep thinking, and I reason out that the chances of her being at this store in particular at this time of day, about 6pm, are very high, as she lives very near to this bookstore.

My hands begin to swell, sweat with panic, my heart beats like an angry techie bashing the brains out of his Motorola cell phone (take that, biznatch Motorola people. Hello Moto this!). My mind races in circles, trying to grasp the situation.

And now, as I think back, I don't understand why I got so excited at something so mundane. After all, she practially lives in the store (geographically). It's nothing amazing to see her. But, for some reason, my mind went nuts, and although I currently don't get why, it still happened the way it happened.

Back to the CD shelves. There's a crack between the rows of CDs. The voice gets closer and closer. I try to move myself, to run away, hide in the computer-book section. My feet don't move, and all I can do is stare into that crack between the row of CDs like a deer.

For an instant, a split second, the world stops. Time stops, and nothing moves. She looks streight at me, or appears to. I freeze, and the world around me freezes, and she freezes. We're frozen. The world spins around in circles, and finally time thaws itself into a lukewarm mush.

She doesn't notice me. I sigh a relieved sigh and trot back to my homeland, the computer-book section to plan my next course of action. On my way, I stop and turn back. Out of curiosity, I peek into the row she's in. My heart races again, and I like it. She still doesn't seem to see me. For a few seconds, I try to focus, but I can't.

I get the odd idea to run past her in the row to see if she will notice me. Thinking back, it was completely pointless, and I don't understand why I was so excited by this sneaking. I must be some sick freak.

But, I hold my breath, run past, rush through the row, and trot back to my hiding place. My head is pounding. A natural high rushes through my body. I run back to the row, and peek into the row she's in and see that she hasn't noticed me.

For the next 15 minutes, I facinate myself by seeing how many times I can come into her field of vision unnoticed. She never notices.

And I go home confused, having hid from someone that I talk to every day at school.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Today, I got even feistier with Blender. I made three models, spent about 6 hours modeling, and am trying to create an industrial landscape/building similar to the petroleum tank above.

But, the really odd thing is, this program has gotten to my head. I find myself trying to control reality using the hotkeys, trying to navigate through 3d space using the middle mouse button, shift, and the numeric keypad. I look at a building and see not a building, but see the building as planes made up of vertices and textures, the curves being simulated by computer algorithms. To move around, I try to hold down the shift key and drag, but find my hands clicking buttons that aren't there, my eyes staring into a monitor that does not exist.

And after using the program for so long, it's hard to draw a line between simulated reality, and reality itself. What I see on the computer is just as realistic to me as what I see outside of the computer. I'm slowly adjusting to handling 2 worlds at once, but it's sometimes confusing. The hotkeys for movement, edge selection, and scaling is so wired into my brain.

But, I think it's all worth it. Discovering Blender was and is like discovering the pen and pencil all over again. It's a new tool, a fun new tool to build a world out of nothing, and make it look good too.

So, that's the end of the fabled "Thanksgiving Weekend".

Now it's time to hit ground running, so to speak, and go to school tomorrow. Yippee!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Did you make that petrolium tank? That looks like a photograph. Very realistic and amazing. I feel like I shall cry because of the inspiration.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The sleep and food thing have really been working against me from the beginning.

From how I see the world, sleep and food are really just redundant obstacles in life, something that must be done, but accomplishes nothing. I didn't eat lunch today, and only got 6-7 hours of sleep last night. This did not bode well for me today. My head was dizzy the whole school day, and I couldn't focus, not that I could anyways. Yawning was a problem, and I really wanted to collapse in the hallway and just sleep. But, to tell you the truth, if there was one thing that would be my dream, it would be to become a robot. Having no sleep or no food means no worries! Mechanical failure could easily be repaired, and parts would be replacable. Data integration and electronic collaboration would greatly increase productivity. No more clunky plastic keyboards and mouses for our primitive human hands. It would be just plug, install necessary drivers, and manipulate data without the restrictions of a physical entity to move. Energy wouldn't be a matter of buying food, but plugging one's self into the grid to "eat" the electricity from burning petrol.

Who knows, perhaps I will get my wish someday.

Or maybe not.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
If there's something that changed today, it would be my outlook on Robotics Club.

I sacrificed quite a few things to be with semi-strangers, in a setting that I was not accustomed to, doing a thing that I was not experienced at doing. The Robotics Club met up in a woodworking area in the school and we built a crate together. This cratebuilding began at six in the evening. Because I found travelling 30 minutes to my home as an inefficient waste of time, I decided to just rough out the two hours between DDR Club and Robotics. So, I did tough it out. I sat in the cafeteria windowsill for two hours, doing homework. And sometimes, the best times are when you are alone. While I was sitting there, talking to myself as I did my chemistry, I felt good. I felt good about getting something done, that being my chemistry worksheet. I felt good about doing it on my own. I felt good being in an empty, dark windowsill. The hum of the janitor's cleaning machines and the whir of the vending units created an atmosphere of mechanical clarity. The background noise did not distract me, but instead drowned out my voice, so I could talk to myself without the risk of alerting a janitor to my presence. And so, I sat in a dark cafeteria for two hours, in peace.

I came into the woodshop at six in the evening, just as planned. To tell you the truth, I had doubts, and perhaps I still do have doubts. I had doubts about this whole the whole Robotics Team getting something done, working together. From the body language from the previous meetings, I've personally felt that the group dynamics weren't so preferable in this Team. We've got really smart people, really quiet people, really loud people, really mundane people, and really calm people on hand. But, the feel of the team was, and still is, a bit rough, gritty like sandpaper. And this is why I did not pay my T-shirt fee,

because I thought to myself, "If this meeting doesn't go so well, I can quit and I won't lose any cash."

And so even though I had my money in my pocket, I held onto it along with the doubt that locked me into a rock and a hard place, so to speak.

The meeting went smoothly, and things worked out. As Alex often says, "It just works."

And this time, like many other times, Alex was right. It did "just work", and the amazing thing about it was that it didn't "just work", but it actually impressed me.
