With communication, things got done, and quite efficiently at that. People didn't bicker, people didn't shout. The people on the team made me feel not like an outsider, but like a real life person. And I felt good about it. My peers, and myself as well, impressed me, and because of this my doubt is eradicated.

So, the moral ditty for today?

Well, why the fuck should I even call these things morals? These things are just things that I should have figured out a long time ago, but haven't. They just seem like morals because I'm too incompetent to discover them like everyone else has. But I digress...

Being alone is always fantastic, but being part of a group isn't all that bad either.

The above statement sounds like something you'd read in one of those idiotic "Chicken Soup for the Soul". If this bothers you in any way, you're not alone, because it sure does bother me.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The previous day's inspiration turned mushy overnight. The same thoughts, the same doubts, the same insecurities, the same nonsense that keeps corrupting my head every day.

And so, I went home, and thought about fundraising.

And I waited, for an hour, sitting in my room, doing math homework, staring out the window, and at my pencil, listening to some jazz...

I was pondering if I should go out into the cold and sell these overpriced pastries to complete strangers, in exchange for a spot on the Robotics Team. And I sat and pondered for an hour. The multiple analog clocks in my room tick and I become acutely aware that time is passing me by, and all I'm doing is sitting in my room thinking about something.

And I thought to myself, "Even the greatest of people cannot get things done if all they do is think of them."

So, I grabbed the order form, snatched my jacket, and was out the door as fast as you can say, "ripoff frozen pastries".

I walked, with my feet, and moved through space with only skin to protect my hands. A big mistake. Over time, perhaps say 30 minutes, my hands became red. This was no ordinary red, but a strange shade of red that facinates the eyes, a skin so oddly... well, odd... that it mystifies the one who is looking at the skin. That is, until you feel the sharp, pain and then the throbbing dull pain that follows such facination.

I dismissed it and trudged on.

The things I do for acceptance, sheesh!

And I walk and I walk, more like hobble. Wheezing, I make it to some random house that I've passed hundreds of times in my life, but never took the time to meet the people inside. I ring the doorbell. Too cold to be nervous, I wait for a few minutes. No one answers. I wait some more. After all, you never know what's going on in these houses. Perhaps the occupants of this house have some sort of religious ceremony going on in there, or maybe a cannibalistic sacrifice, or maybe drug dealing...

Who knows?

Anyways, after about 2 minutes pass, I get fed up with people not answering my call for money, and I run home. More like trudge. And the hardest thing about it was that the faster I ran home, the colder it felt because of the wind.

After what seems to be hours, days, weeks, years of diligent trudging, I make it home. I run into the living room and collapse. I have a conversation with the carpet while my mind regains control over my body. My hands are still that strange red color, and now my face is that color as well. The skin exposed to the wind starts to feel tingly, then stings. I still haven't regained control.

In the end, I sold 9 of these frozen pastries. Was it all worth it?

Who knows?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Ryo -

9 braids is good. keep up the hard work and don't get discouraged. you've sold 9 more braids than jason and I have combined. again, congratulations on the sale. i'll see you sunday.

~Collin

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
It seems that whenever I'm given time, I waste it away, but when I make my own time, I use it like there's no tomorrow.

I think this statement can apply to a number of things in life. I can plug in any word for "time", and it'll come out all the same. Money, art, respect, power, etc. I suppose it has to do with our inherent nature to value those things that we have suffered to create. I suppose even in our "sophisticated" reasoning systems, we all have a bit of self-centeredness. The things other people strive to create are thrown away, trashed.

We throw away plastics, old electronics, half-empty cans of soda, and a whole number of other things. I think it's maybe because other people have strived to create these items.

In third world countries, people keep plastic bottles, eat and drink every last bit of food they can get. Yes, it's mostly for necessity, but they work hard to survive and aquire these items.

And sometimes I wonder if we'll ever run out of things to throw away.

But, then again, ignoring the situation always makes one feel safer.

Is it all about me?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
There's nothing I can do about it.

I have a terrible cold.

Thus, I took some medicine, and now I'm in a drug-induced stupor.

This sort of feeling is the kind of feeling that makes everything around you seem like a dream. I can't feel my face. When I run my fingers through my hair, the hair doesn't feel like it's mine. I wash my hands, but it feels like there's no water, and I'm just going through the motions on instinct. And when I walk, I float.

My homework is to read a section in a book I have. I don't think I'll be able to do it because the words on the page don't make any sense to me right now.

I don't see how I'll survive tomorrow's QuizBowl tournament.

Say farewell to this screwed guy.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I suppose one could call it guilt.

But guilt is more of a word than a feeling. I didn't go to a QuizBowl meet today because I was in no condition to answer random trivia. Although I know for a fact that me going to this meet would have caused more chaos than good, I still feel guilty. A bad, dark feeling of shame. That I failed my comrades that trudged out to the killing fields to bring back a trophy. I failed Zach especially. He spent every day this last week eagerly asking me if I was ready. I always responded to his pestering, but innocent questioning with an enthusiastic "yes". But, now that I think back to it all, all those times I replied to him with an enthusiastic cry of team spirit, I failed. The exuberance of the moments I've come in contact with my QuizBowl teammates, are now wasted away. Because of this stupid virus I have.

The stupid virus that makes me wheeze, cough up mucus, and take medications to force me into a drug-induced stupor.

It's infuriating to be guilty of something you couldn't have controlled. But, in reality I could have controlled it. Hygene, and viral vigilance could have been emphasized more last week, but it wasn't. And here I am, feeling miserable from my cold, and even more miserable from the undeniable guilt of not fulfilling an obligation to the things, and people I hold dear to me.

This is what happens when one is not careful enough.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: My chest has this dull pain, so breathing sucks (I gain 5exp for pun!) The only thing I've been able to get myself to do is make things in Blender. So, enjoy the render.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I've gotten past the brunt of the storm.

Now, it's a matter of time before I'm better, in school, and reading a poem about suicide bombers.

You know, it's really odd how things so far away... seem far away. I mean, with this new technology, telecommunications advancements, journalistic ideals, and televised newscasts, one can be attached to the world, like everything going on in the world is a big mesh, and you're the one trapped inside of it.

But, unfortunately (or fortunately), it's all an illusion. A trick of our primal mind and the telecom giants.

Everyone knows about suicide bombers, IED's, world hunger, civil wars, dictators, and economic strife. But it's all so far away. At least to me. They're things that one can sit at home and see on the television, but turn off and go back to eating dinner. It's something that you see from an electric box, not something someone is going through across the globe. For all I, we, and you know, the stuff being spit out of the news could all be just a bad dream. The people I know at school, have no idea. I have no idea. I don't think anyone has any spec of an idea of how life is like away from comfort.

There's this one kid in my English class that is just clueless as to what the darker side of the world is like. Just to satisfy my sick mind, I have this urge to beat a cat to a bloody pulp in front of her face, because her cluelessness bothers me so.

But, I suppose it's not a matter of if she'll see death and destruction, but a matter of when.

But, who cares? How I see it, the pain doesn't matter until it hits.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I suppose it's a matter of me having a problem with my ego or something.

And it's odd because I've never really learned what "ego" means. It's just something that one can infer from how people use it, talk about it, and interpret it. Ego always seemed to be such an odd word for me. It looks a lot like "egg", and "lego", but it doesn't quite mean the same thing.

Let's see... Ego can mean:

1. self: your consciousness of your own identity

2. Elektrik Gaz Otobüs İşletmesi , which is the bus and metro operator of Ankara.

or,

3. A four-piece rock band from Lisburn, Northern Ireland

I think I'm using ego in the first context, as in how I percieve myself, and how I see others see me.

It's a sham, my whole life.

Actually, maybe, not my whole life. But, it was a sham this afternoon.

Wallowing in self-pity/disgust, the only topic of conversation I could come up with was how I failed today's chemistry test.

And it was stupid. I just kept going up to people to talk about how I failed, and who knows why.

Actually, I know why. I did it because I'm a stupid, egotistical jerk that wants to let everyone know I failed because my idiotic mind can't comprehend how I, in all my amazingness, failed a test. And yes, I'm embarrassed now that I think about it, because there's no point in being a sore, obnoxious loser. Just because all of my peers were able to finish a test and I didn't doesn't mean that I can just go on a giant rant and annoy people with my foolishness. It's just so, illogical, how I acted.

But, I did. And that's just how it's going to be. Because one cannot change what has already past. It's behind me. I suppose I'll just make a new initiative to stop complaining so blatantly to other people because I know that I'm going to fail tests in the future, and it doesn't really even matter, because a test is a test.

Pass or fail, everyone gets a fair grade.

I deserved to fail.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Things are getting more and more hectic every day.

Mind you, I'm not complaining... but...

Ok, fine then. I'm complaining.

They say, the first step to getting over your problems is to admit that you have one.

But, nonetheless, I still think the workload on my shoulders is getting heavier as each day passes. No doubt many of my peers think so too. I mean, it's getting close to final's week, getting close to the week-long holiday hiatus. It's a matter of time before I'm on a van to Florida. But, before this, I must trudge through finals. The Finals.

The Finals have a way of sneaking up on you. I'm anticipating for them, but it's hard to brace for something that only comes up twice a year. It's something that one attempts to push to the back of the mind, if only for comfort, until the Week of Judgement. Which, by the way, would happen to fall on the week before the holiday hiatus I mentioned above.

Tests, trials, examinations, whatever you'd like to call these things, they're necessary. And I'm sure many of us (using "us" to refer to the students of the post-industrial world) would like to do away with these pieces of paper (or computer screen, if you go to some artsy-fartsy rich school) and just go home to the comfort of our rooms (or second home in the Netherlands if you're some artsy-fartsy rich snob). But, wishes will not do away with these monsters. It's a matter of time before I'm convulsing on the floor, trying to figure out how astrology was used in medieval times.

It's just a matter of time...

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
While looking through my various furry forums, I happened to catch a glimpse of a name I remembered from a month or so ago.

Paul Escobar.

My heart beats a bit faster, and I get excited. The post states that the link is to Paul's newly minted site, featuring his art. I really hope the link isn't broken or the post is just some spam.

But, the link is indeed genuine. Upon clicking the link, I am redirected to Paul Escobar's site, and I sit in my chair, trying to cling to the tiny morsel of satisfaction that I feel from discovering such a wonderful place.

I read around, and find out it was created yesterday. And my meager satisfaction grows to pride. I look at his art and it makes me happy.

Then, being the bold person I am, I decide to email him and tell him what I think.
-------------------------
Subject: Mr. Escobar, you are my hero.From: Ryo Chiba Tue, Dec 6, 2005 at 6:08 PM
To: artdevnull@gmail.com

Ever since one day... ever so long ago.

Perhaps it was about a year ago. I'm not quite sure.

I've been facinated by your art, and your name I have remembered.

Thus, when I stumbled upon your humble site (obsessively searching
forum posts does much to one's mind), I was delighted to find art by
you.

Well, I suppose you'll read this, roll your eyes, and delete it,
thinking "What another crazy fanboy"...

So I guess I won't waste any more of your precious time. After all, to
me, bothering you is like bothering some otherworldly god.

Just know that you've got fans, and one of 'ems me.
--------------------

And I wait for a day, and it just so happens Paul is the kind of person that is famous enough to be known on all the furry forums, but not famous enough to ignore fanmail. Opening Paul's email was like opening a big, sparkly present. Joy, joy, joy! And here it is:

----------------
From: Paul Escobar Wed, Dec 7, 2005 at 9:06 AM
To: Ryo Chiba

Thank you for your flattering words, that's very kind of you.

While I did make my site for my own dubious entertainment, it's nice to know that there are other people who like having a look at it.

Again, thank you, and have a nice day!

cheers,
Paul
----------------

And I smile. One of my major idols decides to thank me. What an odd turn of events, and how flattering!

*Note: Paul's site: http://artdevnull.com/index.html

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
This is what "The Geographical Reader, for the Dixie Children by Marinda Branson Moore, 1829-1864" has to say about "Races of Men."


---------------------------------
LESSON X.
Races of Men.

The men who inhabit the globe, are not all alike. Those in Europe and America are mostly white and are called the Caucasian race. This race is civilized, and is far above the others. They have schools and churches and live in fine style. They also generally have wise and good men for rulers, and a regular form of government. The women are treated with respect and tenderness, and in many cases their wish is law among their male friends.

2. There is a class of people who inhabit most of Asia which is of a yellow color. They are a quiet, plodding race, but when educated are sensible and shrewd. They have some books, and a regular form of government, but they are heathen; I mean by this that they worship images made of wood and stone. They do not know about Jesus. And yet they pray to those idols much oftener than we christians do to our Savior. This race is called the Mongolion. Missionaries have been sent to teach them about Jesus. When they every become converted, they hold fast their profession, and are not fickle like some races.

3. When the white people came to this country, they found a red or copper colored race. This people they named Indians, because they thought they had sailed west until they had come to India in Asia. They were tall, with long black hair, and high cheekbones. They went nearly naked, and were cruel, and warlike. They were good friends, but terrible enemies. They were governed by Chiefs, and had not books. The women performed most of the labor, and were called Squaws. This is called the American race. They now have books, schools and churches, and many of them learn about Jesus.

4. The African or negro race is found in Africa. They are slothful and vicious, but possess little cunning. They are very cruel to each other, and when they have want they sell their prisoners to the white people for slaves. They know nothing of Jesus, and the climate in Africa is so unhealthy that white men can scarcely go there to preach to them. The slaves who are found in America are in much better condition. They are better fed, better clothed, and better instructed than in their native country.
---------------------------------------

This passage amuses me. It amuses me in the fact that only a century and a half ago, this book was "the truth", according to the people set aside to educate America's youth.

And yet, the same barriers persist. Undeniably, there is still racial division and prejudice in this country.

But, why?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I'm doing some late night chemistry.

And no, that is not innuendo. I am working on a large chemistry worksheet packet. It's very difficult. The questions aren't difficult, it's just that I'm very tired, distracted, and cold.

This evening, I went to the local bookstore chain with a friend to unwind after my intense chemistry session. So I'm talking to him, and he talks about how he's a "trekkie" and how he fits into this niche in the trekkie world.

And it clicks in my mind.

At that split second, I suddenly relate to him. I realize that the Trekkie subculture and the Furry subculture are meticulously interconnected. Although the "genres" of the subcultures, the public view on these subcultures, and outward appearance of these subcultures is so inherently different, they are so closely connected. The first Furry cons started out as a subculture within the already bustling and popular sci-fi subculture. At these giant sci-fi cons, there would be a budding furrycon. And so there the fire of fandom kindled until the two subcultures split.

And so, at that moment, there was sort of a very comforting feeling around me because I knew that there were others.

And I thought that was extraordinary.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I think that knowing is only half the battle.

Or something like that. I read it all the time in books and inspirational brochures that they hand out at corporately sponsored sex-ed "convos" at my high school.

Because one may know how to use equipment, but Alex's "it just works" saying does not apply. For example, my cellular telephone is dead. The screen has broken, the battery is worn out, and the speakers on it are busted. However much I know about how to fix phones, the Motorola customer "service" people are still going to hassle me by telling me that nothing is broken.

So I sent my phone in a month ago, right? Well, they send it back, I look on the paper form the sent with the phone, and I see a little message neatly typed in a little box labled, "issue".

The message reads, "No prblms".

This frustrates me. My phone clearly lacks any capacity to ring, display information, or even connect to any cellular telephone service. Without working speakers, screen, and battery, this phone is just a lump of plastic and metal that takes up space. And to think, they "rigorously examine" and "test" each phone to make sure it meets "quality" standards.

What kind of quality standards? Very bad quality standards.

If they're going to keep letting crap like this end up in the hands of consumers, I'm never going to buy a cellular phone, or suscribe to cellular phone service ever again. The broadband phone connection I have right now is much better quality than that rubbish they sell at those seedy cell phone retailers. I find it degrading to call the Motorola hotline six, yes six, times to get them to send me a shipping label, and then have the "technicians" tell me that nothing is wrong with my phone. It's absolutely absurd!

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Sob story time, with Ryo Chiba!

I take my French test, and I finish five minutes after everyone else. The teacher always gives me this quirky smile before each test. I always shoot back a grimace of confidence. And, always, I fail to match my confident presentation to the teacher. I'm always the last one to finish any test, and I don't get good marks on these things either.

So, I finish the test, but I let it sit at my desk. I mull over a question that I'm not sure on. Mull over it for quite some time. Mull over it for enough time to frustrate me. I begin to believe that my entire test hinges on this one question. The answer I wrote down in the blank is a mere guess, but if it's right, it's going to be a good day. If I'm wrong, then I'm a loser, a failure, a shame of the human race.

The question stares back at me like an angry dog. It hates me. The question wants to be answered, but it isn't being fulfilled, and I can sense that. I stare back at it, thinking that somehow, my idiotic hostile behavior is justified by my low French scores.

The teacher collects the test, and I walk out of class, nervous. Not confident at all.

I find out the question is wrong. And I engage "Oh, woe is me" mode. For the whole day, I'm in "woe is me" mode, spreading my ill-feelings to those around me.

At the time, I knew that it was pointless to "cry over spilled milk", so to speak, but I did anyways, because sometimes negative sensations cause people to do stupid things. Thinking back, I find it even more despicable that I sink to that level.

To think, I sicken myself, but sickening myself just makes me feel sicker.

Why in the hell are you reading this? This is nonsensical, worthless text. It lacks any satisfactory content whatsoever. Bah!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Ryo - don't sweat French...I scraped through and haven't used it sense. Don't be so hard on yourself; it only makes things worse. If you truly want to feel any better, just admit that you've done the best you can and there was nothing more to do. Only then can you stop the negative cycle. Have a good one, Ryo, and enjoy your break.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I feel bad right now due to a deep sensation of unproductivity.

Inside, I know I've got loads of work to do, mostly studying for finals. Studying for finals entails organizing facts and refrences for all of my essays that I'm going to have to write, brute memorization of a number of vocabulary words in multiple languages, and reading through old tests to refresh old concepts in my mind. Due to this overwhelming workload, I feel like I constantly need to be doing something to justify my existance.

Currently, I'm not doing anything of the sort. I'm not jotting down notes for the English essay, I'm not reading through my math notebook, I'm not even memorizing the irregular verbs in French. It feels disheartening, but I just can't get myself to do it all. It's all surreal.

On a side note, at QuizBowl today, I realized that I'm very slow compared to my peers. There's this very loud girl that's on my QuizBowl team that bothers me sometimes. I manage to get along with here well though. She's in my French class.

Often, in French class, she raises her hand to speak French. I'm not quite sure why one would go about doing this, but in a way, I admire her boldness to stand up against silence and fear. But, one side of me doesn't like her very much. This one side finds her to be a self-centered jerk that likes to impress the teacher for the sake of... well, impressing the teacher.

But, that one cruel side of me is being very unfair. She really is a very intelligent, rational person. But, quaint civility seems to elude her. She is not able to control herself when she is thinking impolite thoughts. Sometimes, she exploits opportunities to boast about her superiority. Quite frankly, I feel like an idiot when I talk to her. It hurts me, but I just smile and go along with her jibes and jokes. I tell myself that what other people think of me doesn't matter, but inside, I really know that it does. Because, if it didn't why would I be thinking of it right now?

One of my peers told me that I can be self-centered sometimes, often actually. It hurts me terribly to find someone telling me that I'm hurting other people just like other people hurt me.

So, at QuizBowl today, for hours, I went along with the silly jokes. I went along with the jovial antics, demonstrating my stupidity. At the time, I thought that was the only way to approach the matter in a socially acceptable manner, but now that I think deeper about it, I believe that I acted out of my place. I should not have gone along with all the jokes.

My self-esteem suffers because of it.

And so, deeper and deeper the wound gets.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Currently, I am praying to my mystical computer idol.

The reason?

I really, truely hope that my computer doesn't crash right now. This is due to the fact that I am burning a DVD, uploading a video file, rendering an animation, playing music, refreshing RSS feeds, ripping music from internet radio, and updating my blog on my trusty Dimension 4700 right now. If it crashes, oh, I'll be quite disappointed.

So, my accomplishment of the day? That would either have to be surviving Ms. Henderson's English class, or learning how to keyframe, use IPO curves, and animate in Blender. I'm siding more with the later.

I have figured out that rendering takes a long time. I've got 520 frames, which translates to roughly 20 seconds, give or take a few seconds, and each frame takes 22 seconds to render. This computes to a little more than 3 hours. I think the render to product ratio is very disproportionate in this situation. 3 hours of hardcore computing to produce 20 seconds of video? I find rendering very time consuming. But, one must remember that I am creating something out of nothing. Well, I'm not. The computer is the one creating something out of nothing.

It's an amazing thing, these computers. You put work in, and products come out.

In this case, the product will be my 20 second video file that I'll be waiting all night for.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Finals week is approaching quickly.

Commence the studying I say to thee!

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I feel dizzy.

I haven't studied.

I can't concentrate.

I should have studied.

But why didn't I?

Well, to tell you the truth, it's because I'm a lazy imbecile.

So, because of this fact, I am going to go to bed early so I can wake up early tomorrow morning and go on a studying binge.

Wish me good luck.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
If there was one person who I'd admire the most, it would have to be the man who cuts my hair.

Imagine dedicating one's own life to the art of cutting off fuzz from other peoples' heads. That kind of commitment is the kind of thing that I admire. Barbers shine with honor, those valiant men and women who make a living by doing something so mundane. Truely, it's amazing that there are people out there who set their ego aside to do this.

But, I see people who work in salons in a lower regard. From my experience, they continue to hoard their egos, using overpriced substances (how else can I describe these things?) to enhance one's look. I find this dastardly idiotic.

In other news, I'm still obsessed with Blender. I'm absolutely estatic about my large Blender book being shipped to me as I speak.

I have a band and law final tomorrow. With luck, I will manage.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I believe that I'm motivated to accomplish things because my parents don't appreciate the things I get done.

It sounds selfish, but to me, it's the truth. Today, I spent five hours modeling and rigging a humanoid robot, and my father had nothing to say about it. It wasn't that he was dumbfounded with awe, but his silence was more of a signal that he didn't really even care enough to comment. And so, I go to school every day, do well, my parents don't really care. My grades are set, or at least that's what they think, because ever since the second grade, they've never even taken a look at my report cards. And why do I even try when no one cares?

Well, oddly enough, I have this innate craving to impress my parents. Not really "oddly enough" though. I'm sure this primal urge to brag, boast, and rant about one's life is somewhat hard-wired into everyone's brain. Or at least, that's what I keep telling myself so I don't feel like a jackass every five seconds.

And I keep working, hoping that someday they'll notice that I even exist. Really, that hope will never die down, even though the chances of them noticing are very slim. If only to get them to notice, I would do something great, or try to do something great. An accomplishment that could be valued. To be something, someone in life.

But, I suppose that's how I describe my mad dash to become a hardcore blenderite. Perhaps, this is why I strive to understand this program, and to get things done in my lifetime. And although it seems like a pointless and horribly vain objective, to me, it's all the reason to keep trying.

"Nonsense!", I tell myself.

But my brain thinks otherwise.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Ryo - haven't "checked in" for a while, so I thought I would. I used to be in the same boat...feeling that my accomplishments were for approval, parental acceptance, etc. It's a very shallow feeling when one realizes that all the hard work is for not. Then I decided to make school "for me." I started caring about school because it represented me. It made all the difference. You're a good guy - enjoy your break...you deserve it.

JK

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The answer to all of your problems are simple.

If gas prices are too high, then don't use as much gas. Complaining about prices is bad enough, but contributing to global pollution, increasing demand, and complaining about prices is as bad as tying a newborn to a rabid cat. With no doubt, this issue bothers me. I don't see how anyone could justifiably banter on about how gas is so expensive. One can take a stroll down any nearby parking area and see idling cars. Cars that have no one in them, but are still combusting their fuel. Heating, working, moving. The gasoline is wasted, but the exhaust is not. It flies up into the air and contributes to the atmospheric soup that we live in. Whether that contribution is negative is debatable, but one can only surmise that it is our society's fault for this increase in price. It's a simple matter of supply and demand, but people, as a whole, don't seem to understand this.

Yes, if you plot the sales of SUVs and inefficient, overpriced, "beautiful" cars one can see a noticeable dip. But, the fact that these hunks of oil-consuming metal are still rather present on roads is an indication that there are indeed people who don't get the message.

Yes, if you plot the sales of hybrid vehicles, one can see a noticeable increase. But, the fact that there are *still* more SUVs on the road than hybrids is a blatant indication that people don't really care about gas prices.

So don't complain about gas prices, just blame yourself.

It's all your fault.

Go hug a tree or something.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My highlight of the day would have to be opening my mailbox and finding an invitation to be part of the "Junior American Miss" pageant this year.

But, the only problem is that I am not female.

I suppose my dreams will have to be dashed once more.

Today was one of those days where one can get lots of hard things done, but still feel not-so-fantastic afterward.

So what if I lost a game of chess to some half-wit racist in my World History class? It's not that big of a deal.

But that wasn't it. It's never the chronologically closest thing that gets you in the end.

I walked to the cafeteria with the chess kid on my back, boasting on and on (in a totally non-serious manner) about how he beat me at chess. And at the time, I really didn't care, or hoped that I wouldn't start caring, but as I walked into the cafeteria, and with the 36th derrogatory remark on my back, everything started to get heavy, emotionally.

Some people say that emotions are for the weak, the immature. I say things things as well. But, I guess these things happen.

Sitting at my lunch table, I find Andrew with his signature smirk, pointing at me. And the weight comes down. Before, the insults were from a subordinate, and underling that I could justifiably ignore. To find such a respected peer gesturing so obviously to me, it was too much for me. All of the text below, that nonsense that isn't even supposed to exist, came crashing down.

It is and was a horrible circle. Andrew just pulled the trigger. He started talking, loudly, about how I failed to defeat one of my peers in a silly board game. It sounds so stupid, and I even thought this at the time, but he just pulled the fucking trigger, and so I succumbed.

So I'm sitting at the table all teary-eyed, shaking, hazy-minded with all of the natural chemicals being circulated through my bloodstream, unable to look at any of my peers because I didn't wan't to reveal how weak I was/am. I distinctly remember not being able to feel my face. I also remember trying to get myself to stop behaving like this. After all, it was all so vain. Why should I even care? Acting like this showed that I cared about myself, and that demonstrated how selfish and vain I am. And so I hated myself for being in this sad state. This hate perpetuates more pressure and anxiety. It continues.

And for a few arduously long minutes the nonsense continues. At this point, I'm really confused, unable to breathe normally, eyes red with salty liquid and expanded blood vessels. I begin to think about how Andrew must feel. So then along with my contempt for myself, guilt started to sink in about how I made Andrew feel bad.

A light blue shirt comes into view. Rus sits down and he somehow gets me to start to chat about some cell phone conundrum involving my defective phone and my mother somehow calling Rus by accident.

As time passes, and as I get more involved with my conversation with Rus, I start to feel better. After about fifteen minutes, Rus has me back on my feet and able to stop being such a self-centered attention-whore.

I find it intriguing that this kid, a kid that I found very rude and obnoxious last year, helped me this year, while a kid that I've found very pleasant to be around instigated my inner conflicts. A flip of roles, I suppose.

Fast forward 30 minutes.

I'm fantastic, I talk to Andrew and resolve my conflicts. Everything is dealt with in a cookie-cutter fashion. We exchange a few words and disband.

But through it all, I have no negative feelings about anyone, just extra positive feelings for some.

*Note: My choice to use real first names is completely random.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Aw, Ryo Chiba, don't be so sad. And don't let Andrew's sarcastic, sometimes-mean self get you down. Besides, unless you're Rachel, I'm sure he didn't mean anything by it. Only Andrew being Andrew. And you're pretty much the coolest kid ever. Also, you don't know it yet, but we're gong to get married someday. =P Cheer up, kid.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: I don't want to be murdered so anonymous
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Wow married?? jk Hey it isn't every day that you get invited to join the Junior American Miss pageant. I think you should "like, totally"join. It is a once in a lifetime opportunity.;) And I want to see you in the bathing suit part... don't forget WORLD PEACE!

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: *Note: I will be off the grid for a week.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I still feel like musty car fabric and old cheese puffs.

The twelve hour drive from "down there" (Alabama) to "up here" (Indiana) has tired me. Thus, I will soon skitter to bed and doze off.

In other news, I have found that several people have been commenting, and I like it when people do it! Although sometimes I consider this site and the text associated with it to be very private, I enjoy getting feedback (mostly encouragement to keep myself from jumping off a cliff after writing some of my "sob-story feel sorry for me" posts).

I hate cheese puffs. I don't know why I ate them while traveling in the car. They make one's mouth dry and numb with overly salty, artificial "cheese" powder. But, one look at the cheetah touting the "xtremely cheesyness" of the stuff gets me hooked.

What can I say, I'm easily swayed by packaging.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I tried to accomplish lots of things today, but sometimes one cannot help but feel like something that was supposed to happen didn't.

On a side note, while traveling to Alabama, I went to this Chinese restaurant. I'm the only one in my family that can actually tolerate those "fortune cookie" things, so this time, like every time, I was stuck with four fortune cookies.

You know, it's always nice to have four fortunes. If one of them is a bad/unappealing fortune, then you can just forget about it and open the next cookie.

Sometimes, they're not even fortunes. The first fortune that was handed to me by the mystical "fortune cookie" higher beings was, "It's Nice to be Important, but It's More Important to be Nice". That is definitely not a fortune, but I still found it very witty. Now it's in my memory so when the time comes, I'll be able to bust it out and impress my peers with my simulated wittyness.

I forget the second and third fortunes (they're never the important ones), but the fourth and final fortune still sticks out in my mind.

The paper slip inside of the delicate treat said, "You will be given an amazing offer today. Accept it!"

The fact that it said "today" meant that it was a one-time event. But, that day, there were no "amazing offers" that I could accept. When I went to bed that night, I felt dark disappointment. Although the fortunes are destined to never come true, and are there for pure novelty, there was still a sad sort of cloud that came about after realizing that these mystical, oriental fortune-telling cookies lie.

But, back on topic, no matter what I do, there is never enough satisfaction. Today, I completed a few Blender tutorials, drew, and updated my DeviantArt nonsense. I'm a "get stuff done" kind of person, and if I don't "get stuff done", then I feel like a festering sore on the skin of time. Even on supposed "breaks" like these, the stress seems to build up. There's stress from the impending doom/return to school, and additional stress from me trying to figure out what do accomplish over the free time I am given.

But, at least I have a plan for tomorrow.

While browsing through good 'ol digg.com, I found Instiki. This concept of a locally stored, globally accessed, personal wiki facinates me.

Thus, it is now my dutiful mission to get my own wiki up and running, for the sake of, well... getting my own wiki up and running.

Hopefully, tomorrow will bring good fortune in my wiki-creation endeavors, although now I know that there will be no "amazing offers" to accept.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: The last fortune I got said "YOU'LL GET A RIDE FROM THE COSMIC WIZARD". Never did get it though. That was, ohhh... 10 years ago. I've given up on fortune cookies. From now on it's lottery.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Today was another day of failure.

After pestering Alex with questions on Gtalk for about three hours, I realized that it was hopeless, at least for today, to get my wiki to be accessed from the Internet. This morning, I had hope, as I configured Instiki to work, and for a time I was satisfied with what it could do. To my surprise, things worked. Computers on my network could access and edit the content. But, unfortunately, after rigorous testing, I figured out that it was not accessible from outside the network, which was a real bummer.

So, like I mentioned above, Alex came to the rescue, but in the end, the wiki is still unavailable from the web.

The URL is: http://192.168.0.102:2500/ , just for future reference, and so I can access it from my laptop upstairs. You won't be able to get to it.

But, I did put lots of information in the wiki. Even if it isn't available from any computer in the world that's connected to the Internet, it's just as useful when it's only available on my network. Hopefully, the computer I'm hosting it on won't go kaboom, and will stay alive, just long enough so I can get tons of information in it, and back it up.

Because of my lack of things to do, I also added 4 more pieces of "art" to my DeviantArt gallery, if you would like to check it out. *Note: The link as on the sidebar in the links menu. Hint, hint: "My Anthro Art".

But, alas (I haven't said "alas" in a long while), a time for sleep is fast approaching, and I will have to bow down to the great powers of mortal limitations.

In other words, I'm going to bed.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: IP addresses that start with 192.168 are always local and never passed by Internet routers, so to make it Internet-accessible it needs different IP address. When the host computer is logged onto the Internet, it will gain a second IP address, and be accessible to all through that address.

I understand this. The IP I stated above was posted for the sole purpose of me getting to the wiki from another networked computer. I was not intending to post an Internet accessible link. Thanks for the comment though.
Sorry, I guess I misinterpreted your reason for posting it. You did write "just for future reference" which I now realize would help you or other people on the local network find it.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Currently, I'm at a friend's house.

Thus, I am tired.

Because of this, I will not type further.

It should be noted that my network wiki is going very well.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I was looking at my watch this afternoon to check what day it was. Today was cloudy, and I sat in my dark corner of the house. So, by the light of the computer, I squinted to make out the numbers on my watch, and what a surprise it was to realize that tonight is going to be the night most societies are going to transition into the new year. But, if one looks a bit deeper into "new years" and such, one can see these worldwide celebrations are for a very trivial, shallow reason. Time has been quantified by humans, in increments and units based both on mathematics and other people.

Think about it, there are quite a few people who aren't even on the "standard" Gregorian calendar system. What is the signifigance of this "new year" to them?

To them, it means nada, zip, zilch. I know, it's cliche, but work with me here.

And to think, if we got all the money wasted on baked goods, alcohol, pyrotechnics, confetti, and replacement lampshades for new years celebrations and used it on aid and sustenance packages for the needy, world hunger would probably end for a day or two. But, who wants to give up a party in exchange for a life? Apparently, not many people.

So I'd like to shy away from all the sappy "New Years" bullshit that usually consists of "I *heart* everyone for this fantastic new years and new years resolutions and crap... blah, blah, blah." Personally, I'm sick of holidays. I'm sick of trying to control my envy, hearing about how much everyone got for Christmas, and attempting to convince myself that I don't care about how much everyone else got. I'm sick of certain Apple products being shoved in my face while waiting in line in a grocery store by some visibly broke, odorous, single-parent, mother who can't afford to buy a carseat and doesn't have enough intelligence to install it even if she could afford the sticker price.

An amazing thing happened to me tonight. I turned on the television and watched it for more than 15 minutes. Even if I was watching an old History Channel re-run on cocaine, the fact that I did something so unproductive is still disgraceful. Perhaps I will whip myself for that.

The household computers, or one of them, didn't like me today. More specifically, the external card-reader doesn't want to make friends with the computer's drivers. I plug the card reader in, and everything's fine, until I put my SD card in, upon which the two imbecile inanimate objects decide (even if they can't really "decide", persay) to fritz and lock up. After the reboot, McAfee decides to randomly uber-scan my hard drive, just to piss me off. Many reboots and curses later, the desktop actually responds, and I get my anti-virus (I do not consider McAfee anti-virus software anymore) assault team going.

So I suppose my new years celebration is going to consist of cleaning the computers out of muck. Fantastic. Fun, fun, fun. I'm just rolling in fun, aren't I?

Happy New Years, you Gregorian conformist bastards.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Hey, Windows Live Mail is exposed! I got in, and as of now, 10:40PM it still is able to be accessed by any person with a previous hotmail account. The instructions can be found here:

http://computerhelpforum.org/somefool/get_windows_live_mail_for_free_-_no_invite_needed.php

What a great way to kick off the new year!

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Halfway through my shower, I forgot if I washed my hair already or not. For good measure, I did again. But, forevermore, I will not know if I washed my hair once or washed my hair twice.

What if my whole life was like that? What if I forgot something every ten minutes?

And somehow, after having this conversation with myself in the shower, I find myself thinking about the true value of reading literature. After all, it's just like watching television. Reading a captivating story about a bunch of British schoolboys crash-landing on an island is no different than watching a television show about a bunch of British schoolboys crash-landing on an island.

Sure, one can say that the television version doesn't hold all of the innate details that are needed to truely "absorb" the whole story and "read between the lines". Well, how is "reading between the lines" or "absorbing" a story going to affect one's life? If you're a normal, statistically average human being, the allegorical references mentioned in so-and-so book aren't going to make a difference. All that can be learned from a story can be learned just as well, and faster, from a list of facts and rules. The school corporation might as well make a gigantic book of facts as the standard, and only textbook used in schools. I'm sure it would save a lot of paper, as well as increase efficiency. If this was to take place, there would be no more reading of pointless chronicles of fictional characters in an ethereal world.

And wouldn't that just make my day.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Have you seen 50 First Dates? You need to.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I look at the watch and it's 8:30pm. So I dwaddle around on the computer for what seems like fifteen more minutes. I look down at my watch again. It's 11pm.

As school approaches, it seems time, life, everything is speeding up. The tasks of future school workload, as well as the extracurricular workload, stare back at me from the farthest reaches of my mind.

One may wonder why these thoughts are in the farthest reaches. Well, the sad truth is that I don't like school, or the work associated with it. Might as well run away and see how far I could make it. I mean, sometimes, I look out the window, wherever I am, and think of just abandoning everything I have and roughing it out in the wilderness. Or if you play runescape (you batty twits!), the wildy.

Yes, it's irrational. But the thought keeps creeping up. And I've read stories about people who do just what I'm thinking of, so I know I'm not alone. What's life if there aren't any surprises? Why not just abandon the future and run for what exists right then and now? I can't make any definitive statements anymore. This whole "discovering who I am" thing is really tough. Finding out "who to be" in the future is just as hard. Career choices as well as lifestyle choices.

They tell you to ask yourself, "What do you enjoy doing?"

But to me, it sounds like, "Calculate the profit vs. enjoyment ratio of every career field in existance and compute the job that offers the highest possibly probability of success."

This choice involves my life, and lots of people have set paths that they follow. I have a path, but I don't know where it points.

The clock ticks, and with a loud buzz, my radio starts conking out again. This promptly ends the above discussion with myself. As I turn the knob to adjust frequencies, I ask myself the real question I've been meaning to ask myself this whole time,

"Why am I here?"

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My facination with adhesive substances has not ceased.

And I'm not talking about sniffing glue.

My walls, they are covered in tape, if only to hold up all the paper I have attached to the wall. The corners and edges of my desk are continuously assaulted by sticky notes, and I have six rolls of dollar store tape staring me right in the face. My desk drawers contain countless other rolls of double sided, photography, super-stick, duct, scotch, and colored tape. In my room, there is no where you can turn and not find tape somewhere or another. I use tape to keep things in place, I use tape to attach individual objects together, I use tape to organize, and I use tape to decorate. I'm living in a tape world, and I'm sure that it's a fire hazard by now.

I wouldn't be surprised if my obsession with electronics, tape, and paper killed me. Quite simply, it would be easy for a spark from my *many* outlets (thank you, power strips) to come in contact with tape, or paper. Upon which the room would burst into flames and kill me in my sleep, or while typing up a post. If I look down at my feet, I see a power strip resting on top of a bunch of crumpled paper. What a wonderful place for a fire to start. My good friend OSHA would definitely not be proud.

In other news, school is getting closer. But, I don't really care anymore since I got to go to the local store and went on a shopping spree.

Mind you, I bought a notebook and a pair of sunglasses.

Due to my utter imbecility, I now have a 1.2 minute recording of me dancing around my room in sunglasses.

Wow, I really did put those sunglasses to use, didn't I?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Hundreds of thousands of millions of years from now, long after humans have died out and the Sun has engulfed the Earth in searing flames, there will be our message in a bottle out there in the universe, floating out in the nothingness that we now know as "space". Voyager I and Voyager II, NASA's distant and old probes (1977), contain a number of things that, if decoded, could reveal much about our civilization. Images, sound data, and text data that could be our only itty bitty spec of evidence that humans really did exist, that there was intelligent life on a planet called "Earth.

It makes me feel small. I'm one person, in a big state of people, out of fifty states, out of 192 countries, on a planet, in a system of nine, in a galaxy of millions of systems, in a universe of... who knows. I find it very humbling.

A side note to all of the self-discovering nonsense above, you can check out the images stored in the Voyager probes right here: http://re-lab.net/welcome/

On the subject of humans and their place in the universe, I resent the fact that Titan A.E. was a flop of an animation. I really liked the concept, however absurd, and the actual movie itself was enjoyable too. But, I watched it when I was around ten years old, so who knows what my crazy mind was thinking then.

But, on a more localized note, school is starting tomorrow, so I can't go without mentioning that.

I spent the day helping SecondLife newbies at my daily camping spot, the welcome area chess table, and giving out self-made "care packages" with lots of freebies and links to need-to-go areas.

Not like you care, since not anyone I know is an active Second Life resident. I just wanted to gloat because gloating is a source of short-term satisfaction, which is what I need before I start believing that school is indeed going to begin tomorrow.

Links, links, and more links. I found SSS via digg.org. http://mirror.softwarefor.org/index.html

SSS stands for "Software for Starved Students", but you can know it by "Software that you should install because you shouldn't depend on closed-source software for long because standards will change and you will be screwed". I'm thinking of burning a few .iso's onto a bunch of CD's and just handing them out to the computer un-savy and needy. And there's a UI on the CD for technologically illiterate people, so I'll be able to hand it out to stupid people as well. How exciting.

Not to mention they bundle Blender on the SSS CD. Isn't the world wonderful?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I tell myself it's a matter of time.

A matter of time before I instantly "become" invulnerable to the palpitations and anxiety associated with public speaking. For quite some time, I've told myself that I'm fearless, that there is nothing in speaking that could in any way damage my "already-in-shambles" reputation.

The fact is, I have speech this semester.

I see the class as an opportunity, almost like a toy for me to play around with. Toying around with ideas and throwing them to the public is fun, especially when you get the spotlight and people actually decide to listen. For the longest time, I had given up on being more pervasive. All conversations I attempt to follow in a passive manner. I have trouble, hesitation in challenging authority around me.

Since sometime in middle school, I found out that most people are unintelligent, and most people won't listen. So, I figured that letting them live in their own little "stupid world" wouldn't be all that bad. I mean, in a fad-following, musically illiterate, bland world of iPod dominance, there isn't much room for individuality. So what's the point of speaking up and telling everyone about how something that doesn't correlate to their beliefs?

No one likes to hear what they don't want to hear. If I tell "Joe Schmo iPod Owner" that iPod's suck, then he won't listen. He doesn't want to admit, or even think about the possibility that he bought an over priced shitbox. So, why even speak up? My plan was to just sit on the sidelines, and maybe if I can't beat 'em, then someday I may be able to join 'em, and in the process cash out on one of these fads.

But, speech class opens a new window. It's a beautiful thing, freedom. You wouldn't find a class like this in China.

One could say that I experienced two extremes today. There's freedom in speech, and confinement in French. In this class, there was a lengthy discussion on digital portable music players, and the teacher was completely oblivious to the inner workings of electronics and such. Because of this fact, there was much discussion and attempts for the students ,who didn't really understand either, to explain to the teacher the inner workings of a portable music player.

As the drama intensified, people started prattling out adver-tistics of the iPod like, "It holds 1000 songs!" and "literally smaller than a matchbox!". Hearing such things so blatantly made me cringe. As the discussion got livelier and livelier, and more heated, my cringe turned into a slight twitch for a trigger that wasn't there.

And then at the climax of the whole scenario, my teacher silences the class and asks for an accurate explaination, as the concept of electronics is such a foreign concept to her, and the class stares back up at the teacher.

I twitch. I want to raise my hand.

I attempt to raise my hand, but stop myself. The action was based on my belief that droning on and on about the schematics of basic electronics parts in a portable music player would make me seem pushy. Soon after my attempt, someone who sits besides me and raises his hand. He explains it very simply, and I feel the urge to add details and complicate things. I quell my urges as I convince myself that my peers' simple explainations will fare better with the primitive mind of my pre-computer French teacher.

And so French class ends and I try to relax. All the self-induced drama is driving me up the wall. Or across the wall, or below it. Perhaps I'll just jump off the wall into the sidewalk.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I try to get to sleep on time, I really do.

But, you know what? Homework, projects, the whole bit. They are greatly taking up my time. I find it frustrating to not be able to go to sleep because I'm obsessively trying to fake my way through a bibliography for some idiotic english project. I absolutely detest having to sleuth around to find the date for some obscure web page so I can put it on my "works cited" or "bibliography" page.

The whole process of compiling the reference data is kind of like searching for lost gold, except when you finally get to the gold, you realize it's just a worthless rock.

So tomorrow I plan to go to some Robotics Team Kickoff-type event with lots of other people attending. I don't expect to have a pleasurable experience, especially because I really don't like some of the people on our, and other robotics teams. It's a matter of personal conflicts. It's just that sometimes, the conversations my teammates have are so off putting. The intelligence level of some of these conversations is very low.

However, there are a few people that are capable of a nice, refined conversation with a little bit of wit, just like I like it. Unfortunately, these people are usually older than me, and thus less "accessible" to me.

In other news, I tried doing my speech today in front of the mirror in my bathroom, albiet in the nude. Oddly enough, I seemed to know my speech by heart, or most of it at least. I suppose it's a matter of reading the darned thing over and over until it seems like a conversation.

But, the problem I have with blurting out memorized garbage is that I often sound very "fake". Like a robot with a wildly oscillating pitch of voice and over-exaggerated facial expressions. I don't know, I try to emphasize myself too much to cover up the fact that I'm not actually "talking" to you persay, but just spitting out memorized garbage. I've had this problem ever since I participated in my middle school speech team, in the "radio" event. Because this event involves replicating the antics of a radio show host, I came to sound like a radio host whenever I try to speak "professionally".

I have to face it eventually. I'm doomed to sound like a bothersome radio broadcaster for the rest of my life.

I might as well make the best of it.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Just because someone is older than you doesn't mean that they are less "accessible". I think it depends on what you mean by that and what you think...

It could be worse than looking like a robot in front of the class. ("hey Mr. Robot Mr. no no" lala and the rest of the words to the song) That is kind of fun... People look at me, a nervous wreak. The people then have SYMPATHY for me. I hate that! In a sense it is their fault that I am such a mess. That and being home school where there is no pressure or even peers that you present to. Somehow presenting to yourself in the nude is much more fun because you can stand there and laugh at yourself and wonder where your shirt disappeared off to and hope that the cats didn't fall asleep on the warm shirt.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Over time, I have discovered that things feel better if one works hard.

For one example, I got sick of Blender during the very stagnant, non-working days of winter vacation. Now that I've got projects, speeches, homework, and tests to worry about, the Blender bug has hit me again. Oh my love of rendering comes back to me from the dead. Although I use the tutorials much less now, the book I got for christmas was indeed a good buy. Keyboard shortcuts are a page away, and I've got reference sheets for almost every concept and feature for the program.

Today, after hours of modelling, I have created a room with a chair, a desk, a radio, a computer, and a bookshelf. Although it is very primitive when compared to other blenderite creations, it is evident that my skills are advancing. This further excites me to model more.

According to my new discovery, the following two months are going to feel euphoric. Build season begins this Monday. This means that from Monday on, I'll be at school more than I will be at home. Returning home at 9pm each day and going to school at 6:30am the next morning will mean that I will be at school for 4 more hours each day than I will be at home. I don't know what to expect at this point. For the most part, I've heard that this hardcore work is very exhausting, but worth it. I've decided to trust my sources for now. Hopefully, they're telling the truth.

Unsure about my future workload problems, I've tried to get myself to do all of my vocabulary. Unfortunately, it just isn't getting done due to the rebirth of my obsession with Blender. So, tomorrow morning I will attempt to do more tedious vocabulary.

*Note to self: Condemn vocabulary books in future new world order.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I better churn this out quick or else I'll miss my sleep deadline. Without adequate nocturnal preparation for school, and school-related activities, the world around me will be come a big mess of swirling colors and derailed hopes of high marks.

This afternoon, I realized that one of my rolls of double sided tape is larger than the other. I've had the two rolls of coveted double-sided for the past year or so, and since then I've never noticed the size difference. They have just been innocently sitting on my desk, but all this time they must have planned for this to happen. My rolls of tape must have planned that I would eventually notice their size difference.

This may not be a significant discovery for you, but for me I saw this enlightenment as a lesson. A lesson that details amount to nothing, as long as the job gets done. My rolls of tape do their job, and they've done their job even though I haven't taken note of details.

For this reason, I disagree with my English teacher. Her motto has something to do about little details, as she is maniacally obsessed with details. Half a centimeter off on the margin spacing? Header on the wrong side? Underlining instead of italicizing? Those would all be significant point deductions.

I see no point to this madness. If one was to write a paper, it's content is what matters, not if the protocols were precisely followed. This is not the USSR. This is a country that rewards flexibility and the ability to get the job done, to improvise. Conformity is devalued in a society so diverse. So why should English papers be the same way? If anything, not following proper protocols would just result in a longer grading time, and I suppose she has justification in punishing students for that. But, making or breaking grade based on the "proper" location of a parenthetical citation? I see that as absurd.

But I have nothing to worry about. As long as I stay as maniacally obsessed with the "important" details in my paper as she is maniacally obsessed with counting off points for the details, I'll be safe.

Forever, I must remember that life rewards the vigilant.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
How marvelous is my life?

I should get used to staying up late. It's inevitable that I'll just stop sleeping completely. For now though, it'll just be staying up "late".

The first official build-season Robotics meeting was today. And the funny thing about it was that...

Well, actually, nothing was funny about the meeting itself, but rather, the people in it.

One person in particular.

I've always liked to psychologically pick on Russel in my mind. I find him a facinating creature, like an extinct animal that somehow has come to life again. His social cues, so correctly timed sometimes, but the mood he casts is so negative. He lets his tone of voice speak to one as if his words really didn't matter. He could say something nice, and injure one's feelings deeply from his rash tone.

I don't understand this mystical being that I know as Rus. I really can't comprehend how sophisticated his mind must be. He is so closed-minded, but he can cheer you up on a bad day. He is so inherently annoying, but his psyche is magnetic. I don't... can't seem to describe him.

This afternoon, I was talking about how I was going to stay after school and sit in the cafeteria for a few hours to wait for robotics to start. He mentioned to me that it was against the rules. And even though his comment was so quip and so insignificant, it had this draw to it... His voice had utter seriousness embedded into it that somehow his message that in reality said "Isn't that against school rules?" turned into, "Do not stay inside after school. That is an order. Do not disobey my order."

And it bothered me throughout the day. It bothered me so much that I sat outside in the cold for those hours, on the icy concrete that lines the building. I sat there obeying him, and it puzzled me greatly.

I asked myself, "Why am I listening to a message that was never given to me?"

The fact of the matter was, the message was indeed given to me. But, I believe that I gave it to myself through Rus. Or, he has some sort of vocal quality that is able to transmit information to me, that coincided with his body language of inner hostility led me to believe that I think now is something on the fringe of paranormal.

Sometimes Rus can't get it into his head that he is wrong, but his headstrong, closed-minded personality adds a mystique to his nature. What is under his skin that makes him like that? What kind of environmental factors has influenced such behavior in this "typical" American teen? Who is he?

The mysterious Rus will continue to evade me until I discover his core. The core that I so love to hate, but cannot because of his innate ability to help me feel like what I'm supposed to feel like.

A human being.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
It seems the days are getting longer, most likely because they are.

This also has to do with the fact that there are so many things to do that life seems to drag on. Lots of things to do mean lots of things to dredge through, such as multitudes of tedious vocabulary questions and chemistry worksheets. That combined with the Robotics build-season, it's a big lump that lengthens my day considerably. For me, this is good.

I value my time. After all, we're all given a certain amount of it when we come into existance. Each second that passes as you read this sentence, this amount of time gets smaller and smaller.

The window is shrinking, very slowly.

But, if it's shrinking, why not pretend to lengthen it? I can delve into my own little world of slowed down time and pretend, as I flip through the pages of my recently-assigned, rather lengthy Charles Dickens novel, that time is passing at a slower rate than it actually is. After all, reading Charles Dickens often makes one feel dreary and lethargic.

I want to vomit on my book.

Books, books, books. What is it with all of this literature nonsense? What is there to bilk from these unbearably wordy texts? If there's one statement I can make without any sense of remorse or guilt, it is this:

I hate literature.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I am absolutely estatic about getting my hands on 3ds Max sometime this month (hopefully this Friday, maybe). I have no clue on what it's UI is like, what the tools available are, if it has intensive hotkey usage, or if it has different terms for the same things used in Blender.

I'm assuming that Blender is really easy compared to 3ds, but perhaps I'll be pleasantly surprised (never the case). If anything, playing around with it for a few hours will teach me how to use this tool.

Not that I'm getting any stupider or anything, but my typing abilities and conceptual thinking abilities, which make up the bulk of the abilities I need to write beefy posts, is drained. Due to a few hours less sleep every day, I can't think as clearly. My mind is clouded.

It is worth noting that I am ashamed of myself for not doing my speech today. I hate it when I plan for things to happen, and they don't. The fact that the peers in my speech class actually volunteer to go is creating problems in my plans. Because they raise their hands, I hesitate to raise my hand.

Why?

The reason I tell myself is that I don't want to take the opportunity of speaking from someone else in my class.

The real reason is that because I was stunned by that fact that I had to compete with other people to do something unpleasant. I guess I'm not as "valiant" a martyr when people are volunteering to go to the gallows, so to speak.

I would like to reiterate that my mind is clouded.

Because it is.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
For the sake of me not going insane due to lack of sleep, I am going to post my speech. I know it's dishonorable to put up content on here that really isn't meant for such a personal medium, but I can hardly think of my French, nonetheless what to type up. Blah.

My speech:
--------------------

Here begins the timeline of my life, Ryo Chiba. April 22, 1990 years after the birth of Christ. Date of death? Now, there's a question for you. Yes, one can surmise from the information given in the previous statement that my name is indeed Ryo Chiba, and that I am actually 15 years old today. But, is there anything more interesting to this faceless account of my sad, short existence? Well, for one thing, there is my computer.

From my activities at home, to a number of details that could be recorded as I traverse the world, one could even say that I detest human contact. Of course, this is not true. I just happen to prefer my sterile office chair in my tidy white room over “hanging out” as many call it. The origins of how I interpret “fun” and “comfort” are really just so obscure and unknown to recall. Thus, my interests mainly focus around activities that are meant for solitude. My natural habitat is in a chair in front of a computer. Now, hear me out. I am not a lazy person. Although appearances say otherwise, I find inactivity in any way utterly disgusting. I don't think I've turned on the television in my house in a few months. I find no consolation in sitting around and doing nothing. Talking with me usually is useless because the conversation ends up being meaningless banter. Because I find inaction revolting, I find things to work on, such as homework and school-affiliated projects. I spend quite a bit of time mulling over various unfinished bits of paper that I sometimes pull from my binder. I spend such a considerable amount of time on homework that one could even call it a hobby of mine. I suppose that it's how I try to justify my obsession with work. I believe this says a lot about my character.

Everyone seems to want a funny story about me, but the truth is, I am a funny story. From my birth in Japan, to my childhood in Alabama, to this very introduction speech I am giving to you today in Indiana, my life has been scattered, to say the least. In addition to Alabama, I have traveled to countless cities in countless states. In geographic location of life, I have developed my own personality. If one was to judge “who” I was five years ago, it would be totally different than “who” I am now. I don't even know who I truly am. Thusly, I find it extremely important to record information that I deem significant, whether it be about myself, other people, or random ideas. I see analog methods of this dirty and physically tiring. Digital methods are tiring as well, but it's the only viable option available. In other words, I like to type. Ever since Monday, June 23, 2003, I have spent thirty minutes of mostly every day typing the information mentioned previously. To date, I have 860+ entries, numbering 500 pages of 10-point font, resting on a nice back-up floppy that I keep in my room. Amazingly, these thirty minutes a day have impacted my life greatly. In this time, I have improved my poor writing skills, increased my previously deficient vocabulary, and gained a certain amount of technical expertise. Although the previous statements sounded like a pitch by a drug representative, I have my defects. I still have trouble with simple math, due to my calculator dependency, and sometimes I can't annunciate words.

By peering into this large compilation of words, one could pry open my inner psyche, which I assume this is all about. The word, “me” crops up 134 times while the word “you” crops up 129 times. “Life” crops up 77 times while “death” and “suicide” crop up 20 times. From this pseudo-statistical analysis, one could speculate that I care about myself more than other people, and that I concentrate on life more than death. The true actuality of these statements is unknown, but it gives you an idea of who “I” seem to be.

Although this irksome summary of myself may not have left you in the proper mood, I hope that the speech was effective enough for some of you in the audience to begin to understand who I am. As for my date of death, that is information that I hope to never know.


Ta da.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Looks like you could use a comment on this thing. So here one is.

Uh, here's another one!

And if it's not too late, the better word is "enunciate," rather than "annuciate."

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
If I don't post this soon, it'll be tomorrow already. Midnight is fast approaching, like a deft leaf slicing through the crisp, winter air. Surprisingly, the temperature in my room is very mild. This makes me happy. I like it when I get the atmosphere just right. Dim yellow lights, recently disinfected citrus odor, light jazz, a glowing laptop screen. The whole feeling in my room is just so positive. This is surprising as well, because I do a number of negative things in my room, such as gripe about homework.

I guess sometimes good vibes come from the oddest of spots.

Occasionally, I talk to people at school. Every once in awhile, the person I converse with will catch me at the wrong time, and I'll sometimes be impolite or be ruffled. Afterwards, I usually think about what happened, and how I'm such a decrepit fool for being in such a low morale.

This contemplation makes me hate myself even more.

After all, what's the point of thinking of the past if it has already happened? Well, for one thing, one can learn from the mistakes of the past.

But, what frustrates me is that I never learn. There is always *something* that will put me in a bad mood, and then I start to be insensitive and angry. Usually it'll be something stupid, like a mistake on a math problem, or the fact that I'm never going to catch up to some of my peers in a reading assignment. So, each time something like this happens, it's the whole messed-up cycle of self-contempt and general lethargy.

I can't lie, school is draining me.

I cannot escape it.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
It's going to be tough for the next few days, being able to type out garbage every night as my mind dwindles between the realm of insanity and critical failure. The outlook is dreary. I imagine a world where I don't get to sleep until midnight, and have to wake up at 5am. It's a matter of what needs to be done. What needs to be done must be done, and if that is to happen, then I must suffer.

Thusly, posting must be done. And if I have to go nuts doing it, then so be it.

In other news, there's a nice large hard drive heading toward my house. Lovely. I love storage. I do lots of things on the computer, and it eats up space. On the "to-do list" for tomorrow is to go through and flush out the computer. Otherwise, I'll have a meltdown on my hands, or rather a large growl and beep from the innards of my desktop before it mysteriously reboots itself.

Bah, it's so hard to type when you can't think and nothing has happened.

So this will conclude the record of my Saturday, the 14th of January, 2006.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
After spending way too much time on modeling, my SMART Car is almost done. Currently, it is being rendered out on the computer downstairs. The processor is chugging along at around 100%, and the image is still going to take about half an hour. I'm assuming it's because all the meshes that I use in the model are all subsurfed by a factor of three. In other words, each polygonal face in each shape is made twice as complicated each time I "subsurf", or subsurface the shape. Thus, my whole scene contains an extravagantly large number of actual vertices. That coupled with the fact that lots of the materials I use are reflective makes my rendering times very long.

I'm very inefficient with such things. My next step should be managing the resources I have, to cut corners where I can.

But, enough about my futile blendering.

I was flipping through this month's issue of PC World magazine, and found a little blurb that read, "Human vs. Machine".

Being drawn in by the title I read the blub. The mini-article of sorts spoke of a website called www.mturk.com where one could make money by doing commissioned work that only a human could do. For example, the website asks you to put in numbers that can be found in blury images. It's a bit like doing a "capcha". They pay a cent for every capcha you do. I've done around 250. If all of them are right, I'll get paid two dollars and fifty cents. I'm not sure if it's worth the time, but then again, I've never earned a cent in my life.

Thinking about the week that is about to start, I'm a bit overwhelmed. Last week was just a warm up, a testing run to see if I could survive my new schedule plus Robotics. This coming week is going to push the bar even higher. Having the bar raised usually means going through grueling nights of tearing my hair out while trying to understand a seemingly nonsensical chemistry textbook in the depths of my room. Sometimes it's not even chemistry. At any given moment, I could be frustrated on French, English, writing another pathetic speech, or even math. Chemistry just seems to be the issue most of the time because of the sheer workload of the class.

This can be both a good and a bad thing. Because there is so much work, it is easy to bolster a grade with easy points. This contrasts with French class, which has no workload whatsoever.
