Having these things in front of my eyes was more than enough to make me want to open them more.

Stars sparkle at night, and I'm riding in the bed of a truck of a friend's car as we come home from regionals. I look up at the stars and contemplate such things. Tired from the rush of action, drab from the struggles and conflicts of a robotics team, desensitized to noise. I look up at the pinprick dots of light scattered around the sky, and wonder.

"Is it all real, did I really meet all those people and cheer for all those teams?"

And staring into the woods that engulf us, I manage to wring out a smile out of my tired face.

Satisfaction that can only come from robotics. Character that can only come from hardships. I realize that Mr. Kamen made something out of nothing, impacted my life without even knowing me, and because of that have a relationship that doesn't even exist.

And as the road unwinds beneath my feet, the orange streetlight flickers past me, and the world begins to feel rather small, in a good way.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: "A stranger is a friend you just haven't met yet." -An old Irish saying

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Muddly. If that was a word, it would describe today.

I was very angry today. A quiet, brooding anger. An emotion that has no right to be there, no purpose. After all, I really have no reason to be angry at anything. I should be excruciatingly happy from winning at Robotics.

I'm presuming that the anger is from all the pent up anger from the past few months. Every lunch period, I'm fuming angry from having to sit next to two mentally retarded children in the class before. I still haven't accepted the fact that I am going to be screamed at for no reason intermittently during that class. It's a very difficult thing to accept. Especially when I reserve that class period for sleeping.

The anger also stems from the fact that I'm being pushed around by people for expressing my thoughts on things. In social situations in which the conflict involves me, I often get self-conscious, depressed, and sad rather than angry and enraged. I'm sick of myself hating myself for being involved in such things. I've got to just accept the things that happen to me and the circumstances that surround these events. If someone hates me, if I can't control myself and say what I have to say, but apologize, if people are better than me, more talented, more sophisticated, more athletic, smarter, richer, then I've got to accept it. It's destiny. If I fail, then I do, and it's no use complaining, or trying to make myself feel better by telling other people about it. It's no use because it accomplishes nothing. Things remain where they are. All it results in is wasted time ad energy, as well as an over-inflated ego.

But, I know there is a high chance that I'll revert back to my primal urges to gather pity when the situation calls for it. This is rather unfortunate.

I hate myself, but hate myself for hating myself, and because of this, hate myself for hating myself for hating myself. Repeat this step for 24 hours and you've got my average day. Fun.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes I wonder about how I want to live my life.

I was entertaining becoming a volunteer for MSF, also known as Doctors Without Borders. Entertaining the idea of going out of my comfort zone to help dying people in dangerous areas rampant with war, disease, and crime. Entertaining the idea of sacrificing the very comforts that I enjoy and hold dear every day. To become someone for the sake of becoming someone.

Plus, I hear that they're constantly needing French-speaking volunteers. Just another incentive to try to learn French. (Which is becoming increasingly difficult)

But, of course, as all ideas come to a screeching halt, I ask myself, "Should I keep this in my head?" Because, if I keep things locked into my head, then I begin to work towards these things. Whether I do it subconsciously, or consciously, I slowly begin to drift towards the message that I lock into my head.

So, due to my facination with such things, I'm reading an account of an MSF volunteer.
Great, now I'm not going to get it out of my head.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
With the assistance of a certain website, I have been able to finish all of the vocabulary assignments for the year. Exciting stuff, I have to admit, copying down word after words after word on a sheet of paper. Simple "busy work" that is there for the sole purpose of degrading children. I'm glad there are resources online that combat this scholastic fiend.

The day was another day of thinking about going to Africa. I just can't get it out of my mind now. And because of this, I'm afraid that it'll eventually start to get stale in my mind and I will forget it forever. And I don't want to forget it forever, but instead, I want it to stay dormant in my memory until the proper time comes. Having all my idealism burst out now will waste it all. Currently, I have no ability to live up to my thoughts. Perhaps in a decade or two I will, so I must save my idealism, my hopes, my dreams. So they don't all fade away, like many of my ambitions have. And when things burn up too early, potential is lost.

On another note, I must say that the future is astounding. This statement may seem out of context at the moment, but it really isn't (well, actually, maybe it is). The Sun is eventually going to burn out. So, what does that mean for the human race? It means that this species must do the impossible, accomplish things that cannot even be thought of to this day, simply to survive.

It makes me think of the old animated film, "Titan A.E.". I loved the film at the time. Unfortunately, it was a flop and hardly made a dime in theatres. But, the movie made me think about how the human race's future needs are so interconnected and similar to "impossible" dreams of the future. Giant spacecraft and otherworldly travel are things of fiction now. But, how will we, as a species, survive if they continue to be things of fiction?

And, it all oddly ties in with Speech class, in the fact that we learned about Maslow's hierarchy of needs today. At the top of the pyramid lies "Self-Actualization". In order for these fictional elements to become critical tools for survival, this tier must be met. But, no one can reach the top tier without satisfying the lower tiers, physiological needs, safety needs, love/belonging needs, and esteem needs. So, I figure, that until these needs are met for most of the world, the world will never be able to grab hold of the top tier, the most important tier. The tier that must be reached in order for survival to be achieved.

Obviously, humans have a long ways to go. And, although the time limit is extremely long, the clock is still ticking.

Let's all run the rat race. Maybe some of us will get to the end.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My Time magazine came in today, just like it has every Wednesday of every week in the past. Those old airline miles that my father earned back in the day when Northwest wasn't bankrupt have come in handy in suscribing to Newsweek and Time magazine indefinitely. You wouldn't believe how many miles are in the account. I'll be current on world events for a while now.

Anyways, in the magazine, there is an article discussing how children growing up in today's world are constantly "plugged into" something. Whether it be music player, instant messaging client, or cell phone, electronics fuel the lives of many young people.

It worries me that we, as a society, are so dependent on something that can be taken away so easily, electricity. The crucial energy needed to power America runs through thin metal wires that snake throughout the country, being produced in select locations using polluting methods. One good strike could wrek havoc on the national power grid. Most people now consider electronic devices "necessities", so how would everyone react to no electricity? No computers, no washing machines, no light bulbs, no stereos, no televisions, no ceramic heater. Cellular systems shut down, airwaves silent. Ventilators in hospitals shutting down, traffic lights turning off, waste water treatment plants going bezerk.

In the very unlikely chance that electricity will somehow disappear, chaos will ensue. And computer-fried children all over the world will lose their ability to say, "wassssup!!1!!1" to each other, lose the ability to make phone calls to each other concerning their clothing, and lose the ability to share bad, overly dramatic, emotional poetry with their friends.

And, the world will have a reason to rejoice for a brief moment, until everyone realizes that having no electricity is bad.

I have a lot to study, a lot to do. Skipping sleep entirely tonight seems like a viable option. I'll just see how things come out.

In Chemistry today, I was being rather obnoxious to a friend because of my personal insecurities about knowing the material. Now I don't like myself. What I should have done is kept my insecurities to myself and trudge on, trying to learn everything in my own time, and not ask stupid questions to my peers. I was wasting their precious studying time asking my own selfish questions. How could I? I'm a horrible person, and I know it.

Writing that paragraph makes me want to do unpleasant things. Now I'm in a temporary bad mood.

-3 SELF-ESTEEM EXP

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
You weren't being obnoxious, and honestly, as if I ever study. You are not a horrible person.

I am however, annoyed with the poetry comment. Not all poetry is bad, just most of it.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I remember a day in the Indianapolis Airport. Back before terrorism shook the FAA like an infant in a wood shredder. At the time, I believe I was going to travel back to Alabama for a week. Flying by myself, or course. My father doesn't think well of the place, and my sister is too young to remember the place enough to feel attached to it. I, on the other hand, have fond memories of quaint, little Greenville, Alabama.

So there I was, sitting on one of those musty terminal seats. The kind of seats that are usually some gaudy shade of blue, orange, or green. Seats that creak when one puts too much weight on them, the kind of seats that have been sat in by thousands of people over many decades. Sitting there, smelling the terminal, it smells like exhaust and plastic. Traffic is slow, captains from a nearby plane walk out and stride to the magazine rack nonchalantly. The man at the counter, in charge of the tickets, smiles. Not sure if it's fake or not, but it doesn't seem to matter to most of the people who catch a glimpse of him, so the smiling continues. It's a lazy summer afternoon, nothing to do.

Just a half an hour ago, my father had dropped me off at the airport.

And now I hear a call from a fuzzy airport speaker. One can tell that this airport has not been refurbished in many years. The call instructs me, and other passengers to report to the counter. The smiling man looks down at me from the cheap, grey counter. I hand him my ticket, and I start walking into the flying concourse that will take me to my plane.

Suddenly, a jerk to the arm. The smiling man asks me if I have an escort. At this point, I'm confused.

"What is this escort bussiness?", I am thinking.

And the smiling man isn't smiling so much anymore. He says that I can't get on the plane without an escort. Confused, and scared, he leads me back to a seat in the terminal near a window and an old, rusty wheelchair. There's a soggy mop nearby. It bothers me for a moment, as soggy things often do.

From my seat, I can see the smiling man on the phone with someone.

And a moment turns into a few minutes, then into an hour. Each ticking second leads to social instability. With no parents, I have no back up mechanism, nothing to fall back on. I'm irritable

And so a woman comes up behind me and taps me on the shoulder. She's in a striped uniform, neatly combed hair, airport-ly plastic smell. A whiff of something else, which I couldn't tell at the time. I assume she's there to take me to where ever I'm supposed to go, and my assumption is correct.

Winding through lax security, I have no clue where we are going. "Madness!", I think to myself. And in some sense, it was all madness. The world was a blur, being dragged by airport personnel to an unknown location.

Finally, we reach the corner of the front of the airport, where the ticket counters are. It looks like a corner, but suddenly, I realize that the corner has a door behind it. I go in.

And the scene inside facinated me. About six or seven airport employees sitting around a card table eating tuna from the can. The smell. It must have been tuna. She drags me in, and the men and women sitting around the table greet her enthusiastically. The tuna lady introduces me and my situation (of having no escort to take me to Alabama until my father realizes his mistake and drives back to the airport). She sits me down at the table and asks if I want anything. I don't say anything, so she gives me some food court vouchers, five of them. The flimsy paper cards end up being my only compensation for being in this mess.

But, the personnel seem to interact with each other as if they were one big family. I sit with them at the card table while they eat and discuss things going on around the airport. There is no window in this secluded room behind a corner crevice. Only the harsh light of a flourescent bulb. The fridge hums a comforting hum. And I sit there for thirty minutes or so, absorbing the atmosphere, flipping through my vouchers. There's a Burger King, Panda Express, and three Subway tickets. One of tuna lady's friends notices that I'm flipping through the vouchers and she asks me if I'm hungry. I'm not, but I say I am to escape the monotony of tuna-eating.

I walk out, and I see my father walk in through the front doors. I run up to him and away from the mysterious pack of airport workers. They smile at me and wave. I smile back. And for that split second, not even a moment, I connected with the tuna lady.

And to think... I still have no idea who those people were.

I didn't even have the chance to thank them for the vouchers.

Memories... It's so odd to me how I can remember this so clearly even though it all happened years and years ago.

And it's not so odd that I can't remember so clearly my chemistry that I have to take an exam on tomorrow.

How unfortunate.

(If I don't post again, I'm probably in Utah. Be back in a week)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: this is an amazing story...

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I will be leaving for Utah in a few minutes.

Hopefully, I'll come back alive. Farewell, world. I'll see you in a week.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I've spent the whole day trekking my way through busy airport terminals and the like to eventually get where I am now, in my room. Sitting in my room, the peaceful headquarters for the operations that I so dearly treasure. Operations and tasks such as the kind I am attempting now, typing away. Rather, hacking away at the keyboard. My typing skills have slowed and my once nimble fingers have become clumsy due to lack of computer.

Salt Lake City and Moab were rather ace. Four days of hopping rocks in the desert has given me a rather distinguished tan, which I don't really like.

But, the disturbing things about the trip were not the events that surrounded it, but instead my thoughts and my mind during the trip. Desperate moral quandary, infatuation, a nagging feeling, a happy feeling, things that I cannot understand. Must be the whole "confused teenager" act that I'm supposed to follow. It makes me want to buy a few composition notebooks and write sad things about my life.

I've had these dreams during my vacation. Apparently, I cannot escape that which I try to escape.

School.

English class in particular. But, all throughout the last few nights, when I was supposed to be sleeping, relaxed, content, I was having nightmares about school. Absurd, really. In these dreams, I would encounter surprise exams about books I haven't read, be prompted to turn in assignments and projects that I had not heard about, forget my locker combination or room number, or receive a failing grade on a major test. In the aftermath of these nightmares, I would wake up in a dazed, cold-sweat trying to find the lost assignment or to remember what my project was.

Fear.

I try to get away, but my attempts are always futile. Spring break hasn't really given me a "break" so far.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: *Note: Webcomic added to linkbar (Sob Story)

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Branches and boredom.

When you get bored of something, you have to move on and learn to do something else.

This philosophy cannot be efficiently applied to practicing my 10 minute speech, but today it has. I'm sick of looking at text. Sick of writing, sick of drawing, and sick of moving around. So this afternoon, as I slowly plodded through creating the six notecards that I will use for my speech, I stopped. What I meant to do this afternoon was to rehearse and properly perfect my speech.

That didn't happen.

And instead, the 3d bug has hit me again. It's been nagging me ever since I returned from my trip, when I found a nice, free (as in freedom), and generic Blender-specific model that looks promising as a tool to help me learn more about character animation. I've revisited new, as well as old, animation resource websites to help me understand the very basics and solid techniques to creating fluid life. I'm eagerly awaiting the new audio clip for this month's 10SecondClub animation contest. Application, my friends. I must learn to apply the things I read, and in theory, with practice comes skill. When time permits, I'll inevitably find myself learning, or working on such things. And as inevitably as I'll find myself learning, I'll also find myself distracted from other important things, like my informative speech which is sitting like a neglected child in the corner of my room. Unfortunately, I have to give it this coming week. I'm not pleased with my knowledge of it, so I hope to try to stave off my addiction to Blender for a few days so I can do what needs to be done.

One of the "things that need to get done" is sleeping. That which I will attempt shortly.

Preferably now.

Good night.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Shooting my foam dart gun at the ceiling fan amuses me greatly. Each time I pull the spring back and slowly depress the trigger. The loud click that comes from plastic ramming into plastic, which rams into foam. The forceful pang of the suction cup end of the dart impacting the fan. The fan blade vibrating from the impact, slowly stopping. The orange foam cylinder tumbling in the air to the carpet. All of these things are events that I find great joy in.

And so I pick up the dart and repeat the process.

But, in another way, I hate myself for it. The absurdity of it all frustrates me. I accomplish nothing in this senseless act of mock-violence. However, my primal urge to shoot foam projectiles at a simple device designed to circulate air throughout my room overrides my need to do worthwhile things. Shooting again and again. With no point. Pulling the spring, and pulling the trigger. Pulling and pulling... Purposeless.

Failure to have a purpose is a failure to be a person, to have life, to be anyone.

How exceedingly emotional, these words I write. I am rather ashamed.

The further I pursue this topic, the worse I feel.

Today was supposed to be great, grand, august (or so my vocabulary book tells me), magnificent, splendid, glorious, brilliant, and a number of other synonyms that I don't care to look up. But, now the digits on the clock that sits timidly on the right side of my taskbar read "11:33AM". This day that was given to me to do my favorite things, the day that was given to me so I could do the things I always wanted time to do, this wonderful day, has already half-passed away. And here I sit, as the last digit advances like a bus that has no stop to fulfill.

This bus continues on a destined path, forgetting about my simple need to ride it, passes me by and the world continues to turn as I wallow in my own disgusting puddle of self-pity.

That, my friends (and acquaintances) is a lovely sentence.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Special "End of Spring Break" Edition Post




Let's celebrate with a droll exciting interview with yours truly! Hooray.



  • So, let's start here. Why are you wearing that silly hat nonsense?

Well, for one thing, this is my simply spectacular (My alliteration pwns all) lawn mowing garb. And let me tell you, it's not just for show. Each piece of clothing actually has a purpose for being attached to my body.

  • Mowing the lawn, eh? When did you last do that?

I'm wearing this right now, so when do you think I last mowed the lawn, punk? I actually was just mowing the lawn five minutes ago.

  • Wait, so you actually wear that?

Yes. I do. I think most of my neighboors have gotten used to it by now, I think, maybe.

  • So what kinds of things do you do when you mow the lawn?

Listen to music, move the steering wheel a bit, sometime change speeds, then go back to listening to music. Wash, rinse, repeat. Personally, I think it's a theraputic process. The whole simple pattern of it all. Mowing the lawn is a very brainless task, something that even a droid could do, and this is both a good thing and a bad thing. The bad thing about it is that if one is not careful about one's mental health, then one may become violent. However, the good thing about it is that it is such a mindless task that it enables thought to wander gracefully from idea to idea. The constant loud sound does the exact opposite of what one would expect it to do. For me, the noise cancels out bothersome negative thinkings.

  • "Bothersome negative thinkings"? Are you one drugs or something, kid?

Are you?

  • Uhh... Moving on. What kinds of things do you think about exactly?

I think about a lot of things. Actually, many of the ideas that spring up on this website come from mowing the lawn. Granted, I only mow the lawn about once a week, so when I said "many", I actually meant a bit less than 1/7th of the ideas. But, the concepts I cover in a 45 minute mow include political, local, social, and personal topics. What I said before was much to broad, so let me narrow things down. I think of ideas for my creative pursuits (webcomics, drawing, 3d, etc.), my tasks at hand (the next absurd English project ahead of me), friends (and people whom I wish I were more than such with), and the feasibility of certain socio-economic structures. Of course I never finish such thoughts, so I do so in my room.

  • I remember mowing the lawn being much too long for my tastes, so how do you finish so quickly?

Actually, most of the time I start mowing the lawn I don't check the gas. And as such, I usually run out of gas in the middle of mowing the lawn. When this happens, I have to push the darned thing back to the garage (which is a monumental task in itself) and wait for more fuel. I imagine it is quite humorous watching someone like me push a lawn mower for hours to no avail. That's why I think of it as a service to my community to suffer, I'm entertainment! Or, at least that's what I tell myself so I don't jump off...

  • Jump off what?

*nervous laugh* umm... the lawn mower of course! We're talking about mowing the lawn aren't we?

  • This is where I stop the tape and walk away.

No! Wait, I still haven't told you why I wear these absurd hats!

  • *runs away*

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Haha, this was a great post Ryo.

You broke away from your sleep-deprived, depressed-soul norm.
Ain't it great?
That is really cool post, very inspiring, although you forgot "Wax on, Wax off...."

wow ryo only you would be that cool

- Mr. Cool

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Oh, Kimmy. You never cease to amaze me.

I'm talking about Kim Komando, a technology writer that appears every week in the local newspaper. Today, she decided to answer questions about how to clear a web browser's cache, fix a virus, and/or what a "control panel" actually is. The horrible thing about it is that she's being doing this, answering exceedingly simple and similar questions, for the past few years. The fact that people still don't understand what the control panel is casts a shadow of doubt over the advancement of society.

The "Technology" page of the newspaper comes out Monday, and its always full of mindless, stale, idiotic tech news. Sometimes, actually most of the times, I feel like the editors of the newspapers and the wire writers meant the text to be read by monkeys. This Monday, one of the largest columns was about a new "Desperate Housewives" computer game. On the side of the paper, it mentions a webpage that lets one browse through the Bible, and in end different languages. Obviously for the monumental amounts of people who enjoy reading the Bible in ten languages.

And to add ugly to injury, Steve Jobs is present in a large image that is in the center of the whole web of monkey stool sample. How much longer will "we", as a society and species, have to cater to iPod-addicted, Steve-worshiping, Shallowtelevisionshow-watching, Bible-reading morons?

To tell you the truth, I'm beginning to think that it will be a long time before the Tech page in the newspaper cleans up, if ever.

Giving up on the newspaper, I've spent about 3 hours drawing something up. Tomorrow is a half day, which is a prime opportunity to knock out some more drawing while I'm at it. Hopefully, homework will be minimal over the course of the week. I'm just getting settled in.

Settled in to a living hell school.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I like Kim's radio broadcast on Saturdays.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Nine hours of non-school work time. Nine hours spent like this:
  • Three hours half-asleep, writhing on an old couch.

  • Three hours doing homework, mostly chemistry.

  • One and a half hours drawing something out.

  • Half an hour eating, lunch and dinner.

  • Half an hour brushing my teeth and figuring out that my mouthwash has hydrogen peroxide as its second ingredient besides water.

  • Half an hour typing this post out.


So there's my day in a nutshell. My days are much like this every day, except more time is spent doing homework and less time spent sleeping. I'm looking forward to tomorrow, as I get to do my speech about furry fandom. I can't wait to see how the class reacts to my speech, and speech topic. Something so odd (To me, furry fandom is the oddest thing in the world) and not so ordinary usually isn't met with usual reactions. I'll have to wait until tomorrow to do what I want though, so I'll stop talking about it now, because when I talk about things I want to do but can't, it usually bothers me.

Lately, I've caught an illness which I believe is the cold. That's why I tried to sleep so much today, I'm so tired. But, standing in a hot shower for a few minutes has made me feel better, even slightly energetic. Currently, I'm trying to ignore the fact that my room is slowly running out of tissues, and that the supply will be depleted in a matter of hours if I'm not careful about my consumption of such integral devices. As a side note about my health, I got a paper cut on my right ring finger today when I sat down and a magazine page that was sitting on the couch as well took a slice at my hand.

I used to experience much more pain that I currently do when it comes to cuts, impact injuries, and the like. I'm not sure why, but stubbing my toe on a chair leg (which is sadly part of my daily routine) doesn't have the same "OH (insert expletive here)!!!" power. That's a good thing, I guess. Although I wish I didn't have do be so clumsy every morning.

My cough drops taste bad so I didn't have any today. I brought four to school, and brought four back. What kind of imbecile comes up with lemon-honey flavored cough drops anyways?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
There's nothing like a robotics meeting to make you feel like an inferior, deficient, and otherwise substandard clod.

So many things everyone can do. It's a room full of talented people, after all, and the fact of the matter is that some people are going to be more talented, sometimes much more talented than others. And, often times, I'm sure it's not talent. Most of the time, I'm sure it's not talent because, sadly, I am envious. Saying that someone else has talent says that the someone has something that you were simply not born with. Something that can never be gained or taken or revoked. A "god-given", so to speak, specialness that is priceless. But, if I rationalize (and often irrationalize) the situation and dismiss talent as hard work, I have an opportunity to advance myself, if only for the sole purpose of relieving my envy.

The worst part about it all is that I know on the inside that other people do have things that no matter how much I wish for, I'll never have. I have friends that are charming, so charming in fact, that I often times try to understand how and where the charm comes from. I have friends that are exceedingly fast at math, something that I'll never be able to do as well as them. I have plenty of friends that can interact with people better than I can. Things that I will never aquire. As sad and overly emotional as it sounds, I cannot do anything but agree wholeheartedly to the these statements, a fact that I'll just have to deal with my whole life. And, I'm fine with that. Or at least, that's what I tell myself to keep me from feeling worse than I already do.

Envy, it'll kill me in the end.

Speaking of killing things, more chiefly of which, dying in general, I have a number of people that I engage in daily rituals with. Such rituals include a certain tap on the back, a hello, or the sharing of a water fountain for a split second between classes. These acts happen at around the same time, at around the same place, with the same people, every day. I say hello to certain people every single day, between specific classes. And it's comforting to have a routine even between classes, but then again, I have begun to depend on these rituals.

After all, if someone died, and that someone was someone that I said hello to in the hallways every day, or if I shared a drink of water with that someone every day, a piece of me would die. And I experience it when these people from absent from school on a particular day. And on that day a piece of me dies. But, luckily, it's all temporary. Death isn't temporary. Part of me would die forever if someone I was connected to died. This statement makes me care about the lives of others more.

Not that I didn't care about other people's lives before the statement...

But, something like that would really impact me for a long time. I want all of myself to live, and so using the transitive property we have all come to know and love, I want other people to live as well. And it makes me realize how much I depend on other people, and how much I enjoy being in company.

I guess I enjoy company more than I would like to admit.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I should really start studying my French.

But this morning I thought differently. The cough suppressants I took this morning led to a relaxing of my mind. And due to the strategic timely position of French class as my first one of the day, I was drowsy all through it. I remember being happy and having a mild sensation of warmth that surrounded me and isolated me from the world. (In the afternoon, I would figure out that I had been sweating.) So, as my teacher had said the day before, we took a vocabulary quiz. Very simple, and very easy. Nonetheless, I managed to get a 72% on it. If not for the medicines, I would have cared. Cared a lot.

The person who sits in front of me cared a lot. She got eight percent more on the quiz than me. And she knows this, as she looked at mine as she passed it back to me. The person who sits in front of me is two grades below me, as she is a very accelerated student. She is one of "those" people who make a big deal out of grades. And in certain situations, I fit in that category as well. In this certain situation, the chemicals from the medicines somehow kept me from caring about my grade. I was so happy. And I began to understand why so many people live and die by drugs, because it makes them happy.

This is a B! My mother won't accept this! What am I going to do?

This may not be a direct quote, but this is what the girl in front of me said. Now that I think about it, it is a slap in the face for me, a much older student for her to complain and whine and yammer in my face, even though she got 8% more than me. Perhaps she doesn't understand that what she does makes other people feel inferior.

But, I was too hazed to care about her rudeness. Too happy to care. And it was the best feeling ever, to be free from the confines of my self-discipline. To break the proverbial chains that I have wrapped around myself over time. For a moment, I wanted to just run away from it all and forget about school, and forget about homework, and forget about my commitments.

As the day wore on, I slowly drifted back to reality, as well as my cold symptoms.

The girl who sits in front of me may never know that feeling though. And this makes me sad for her.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Wow... that's really sad that her mom won't accept a B. My parents are GLAD I'm getting a B in Algebra II. I have no idea whaht I'm currently getting in Japanese, though. Oh well. Grades aren't everything.

Although, congrats on your brief moment of euphoria.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The week isn't all over, although my watch tells me otherwise. Fridays are often good. Thankfully, this Friday was no exception. I guess good isn't very descriptive or interesting. After all, who wants to read a teenager's rant about how things are "good" and how things "aren't good". I'm sure I wouldn't want to read such a thing.

Words I write (or rather, type out) usually aren't very optimistic. It's a shame really, because ever since the "Optimist's Club Speech Contest" I did back in middle school, I've aspired to be an optimist. But, I've realized that in reality, optimists are really just de-radicalized idealists. And we all know what happens to idealists. People who put a bright spin on things, so to speak, usually can't solve problems well. Life is a timeline of problems. To these people, there are no problems to be solved, and if there are, the solution will inevitably take place. This logic is wrong. Optimists are impractical and unrealistic. They are the quintessence of visionary. Ignoring something won't make it go away.

So I've accepted the fact that I'm never going to be an optimist with this pattern of thought. Pessimists can do the world good.

The peak of my pessimism came today in Health class (Which isn't much of a surprise). Our teacher is having surgery so we have a substitute. I believe that I have mentioned before that our class contains two mentally handicapped kids who sit in front of me. I hate the class and know that there is no purpose for in it, for me at least. The class teaches the same bland information every year. But, each year, the teachers expect us to have never learned it.

Like I said, the peak of my pessimism. The substitute teacher had this expectation, and thusly she attempted to have a class discussion about drugs (You don't know what it's like to live in hell until you've discussed the same information for four years). She talked about privacy concerns involving drug testing.

And, at the time, and currently still, I thought of this topic in a very broad sense. Like many things, I found this topic to describe man, as a species, very well. Drugs are much like many things a person can enjoy and covet. Power, sex, money, and violence for example. Outlawing drugs has little impact on the presence of them in society. If drugs are so illegal, why must we drug test most every athlete in most every school in most every state? Why must we, as a society, watch faded, hour-long VHS tapes about something that isn't supposed to exist in the utopia we all dream for? We must because it will never go away.

So, in a perfect world there would be no life.

No matter how many CEOs the courts send to jail, money will be stolen. No matter how many times democracy is established, another government will topple to the lust for power. No matter how much we try to elevate the layman, there will always be rulers and peasants. Socialism didn't work, communism didn't work, and in the same way, drug prevention won't work.

At least, that's what I wanted to tell my substitute Health teacher today. But, she just moved onto talking about how the media affects our view on drugs.

Oh, how the simple people run in circles.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Reading.

I've never really enjoyed it all that much. In a general sense, I enjoy it, as it enables me to communicate with those not present at a given moment. More specifically speaking, reading fantasy novels has always bothered me. I enjoy looking at statistics, numbers, graphs, and nonfictional accounts of events and/or ideas, but the only fantasy/fiction book that I've really ever deeply connected to was 1984. I enjoyed this book thoroughly for the ever-present political satire and fascinating . I thought, and still do think, that Newspeak is the neatest thing since sliced bread. It makes so much sense for an all-powerful government to eventually move onto control the language of its people. By reducing the number of words, sentences keep their meaning, yet are more efficient. Without synonyms or metaphors, there would be no confusion in converting the words to a message. Newspeak is a beautiful thing to me.

But, then again, the very words I write here in this glob of text could never be so eloquent in Newspeak.

And to think of such a society as found in 1984, it could make one think for an eternity. If you haven't read the book, I suggest you read it.

Unfortunately, I must soon stop talking about the books I like, and read books that I don't enjoy so much. Macbeth forlornly calls for me from under my pile of books.

Call me crude, but Shakespeare just doesn't appeal to me.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Every weekday morning is eerily the same.

My lamp timer flicks the lights on at 5:00AM, about 45 minutes before I wake up. Then at 5:30AM, my clock radio starts to slowly fade in, tuned to the local NPR/Jazz station. Fifteen minutes after my clock radio awakes, I do. With a fuzzy mind, I manage to listen to the morning NPR daily news. I hardly understand the messages they tell me, but the droning of human voices helps to wake me up. Sometimes I hear a few broken sentences, and I can piece together the events going on around the world. But, these thoughts never last more than thirty seconds. Instead, they fade away as the next new sentence or news story captures my dwindling attention. Trying to understand the news is a great way to wake the mind.

And so this continues until it is 5:55AM. At that moment, not a minute before, not a minute after, I stand up from my bed, and start walking circles. Occasionally, I sit down in my couch and stare at the floor. But, I keep myself from staying in one place for too long, or else I'll fall back asleep. So, I walk to the couch, and then to the desk, and back to the bed to check the time. Like a raving lunatic, a paranoid monstrosity, I walk circles, more of a triangle in all actuality, in my room for those five minutes, waiting for the clocks to turn to 6:00AM.

At 6:00AM, the lamp timer turns off and the room is enveloped in total and complete darkness. The only thing that even remotely lights the room are the glowing blue digits of my alarm clock. When the lights go out, I know I must leave the room. I have a fear of the darkness, and so my lamp timer acts as an automated fear stimuli by painting my room black at 6. Frantically groping around my room like a madman, I eventually find my backpack as well as my graphing calculator. I escape the terror of my room in less than thirty seconds past six.

That is how I start my day. That is how I will start my day tomorrow.

It scares me, the fear of an electricity outage. If there were to be no electricity, I wouldn't even be able to awake from my sleep properly. It really makes me think about the exceedingly important role modern electrical power, a less than two-century-old invention, plays in virtually everything. Y2K demonstrated how important computers are, but what are computers but hunks of plastic and metal without electricity?

I still don't understand how I get to sleep every night with my fear of dark places.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Ryo! This is Elyse. Your rantings make me laugh. Some woman at work was talking about her daughter (I think she said she was a freshman at Harrison). Anyways. The girl has a friend who lives in Japan (formerly of Lafayette) and apparently wants to learn a little Japanese before she goes to visit said friend. I mentioned you absentmindedly, and the lady (who's kind of my boss) made me give her your name to tell her daughter. At least the girl's cute (pics of her are around the office).

Anyways... I apologize. You might have some girl forcing you to teach her Japanese. You can blame me... I was forced into the situation, I swear!
You seem really scheduled in your morning. I am like that too, but maybe not to the extremity that you are.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Accomplishment. Something so very relative.

I have spent the past 3 or 4 hours creating the first second for the Ten Second Club animation contest. Like the name suggests, this monthly animation competition involves animating a given ten second audio clip. For the longest time, I've wanted to participate in this competition with the many great animators that take part in this great activity. Last month, I reviewed all of the 50 or so animations that were entered into the competition. The main reason I took the enormous time and effort to judge these was to get an idea of what kinds of things other people are doing when it comes to character animation. I also did it to contribute to the Ten Second Club community. I enjoy browsing through their forums and job listings. For me, it's exciting to see that this hobby could actually result in cash and perhaps a career. By no means am I of that level of animator, but like I mentioned before, I completed the first second for the ten seconds I hope to complete this month.

The first second consists of three words, "Are you ok?". I put all the previous reading on character animation to good use, by first setting up the few poses that I wanted for this short animation (It's amazing how many poses you need in just one second), and then refining the movements by increments of five frames or so. Since there are thirty frames in a second (technically, there are 29), there was much work involved. Then came the lip synching, which is actually much more than moving the mouth. It's a large task to convey emotion through a face, but I sketched the mouth and face keyframes out on a scrap piece of paper, and then used the paper to enter in keyframes for the face. Then, for about an hour, I touched up.

Details, details, details. The power is in the details.

And so I changed a facial expression ever so slightly, moved the lip a little bit higher, made the arm swing just a smidgen bit more lefterly, and made the body lean an inkling more pronounced.

Then I save (I really should have saved more than once, but hey, I live life on the edge), and hit the "Animate" button. The computer works its magic, and I get a one second animation that looks pretty darned life-like. I add the voicetrack, and I'm amazed at how I gave life to a previous lifeless character. It's truly an astonishing, astounding feeling to make something out of nothing.

My sister walks up behind me and watches me as I mindlessly stare and admire my looping 1 second animation of a character saying "Are you ok?". (Ironic, isn't it?) I ask her what she thinks of the lip synch and life-likeness of the character, and she says that its "alive and that's all there is to it." This in itself is rather amazing, as my sister enjoys mocking all of my creations.

And so tomorrow, I hope to create the second second. Hopefully, it'll be even better than the first one.

*Note: I'll post a link to a video clip showing the one second animation I speak of when it gets approved by Google Video.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
What is your voice track from?

Ohhh, I can't wait until I get to see the finished product!

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
"It's gonna' be one of those days..."

And I really didn't want it to be one of those days. We all know the kind. The kind of days where things are abysmal no matter how many fake smiles you pile on. The kind of time where you constantly have to keep yourself from just sitting down and stop breathing by telling yourself lies about the world, and lies about yourself, as well as lies about other people. Starting in French class, getting a bad test. Something like that just ruins my day, but the fact that it does so makes me feel worse than the initial ill will felt. It's a sad thing when a test makes such a big impact on your life. I tell myself that a perfect person would just brush it off, get over it, and focus on improving, not dwadling and complaining about something that has already happened. These feelings of remorse will do nothing to change the red numbers on my test. And, so because of this, I realize that it's not a big deal, I shouldn't feel anything. But, I do.

"It's yourself. You're doing this all to yourself, and you deserve it."

In all reality, I did deserve today. Deserved today for the lack of effort I put into things. When I really should be giving more than my best effort, I'm just gliding my way through the bare minimum. There's no motivation. And when things get down, and things keep getting down, and things don't seem to ever get better, it's hard to be excited about things anymore. Things. Things like tests, things like friends, things like sleep. Simple, idiotic, selfish things.

"Concerning yourself with yourself is a demonstration of your inability to think in a broader sense."

The truth finally comes out. Why would talk about myself if I wasn't self-centered? The negative attitude, traced to the source, that being myself. It's a self-fulfilling prophecy as well. I might as well make the world hate me even more by writing more words. And as I do so, I become even more of a jerk than I really am. The period that I just typed is not the end of my complaining and whining. I'm just as bad as the people I criticize from time to time. Why even criticize people? The simple fact of the matter is that it is not correct to do so. My life is incorrect. My mind is incorrect. The words I hear are incorrect. Everything I touch becomes incorrect.

"Stop now, people might notice."

I try. But, there's nothing I can do about it. Please, why can't I just not think to myself for a few minutes?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Life plods on.

Rather, excalates, like one giant crescendo that stretches from here to eternity.

Something I've noticed, music pollution. Due to our constant contact with music, it has lost much of its charm, magic, and purpose. Personally, music is having less and less of an effect on my mind. No longer do the complex and melodic rythms of my favorite tunes inspire me to work faster or harder. Music tolerance is a problem. I wake up to an alarm clock programmed to play jazz, get on a rap-playing bus, sit next to classmates that are blasting punk rock through the air, go home in a car tuned to an oldies radio station, and sit in my room and turn on my stereo, which pours indie music out. It's clogged up my mind, clouded the air, I can hardly see through it wherever I go. What is the point of music when it becomes a sort of noise? Sure, portable music devices has brought music consumption to the masses, but slowly the ability of music to captivate an audience is slowly fading away.

It ties into today because I finally caught onto why I've been taking so long to do homework and other tasks in my room. The music. For the first time in a long time, I turned off the stereo when I walked into my room and worked in quiet. In the end, I got done with my homework quicker, and I felt better about myself. There was something about the ambeint noise that filled the room when the music was turned off, like chirping birds, or some whining kid across the street. Something comforting.

And I think it's a sad thing when something as amazing as music begins to degrade due to overconsumption.

Fruits that get too ripe begin to rot. And in the same way, our extreme exposure to music has cheapened the experience as a whole.

I saw a spider crawl next to me when I was sitting on my couch this evening. I'm afraid to get near the couch now. This is bad, as I find my couch very comfortable to do homework in. I plan to Lysolify and cleanse my room sometime this week. I haven't done so in a while now.

Oh yes, Google Video has finished verifying my little character animation analysis clip. If you want to see it, go here: http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=1533736450543236286.

I have just realized that it is thirty seconds until midnight. I better hit the "Post" button quick.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Haha, that video you put together of just that one line is really cool!

Nice job.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The temperature in my room is too high for my taste at the moment. The fan is doing little to help the situation. My room is orderly, in fact, eerily orderly, but dust has become an issue. It seems to come out of nowhere. My fan is probably blowing more dust at me than air. Well, like I've said before, I'll get to cleaning when I'm feeling better, and when I have more time.

But, it's all an excuse, a sham. A sick, wretched way of trying to ignore a problem that won't go away. The solution to the problem being a minor inconvenience that I, as a tired/lazy person, cannot stand to go through. I should stop putting it off and set a date.

Speaking of time, I've figured out that I can make time. Due to a number of reasons, chiefly me obsessively targeting character animation as the "next thing to master", I am choosing to lose sleep to gain time. Novel idea, I know. Sometimes, I amaze myself (not really).

This morning, looking at my French grade really didn't help the day get better. Two words that describe my French grade are, "Damage Control". The next few weeks of that class will be all about cleaning up the gigantic academic mess I've made. But, at least I can tell myself, "It can only get better from here". Nonetheless, I must be alert at all times, be ready for all surprises, and absorb as much French as I can. This is particularly difficult, as this is my first class of the day.

Wonderful, wonderful sleep. Something that I often sacrifice, and something that I always covet.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
It's early. Early morning.

I guess I could call it a passion. A sting. I was seduced. Pang! Another rush of emotion. Click, click. And it's almost done. Glance at the clock, and I realize that it's no longer Friday, but early Saturday morning.

No, I wasn't looking at porn in the wee hours of the morning, although the thought is quite humorous.

What did happen was that I finally finished my 10 Second Club animation. You wouldn't believe how long this animation (which is actually 15 seconds long) took me. True sweat, tears, and not so much blood, my friends. Twenty hours of it, I figure. Or perhaps it's ten. Time gets mangled and disfigured when you're a raving animating machine intent on perfecting a stray keyframe.

So I guess this is when I sigh a sigh of relief, slump to bed, and try to get a few meager hours of sleep before my parents abandon me at the library tomorrow. Oh, how I loathe English papers. A perfectly fine weekend, now tarnished by paper-writing. Not to mention that I have to write a speech as well.

There's no point in complaining further. I'll just have to take it how it comes at me.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
This is Nancy Grace. Frankly, I hate her. I know that "hate" is a very strong word, that is often times too crude to be used tastefully, but that's the only word that comes to mind at the moment. Every so often, I turn on the television while I brush my teeth. Lo' and behold, I always happen to brush my teeth when Nancy Grace is busy ridiculing some poor journalist on national television.

She's a lawyer.

So, I guess that's what she was born to do. Born to protect "innocent" people, born to "negotiate" (argue), born to cajole a confused jury to agree with her through a presentation of "facts". So, in a sense, she was born to bother me.

Every time I happen to catch her show, I try to give her another chance. Another chance to be my friend. She fails every time, because every day, she has this routine that never ceases to infuriate me. It goes something like this:

  1. Pick out a controversial topic and/or current news event.

  2. Choose a side.

  3. Invite a few uncharismatic journalists and experts to her show.

  4. Do just barely enough research to understand the event in question.

  5. Get the rest of the information handed to you by underlings.

  6. Start the show, introduce the topic being sure to add a touch of personal bias.

  7. Ask the aforementioned journalists and experts questions.

  8. Rudely interrupt them in the middle of their answer to ask more questions.

  9. Accuse them of being corrupt liars.

  10. Cut the invitee off completely, and continue to tell the story, being sure to add personal bias.

  11. Introduce a few more guest speakers

  12. Accuse a few more guest speakers.

  13. Urge watchers to take action by writing letters to their congressperson.

  14. End the show with a emotionally-wrenching conclusion that makes the watchers hate the opposing viewpoint.

  15. Rinse and repeat every 24 hours.


Frankly, I can't stand people who interrupt people and don't let them talk. Nancy is one of these people. She asks questions for the sole purpose of interrupting other people, and it is very evident that she has an over-inflated ego. My hope for the world is that someday people will take the time to listen to each other and resolve issues peacefully. What Nancy Grace does is militaristic. She fights to get you to agree with her, and she has no regrets grilling some innocent journalist or health expert. Sure, maybe she's right every once in awhile. But, it doesn't matter to me, because if she's not considerate enough to let other people talk, then her own point of view isn't worth hearing.

I hope she doesn't reproduce. I would hate for the world to be populated with more Nancys.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: *Note: "Seed of Judgement" added to webcomic linkbar.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
It's raining outside.

But, talking about the weather is absurd. The world has experienced what we call "weather" since it has had an atmosphere. It has rained billions of times, there have been billions of lightning strikes, and just as many sunny days as well. Flooding, tornados, hurricanes, ice storms, all run-of-the-mill events that, in the whole scheme of things, are so incredibly insignificant. But, in many ways, we are like the weather. People, they change, sometimes for the better, sometimes for the worse. Through the mistakes and folies come character and strength, and sometimes a bad thing can actually do some good. Thunder hits the ground, which starts a fire, which burns down a forest, which smolders to ash. In many ways, this is both a good and bad event. Bad in the fact that trees were killed, but good in the fact that now the soil is fertile due to the ashes, and new life can grow to be taller and better.

Most people are like that forest. They get hit by unfortunate events, fall down, and through much effort get back up stronger than before. Occasionally, there'll be a Chernobyl, where an unfortunate event doesn't result in good. But, now that I think about it, even Chernobyl came with good. The awareness of the dangers of nuclear power couldn't have come at a better time. Now we all know that such programs require substantial funding and maintenance.

The sound of thunder is comforting. Like the organic thud that comes about from falling into bed after an exhausting day. Like the deep rhythms that bellow out of a passing car at a red light. Like so many little things that make life more than a twisted dopesheet.

Sometimes I have dreams of being hit by lightning.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
There are little white strips of paper on my desk.

On these rectangles are slightly faded lines, from an ink pen scribbling French words on them. They seem to be small note cards from long ago. And they sit there, perfectly in chaos. I don't know what makes it so visually pleasing, but I find their arrangement in harmony with my desk. The angles at which they stab each other, the way they hide under and over the other objects, the means by which they deploy themselves. Such a consummate placement.

Next to the cards sits a few pens, three black ones, in fact. Markers, a cup full them in all sorts of vibrant colors, a pair of scissors, rulers, adhesive notes, tape.

The tape seems so dejected. Forgotten. Although it does have purpose. I use it often, so I guess the tape can't feel so horrible. It has such a distinct aim, purpose for existence. I enjoy staring at that cheap plastic container with an opaque strip of adhesive. As pointless as its life appears, hidden under all of the pretty notecards, it has something so powerful and priceless. And I stare at the tape, and it makes me feel pointless all of a sudden. The tape is sitting on my desk so I can stick things to my wall. The tape didn't have spend its life training to become what it is, and the tape didn't have to make a decision about becoming tape.

I stare at my desk often. It's just another of my inefficient habits, really. My desk reminds me of life. So diverse, and so mixed, and so... Apparently random, but not so underneath. The good times, the bad times. Memories of using the red ruler for making a Valentines card in elementary school. If you want to know, the card never reached its intended destination. A Rubiks cube that I never got to solve. Memories of disappointment, the realization that I lack comprehension in puzzles. The markers, they have such a friendly and inviting feel to them. I've used them so many times, the words on the side of the marker are starting to wear away. I have a little plastic plane that sits on a cheap plastic stand. The cheap stickers on it are starting to fade and crack. The aging plastic brings back memories of being far away in a foreign land.

A spent "Hello Kitty" eraser sits on top of it all, like some gaudy reminder to get more erasers from the store. The little bunnies and flowers smile back at me. Fake smiles. Trying to improve my life by smiling at me, but in reality they mock me. The flowers, the bunnies, the kitty. They mock my complicated life. All they have to do is sit there on the plastic housing of the eraser, sit there and do nothing for an eternity. Eventually, they'll head to some obscure landfill to clog the Earth with more petroleum-based goods. So they can sit and smile a little farther from my desk, and a little closer to hell. I never liked that eraser.

The absurdity of it all. The absurdity of looking at my desk, at the random pile of my belongings sprawled out in chaos. Life, such a complicated thing, yet it can be compared to the simplest things. Or perhaps I'm looking too far into the bunches of inanimate objects that continue to multiply throughout my room. Multiply like the bunnies and flowers and Hello Kitties and other beings that constantly must ridicule me.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I felt calm today. Sort of.

During lunch, my English books fell into someone's lunch. Mind you that this food was pasta. And of course, gunk got between each page, discoloring, as well as casting a very unpleasant odor on and in my books. Not to mention that I have to turn these books in back to the teacher in a week or two. I also forgot to mention that the owner of the lunch was someone I loathe immensely.

I set the books on top of the lunch table. I sit down, and position my books in the middle of the table. The kid sits down next to me. The kid who irritates me in Health class, the kid who obsessively talks about sports, the kid who drives me nuts on the inside, and the very reason I do not to carry a knife to school. That kid. So he sits down.

Somewhere down the table (it streches down the whole room), there is seismic activity, or some people jostling the table. I hear a thud, pay no mention to it. Then, turn around, curious. I find that someone had moved my pile of books directly in front of the sports kid's pasta, and that my books had toppled into his pasta. Of course, he takes them out of his pasta, and keeps eating, nonchalantly. And so I sit and stare at my ruined books. Not particularly excited, or angry, or sad. Emotionless.

I nonchalantly take the dirtied books to the bathroom, and clean them as best I can with some cheap, brown paper towels. These towels are neither effective at wiping, or absorbing, so my job becomes difficult. After a few minutes, I figure that I've cleaned as much as I can. And so I return to the table, where life proceeds as if nothing has happened. The bell rings, and I'm left with my orange, smelly books. The sports kid has finished his lunch and walks out of the doors. I stare at him, but my eyes are empty. I felt like a cold shell of a person. I suppose I forgot how to be resentful for a moment.

After lunch, sort of an odd sort of anger and resentment that has no energy remained in me. A big lump of it just sat in my gut, silent. No visible emotions, no frenzied messages rushing to and fro throughout my mind. Just emptiness.

And for a while, I just walked the hallways only knowing where I was supposed to go, but not why. Knowing the name and number on my ID card, but not my personal identity.

I suppose one could say that things went well today. I don't see how getting angry, or especially spiteful about my books being ruined would solve anything. I'll just have to deal with the consequences of fate. There's no point in shaking fists at things you can't see.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Wow, this sounds like a completely horrible experience.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Time and time again, I find myself out of time.

And so the voyage begins and ends.

I tell myself that I'm booked 'till eternity, but in reality, my life is empty.

But, there are people that fill my life up with substance. It makes existing worthwhile. Going to school every day just to see those people, just for the momentary greetings, the absurd conversations, the smallest of facial gestures.

I walk into my math classroom to see all of my peers. We have at it with small talk, giving each other common hand gesture greetings. The bell rings and the teacher gets up, starts yelling at the class to be quiet with no reaction, tries again, and eventually succeeds. And so we go over some old-news, easy math concept from ages ago that we all know. Behind me, a friend makes a witty remark on the difficulty of the material. I quickly turn around, shoot a quick grin at him, and in return he shoots a smirk right back at me. We continue with our lesson, and the rest of the day fades away in my memory.

Those moments where a common bond is established among peers are so contenting, are so satisfactory, and complete me as a person. I live for the wink and the grin. I live for the smile and the talk. The little things, like how someone walks, the way someone's hand flips a page to a book. The arcs in which such movement is achieved. The tiny, miniscule things that turn humans into people never cease to catch my attention.

Serious topics are so bothersome. Talking about religion, or politics, or economics is so frustrating. These things break friendships, and create conflicts. And it happens too often for my tastes. Everyone thinks they're right, and everyone enjoys partaking in vicious arguments. I used to partake in such things, and I'm afraid to say that I still do at times. But, now I attempt to control myself or ignore such conversations. Over the years, I've realized my own ignorance, and because of this, I've come to understand that I'm exactly like everybody else, in the sense that a resolution will never be achieved with bickering.

The teacher ends the lesson, and the class gets the assignment. Same old day, same old math. We all get done in a matter of minutes. And soon, the air gets stale. As I stare at the clock, waiting for time to pass me by, I overhear a heated argument over some religious belief. And so I turn around to see my friend quibbling, and in his eyes is the primal urge to voice his opinion. I turn back around and stare at the clock. Tick, tick...

Waiting for it all to end.

I believe that if everyone took the time to sit down, look around, and realize how enjoyable people really are as individuals, and not fuss over ethereal things such as ethics or morality, we, as a society, would be in better standing.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Today was a Thursday, and like any other day there was conflict.

I was walking down the hallways. They, of course, are congested. One area in the hallway in particular is the most crowded. There is only enough room between the loitering people on the sides for one person. There is human traffic coming in both directions. Because of this, one must stop to let an incoming person get through, and then go through yourself. The inefficient process repeats itself until the school is empty, or the school administration decides to come up with a magical way to solve the school's overcrowding problem. Chiefly, expanding the school. But, that's besides the point.

And so while I was waiting for someone from the other side to cross over so I could squeeze in next, there was someone behind me. I heard a aggressive command to "move", and so I turn around. While I turn around, the person whom I assumed issued the command stuck a pencil into my back. I recall he had a very plain white shirt with some sort of logo on it, a generic stranger. And his face was contorted into somewhat of a scowl.

Needless to say, I was very surprised, but luckily was able to cross through and escape the madness.

A few minutes afterwards, I felt really negative and angry. Partially, I was blaming myself for causing an inconvenience to the stranger. On the other side, I was angry at him for poking me. I was waiting my turn to get across, so why shouldn't he as well?

After awhile, I tried to forget about it all. And in the end, the whole incident reminded me that there's no point in bothering other people for something that isn't going to change. Doing so has a negative impact on those around us.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The week has ended, and so the real work begins. Three papers to write in two days, little time.

"These are the times the try men's souls", said Thomas Paine. And he couldn't be any truer.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My legs are sore, I'm surrounded by papers, the clock reads a little after two in the morning, and I'm 16 years old now.

Today is supposed to be some sort of a milestone, but getting both of my English papers done seems to be more of an accomplishment to me at the moment.

Tiring. Lots of things going on today. QuizBowl state championships was quite a bit of work. Moving furniture around, untangling cords, allocating food, managing resources. There was also quite a bit of play. Running like a madman in the hallways playing tag, frenzied screaming while going for a headshot in a video game, and a little physical violence, as a few of us bickered about taste in music. Actually, that game of tag was the best fun I've had in months. I'm not sure if "normal" people experience more enjoyable activities on a more frequent basis than me.

I was lucky enough to have one of my peers show me into the lighting corridor that is on the roof the auditorium. From there, one can look down upon the people on the stage. The view is so outstanding that I watched the whole final match from there. One does have to climb three ladders to get there though, which is a hassle. But, I figure that if janitors aren't around, I might be able to sneak in there during lunch period. That'll be my next challenge.

After all of the nonsense at school, I went to see a band concert with someone. Great show, but better talk. And the someone happened to be female, which was a first. Does this strike anyone as odd?

We wrote silly notes to each other, which disillusioned me with the idea that I'm socially competent.

I'm so fritzed. I think I'll go to sleep.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I spent today writing my speech, attending a robotics meeting, and printing/labeling 500 CD's for the robotics competition in Atlanta that is quickly approaching. I leave on Wednesday for the thing.

One of my Robotics teammates parents who works at Purdue reminded me that the Graphics major (animation professional) wanted to meet me sometime. Meeting someone like this is a dream come true for me. I'm hoping that I'll be able to arrange something over the quickly approaching summer.

I got back from the CD printing/labeling binge thirty minutes ago. It's 1:44 in the morning, and I haven't obtained a second of sleep. School is going to be painful.

But, through the hardship comes character.

My eyes hurt.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I was having a hard time concentrating in French class today.

The teacher gave "speaking tickets" to all of the volunteers who gave the answers to her questions (in French, of course). She didn't reveal that she would be until after everyone had finished answering her questions. Speaking tickets are little squares of paper that are redeemable for points. One must collect as much as the "average" person in the class to receive all of the points. Any extra can be taken for extra credit. Of course, being the idiot that I am, I didn't volunteer. When she revealed her intentions to give the volunteers tickets, my heart sank. For the next twenty minutes, I had to talk to myself to keep myself from mentally snapping and having an emotional breakdown.

"How could you be so stupid?"
"Those were free points!"
"Your grade will suffer for your failure."
"Might as well give up, you have no hope."
"You deserve to be punished for not volunteering"
"Why don't you ever learn!? This is what always happens."
"Stupid, stupid, stupid, stupid"
"There's antifreeze in your room for a reason."

So these were the thoughts that were running through my head. I couldn't help but feel helpless, but the fact that I wasn't helpless, that I was the cause of my own suffering reinforced my thoughts that I was an incompetent, selfish fool. Feeling bad would make me feel worse. Feeling worse made me hate myself. Hating myself would make me feel bad.

The bell rings, and another horrible French class period ends. I slump out trying to collect myself so my true emotions don't show. Someone taps me on the back, I turn around, and I mumble something to him. He feels brushed off, so he leaves. Or, I leave him. Too unstable to feel guilty, I, a disgruntled student about to collapse from exhaustion, enter the math room.

Life gets progressively better after this. I sleep through half of the period in math class, and my mood jumps a bit higher. Someone in band class makes me smile. I slowly gain confidence in speech, as I attempt to convince my partner that we have a strong argument in the upcoming debate. I learn to control my incessant urge to decapitate my peers in health class. I explore during lunch. I relax during english. I have fun making a fool out of myself in chemistry. And the bus ride home has me feeling as positive as I was before French class.

But, hell will restart tomorrow. And the deplorable cycle will start again, as it manifests itself in my soul once more.

Every day, I look out of the many windows of the school, staring at the beautiful blue sky and the vibrant greens of the grass blades that wave in the wind like little sails. But, I realize that those pretty things may as well not exist. Looking through those windows is much like looking into a television. I will never escape the establishment that isolates me from the outside. And as I forlornly tap my finger on the thick windowpane in an empty hallway during my lunch period, I realize that this may very well be the closest I'll ever get to experiencing freedom. Even if I manage to escape those that encase me in concrete walls and beige paint, I will enclose myself.

Life taunts me with windows that I'll never break through.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Here's a nice little riddle:

No glass is unbreakable.
Also, Windows isn't exactly an unbreakable system, if you want to look at it that way.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Lately, I've been crashing in the programming room for lunch.

I usually walk around the school for fifteen minutes to collect my thoughts, forget about my hunger, and relax.

Wandering through the school, there are so many little things that one notices. From how many paper towels are in the trash bins in the bathrooms, to the quaint frayed strands of carpet where wear and tear through the ages has unraveled the worksmanship of overseas carpetmakers.

My friend usually opens the door to the programming room when I arrive and knock on the door. I'm fearful that he may be annoyed by my presence, that I'm somehow mooching his free space away. Most of the time, he plays relaxing Japanese pop music, so I always manage to calm down. There's something comforting about a room full of silent, unnetworked computers.

And so my lunch has flown by quickly for the past few days, and I'm loving it. I remember sitting next certain loud people, in a room filled with noise. The clamor of eating, socializing, and the occasional stunt that the next horomonally-unstable idiot decides to pull. The smell of tomato paste and nacho cheese, the smells of things not worth mentioning here. Sticky tables, the even the air being unclean. I've found an escape.

It's 1 in the morning, and I'm debating not sleeping. After all, I'll be on a bus for 10+ hours, but I have a French quiz tomorrow as well.

Like I said, I'll be leaving for Atlanta tomorrow (technically today), and as such, updating will be scarce, if any. Be back on Sunday.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The guy gets the girl. The celebrity finds acclaim. The technician finds purpose.

Some people become winners. Others have to wait.

At the robotics national tournament, everybody was a loser, some more than others. A few successes existed to offset this.

I hate talking about other people, but I do so only because if I don't, then these thoughts will nag me until I either have a mental breakdown, or don't get enough sleep to be capable of memory (recently, there has been more of the later).

Rus worked so hard. Of course, I couldn't see him work. He would stay in the secluded pit area, tending to stray judges, working hard to sway their votes toward our robotics team. He had a mission. He was to present our team as the best team, in both technical and moral fields. He was to add a face to a number, a personality to a cold, heartless machine. And so he did so with a passion.

I shared a room with Rus. I also was in a room with the driver of the robot, and a stray programmer. Together, they would show me how people interact. Every night, we would enter our room together, exhausted. The room smelled faintly of smoke and cleaning solution. An aromatic stain on a nonsmoking designated room. The lamps, they dimly light two beds, a pine nightstand, and a flimsy table. The walls are orange, the picture on the wall is of a generic landscape. The room itself is much like this generic landscape. It is so ordinary, as if all the cheap hotel rooms in the world could pass as this one.

And so we would sit down in the beds, the driver and Rus, making snide comments to each other, the programmer tapping on the pine table, and me running to the front desk to put down a twenty dollar deposit on an ethernet cable. I come back to find Rus proclaiming is accomplishments of the day, never ceasing to mention the fact that he had not urinated for the whole day because of how hard he was working. I mentioned that I had brought the cable to give us access to the Internet. He comments on how I pronounce ethernet. I learn then that I have been pronouncing yet another word incorrectly for god knows how long. Then he goes back to telling all of us how he used his immeasurably sharp wits to woo judges. I turn around organize the pine table, which is now covered in empty cans, plastic bags, and trinkets.

I just couldn't stop thinking to myself, "If he's so fucking amazing, then why can't he help me keep the room clean?"

Keeping my thoughts to myself, I took a shower and tried to wash away my envy. Envy of what, you ask? I keep telling myself that there's nothing to envy. That he's just like me, that I shouldn't complain for where I'm at. But, the fact of the matter is, Rus does more than I do. He is rewarded for his success, and there's nothing wrong with that. It bothers me that he enjoys constantly telling those around him about his success, but perhaps there is nothing wrong with this either. His dedication to the Boy Scouts has led to many powerful connections. His determination and curiosity has led to him knowing just enough more than I do about computers to frustrate me. His persuasive skills gleam while listening to his conversations with people who are more important than he is. Competitive speaking has given him wit, and a thorough knowledge of current events. His very DNA has made him taller and stronger than average.

And so the story continues.

I trudged out of the bathroom ready to sleep. Rus is flopped on the other bed next to a girl from the West Lafayette team. He showed her a few funny movies, and told me to join in, and I did. Every once in awhile, he would make a witty comment and that would cause the girl to laugh. I would just sit there awkwardly watching the bland viral videos. Then, Rus had the bravado to watch a viral video that made fun of asians. Ironically, it would end up being about how asian males are not appealing to the other gender. I laughed with the programmer, the driver, Rus, and the girl to fit in. Inside, I wanted to kill everyone in the room, and die at the same time.
