After school today, I drove to the nearby Ace Hardware and found the Swiss Army Knives. Having a sort of underlying brand loyalty to Victorinox (My father's knife is Victorinox), I chose to purchase a Victorinox Cadet SAK for twenty dollars. Wearing a black turtle neck and black khakis, I felt a little out of place buying a knife in a hardware store, but no one asked any questions. The employees were very nice in opening the knife cabinet for me, it felt very good to have some service, after being so conditioned to the Wal-Mart style of shopping. And another kudos goes to the cashier who didn't complain when I paid the sum in one dollar bills.

So now I have a neat little pocket knife to cut all the hair clumps and Muriatic Acid lids that stand in my way. I do believe this is the same model of Swiss Army Knife that is given to the Swiss Army. Doesn't have as many tools (4 implements), but it's thin and light. Supposedly, the aluminum casing is more durable than the traditional red plastic.



And now you can enjoy a picture of a fat kid looking at movies in the bargain bin. I was able to snap this picture in a local Wal-Mart last weekend.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I went to the Kumon center today. I felt pretty confident through the whole day (of course, this is relatively speaking, as I was only feeling a little confident, which is a lot more confident than feeling greatly insecure, which is how I feel ordinarily), but a kid who is about the same age as me comes up to me and asks me to explain to her a math problem that I don't remember how to do. After muttering and dancing around the answer for a few minutes, she finally tells me that I'm worthless and promptly walks away. Worthless? I sure did feel worthless after that little comment, and so I retreated back to the little kids, where I can explain the intricacies of long division and adjectives.

After about thirty minutes of feeling sorry for myself while grading papers, I am assigned to help two kindergarteners do their reading worksheets. Teaching one kid how to read is hard enough, but two? Difficult. I couldn't focus attention on anything, because my mind was constantly zipping back and forth, trying to coax words and sentences out of these miniature people. And I don't remember how I was taught to read, so I don't think I taught very well, but I did my best, trying not to just hand out answers, but work on each word syllable by syllable. One of the kids wasn't a native speaker, so the "R" sounds always came out as "L" sounds. It's so difficult to teach the formation of sounds. How do you explain such things?

The non-native speaker kid reminded me of myself at that age. Loud, obnoxious, funny, but still serious, with small hints of wit mixed in. He trailed off when he talked, just like I do. Random little bugger too. In the middle of doing his worksheet, he started talking about his bird that he named "birdie". Apparently, he got it from a local exotic pet store and so far that has been his only pet.

I guess he was young enough to not realize how much my social skills suck, so he was very friendly to me. When I walked out the door, he followed me out, and as I pulled out of the parking lot, he waved goodbye to me. I was amazed. "Finally", I thought to myself, "I've found one kid who doesn't hate my guts." Unfortunately, he may very well be a clone of myself. So, I haven't really succeeded in anything today, besides having my self-esteem kicked down a flight of stairs by someone my age, then having it picked back up by a reading-impaired kindergartener

The experience is worth something, right?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Ten minutes at a time. Ten minutes at a time. I have to take my work ten minutes at a time or else I would surely go insane.

How much more of this will I last? I'm dehydrated, my skin is damaged from the sun, but I'm getting paid. The money makes it all better. I draw a little something on the back of the pool log. Kids are breaking the rules, and I question my ability to enforce them. The wind blows and an umbrella tips over. Everything is ordinary.

Back in the days of old, when I swam in swimming pools for recreational value, I promised myself that I would never enforce the irrational health department rules that were imposed on me. The circumstances changed slightly when I started earning cash for doning these things. Enforcing "the law", or so a certain someone said.

I work the morning shift tomorrow. I'm tired. Just ten more minutes.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Never promise something to yourself that you "know" will never happen to you. I promised I would never work in the food industry, and now look at me...

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I rediscovered ArtRage and I've been furiously using my tablet since around 6PM, right after my afternoon sleep. A few minutes ago, I took a step from my doodling and looked at my watch. Almost midnight, and I work tomorrows morning shift. A true "I'm a stupid idiot who can't keep track of the time, nonetheless manage it" moment. But, it's so addictive. I really did think that my tablet would end up being another expensive piece of junk I would regret purchasing. I guess the learning curve was a little too steep for me when I started drawing on it, and that's why I sort of gave up after a few days of practicing. Since 6PM though, I've gotten a lot better, or maybe the program has made it easier for me. Either way, I like ArtRage much better than the 'spensive Corel Painter.

The free version of ArtRage is nice, but I'm debating spending $20 for the full program. Unlocking the layers feature seems really appealing at the moment. I never thought I would ever consider paying actual money for software, but here I am, considering it. You can download ArtRage here: http://www.ambientdesign.com/artragedown.html.

There are lots of little insects (two) near my computer monitor. My pool job is slowly getting rid of my fear of bugs. I'm surrounded by bugs at work, so now I sort of just swat them away, and have no problems destroying the smaller ones with my bare hands. Before, I would grimace at the sight of bugs, but I'm more calm now. I'm glad that my fears are curable.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Another ordinary, "stay up really late" sort of day. There was hardly anything challenging about today, and that's what I hate the most. When there's nothing to stress over, and thus nothing to type about. Relaxing yes, but frustrating in its own special way. Actually, I'm not going to lie. I'm just tired and I wanted to come up with an excuse to excuse me of staying up any later than I have to. Good night.

In other news, my dA account has been sort of revamped. Drawing, drawing, drawing. Blah.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: School will be back soon.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: *Note: Lackadaisy added to webcomics links.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The place I volunteer at was hectic. I tell you, it's an act of superhuman multitasking to be able to volunteer there.

The situation is relatively calm for the first two hours. Tasks are manageable. I'm given a stack of worksheets to grade, and I can grade at my own pace, occasionally helping someone with a math or reading problem.

The last two hours are when things start to pick up steam. Older kids, with more homework, more problems, more issues, more complexity, and more attitude start to come in. At the same time, a large amount of very young children enter. These are the kids who you have to dedicate a lot of attention to, because they're learning to read and such. I figure, if you mess 'em up young, you mess 'em up forever. So, I try not to do anything stupid while interacting with the little ones. All the older kids (most of them) think I'm worthless, but they ask me questions anyways. During the last hour, a consistent stream of slackers who have three weeks worth of homework rush in and turn their folders in. This results in a pile of papers to grade, which coincides with the peak of traffic.

Grading two stacks of papers, teaching a kid to say "fort" instead of "foat", reading and trying to find a series of equation possibilities for a hyperbola, ignoring a screaming/crying kid behind you, and timing all the exercises with a stopwatch, all at the same time. For an hour and a half. It's straight dope, it'll get in your head and tear you apart. I'm sure the tip of my red pen was hot by the end of the first hour. But, I suppose I'm slowly learning to cope with the difficulty of multitasking.

My volunteer work is much more difficult than my paying job. Hoorah for situational irony.

I finished my twenty volunteer hours to get my fancy diploma (which really isn't all that fancy) today, but I think I'll keep coming to the place until the end of this month. Why? Even I don't know. Maybe it's for the sake of routine, maybe it's because volunteering is my way of cutting myself, or maybe it's because I'm an egotistical jerk who wants to rack up volunteer hours to show off to peers. Either way, I'm in for another hectic four hours of "crazy children bonanza" this coming Thursday.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
As many may already know, tomorrow is summer school. I'm glad I'll have something to do in the mornings. It's always frustrating to wake up and not do anything until afternoon.

I derive so much enjoyment from berating my sister on her poor web design abilities. Her color coordination is horrible (parchment paperish yellow mixed with forest green, a splash of bright pink with black borders), she doesn't know how to direct the viewer's attention (distracting decorations plague her new template), and she fails to understand that gradients are for noobs. The last gripe is one of my pet peeves. I absolutely detest gradients. It's something the majority of the world fails to use responsibly. The novelty of these idiotic fills wore off over six years ago.

I shouldn't make fun of her as much as I do though. My attempts at making websites were much worse. Faded sepia background images with magenta and cyan title text, sewage-green mixed with a little pastel pink. My finished templates were surely vomit inducing, and at times possibly fatal.

In other news, a North Korean state-run news source stated that if North Korea is threatened by the US any longer, they will wage "a relentless annihilating strike and a nuclear war with a mighty nuclear deterrent." The US has dismissed such threats as "hypothetical".[LINK]

This is funny. I guess even the US government is laughing at these stupid threats. An "annihilating strike"? Hilarious!

Today, I had to close the pool and reopen it twice due to stormy weather. As I sat in my pool chair waiting for people to come to the pool (three people came for the two hours I sat there), I stared at the sun. The clouds obscured the glowing orb just enough that I could admire its shape without (hopefully) any lasting damage. The sun is perfect. I can now understand why cultures before civilization worshipped and celebrated the sun. Even now, the world goes to church on each "Sun Day". It's so large the sky has a noticeable dent, it's so powerful it hurts the eyes, the sun. It powers us, its energy is the only reason you are sitting here and reading this pathetic post, and I am sitting here writing this pathetic post.

A large asteroid came very close to Earth on Monday, "slightly farther away than the moon." [LINK] One must question the importance of everything from this information. "everything" is so broad, but when dealing with a possible asteroid-Earth collision, everything is at risk of being destroyed. Everything as in everything. Technology, society, culture, civilization, the human race, the planet. Everything. Thinking about an asteroid collision makes celebrity news seem so absurd. So-and-so married so-and-so, etc, etc. And giant rocks are flying through space narrowly missing our planet, narrowly missing destroying everything. When the celebrity news gets more attention than news of this asteroid, and I'm sure it does, then it becomes so glaringly obvious that the world is looking and walking the wrong way. Having everything destroyed is such a simple thing, but it's so hard to conceive in the mind. It's sort of like dying. All of our memories are of when we are alive, so none of us know what it's really like to be dead.

I'm still afraid of dying.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
About two hours ago, I started sneezing. Now I have a headache and I do believe that I am experiencing the beginning stages of the common cold. My sister had a friend over who was sick. I must have caught it from her. This frustrates me, because I hate being sick. And I actually have tasks to perform this summer, so being sick will have consequences on my stress levels.

I hear a loud plane flying over my house. To my left, the posters on my wall begin to vibrate a little. Ice water in my plastic cup is making little ripples. It must be an old propeller plane. But, why do they have to fly so low and close to my house?

Whenever I hear loud planes overhead, I sometimes get the absurd idea that the plane is carrying a nuclear bomb, and that it will drop, vaporizing me and the world that surrounds me. So, usually I stand there and wonder what it would be like to be instantly vaporized. And other times I wonder what I would do if I had advance notice of my impending doom. What would I say, and to whom? What would I do? What would be my initial reaction? How would I feel? All are valid questions that I ask myself often, most often when loud planes are flying overhead.

The fact that I think of these things suggests that I have a fascination with death. And it feels very odd to think about death so often, but it's the apparent impossibility that encases and covers up the blatant possibility that intrigues me. It is very well possible that I could die at any given moment due to a number of circumstances. But, as I type this out, death seems so impossible. And that's how I explain why thinking about death is fun, for me at least. It's fascinating, creative, and scary.

The plane is gone, and my mind patters away from thoughts about atom bombs and death.

I take a sip of ice water and forget about it all.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I hate talking about politics or economics or anything of that sort. I used to love it, but looking back at my ignorance, I've learned to keep (or try to keep, rather) my mouth shut during conversations, or arguments about these topics. I hate talking about these things because I hate people who talk about politics or social crises. As I've said too many times before, "hate" is a strong word. "Hating" a group of people is a very unfair generalization, but in this case, I figure that almost everyone has no idea what he or she is talking about when they discuss politics, so I consider my negative attitudes toward this group of people (everyone) as justified. It's one thing to believe in something, but it's another to take the belief and attempt to shove it down other peoples throats. I've been guilty of this charge many times in the past, and I'm ashamed to admit so.

But, I'm glad I've realized how stupid I am. Some people never figure it out. My revelation has resulted in countless silences of myself during discussions of this nature. Always, I feel this pressure to tell everyone how I feel about a particular issue, but I control myself and only share my feelings with my closer peers.

People always enjoy citing statistics. If the math says "yes", then it must be so, no? But, statistics are often superficial. Drug companies do multiple trials for their new drug, and throw out the trials that don't give them good results. The "bad" statistics, or the numbers that do not favor the company, are discarded, and the "good" statistics are paraded on magazine covers, newspaper ads, and television commercials. Statistics for any given controversial topic are the same way. We, as fervent consumers of information, have no more knowledge of the validity of a statistic than a cherry tomato does of its own existence.

Throwing statistics out of the window, that leaves questions of value, of morality, or of ethics. And the answers to these questions are always different for each person. So, I figure that humanity will be forever plagued by meaningless banter and argument over topics that have no perceived relevance to ones life. I embrace this, but at the same time, strive to abstain from this primitive act. Only in a perfect world, an empty and dead world, can nature be separated from conflict. We are distinctly alive creatures, and as such, conflicts define us.

I drew in my sketchbook today. Drawing is more productive when you know that you do not have the physical strength to do anything more strenuous. I sometimes can't stand drawing because I know I could be doing something more productive elsewhere (although these notions are usually false).

My cup of ice water has run dry. Off to bed for me.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I took zyprexa which was ineffective for my condition and gave me diabetes.

Zyprexa, which is used for the treatment of psychiatric disorders, such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, accounted for 32% of Eli Lilly's $14.6 billion revenue last year.

Zyprexa is the product name for Olanzapine,it is Lilly's top selling drug.It was approved by the FDA in 1996 ,an 'atypical' antipsychotic a newer class of drugs without the motor side effects of the older Thorazine.Zyprexa has been linked to causing diabetes and pancreatitis.

Did you know that Lilly made nearly $3 billion last year on diabetic meds, Actos,Humulin and Byetta?

Yes! They sell a drug that can cause diabetes and then turn a profit on the drugs that treat the condition that they may have caused in the first place!

I was prescribed Zyprexa from 1996 until 2000.
In early 2000 i was shocked to have an A1C test result of 13.9 (normal is 4-6) I have no history of diabetes in my family.
----
Daniel Haszard http://www.zyprexa-victims.com
I don't see how Zyprexa has to do with politics, but I suppose this goes to prove your point about how some people love rubbing statistics in people's faces. Something that I too am guilty of.

This is hilarious.

A spam comment proving my point.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I have to work tomorrow morning. Planned excursions for tomorrow seem exciting enough. We will meet me at the pool and we'll socialize for awhile. Then, all hell will break loose and we'll go to random places in his car (which usually means the library, a random place that I enjoy very much). Anything beyond that time is unknown at this moment. Since I'm sick, I should probably get to sleep. I'm sure I'll find at least one dead mole in the pool tomorrow. What fun.

To the sleepinator (alternatively named: bed)!

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: I'm spending the night at Ryan's house. Happy that I don't have to work tomorrow. Relief. I'm boring.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My computer keyboard feels slightly sticky from the sweat on my fingers. My hot, humid evenings (no air conditioner in my room) are dedicated to writing things at my desk. Three main things must be accomplished every night. Those things are typing posts on this u, writing and replying to emails (of the lengthy kind), and writing in my personal composition notebook. Two of those things require the keyboard.

It's mindboggling to think of the data transmission that has gone through this keyboard. Words from my mind, converted into binary chunks of data, shown as text, sent to servers all over the world. To think, at the moment this keyboard is the only link I have between you and I. It is how I talk to you, convince you, perhaps insult you, and at times encourage you. These keys, how they have been pressed to produce sequences of letters to form words. These shapes, so abstract, but to the trained mind, they contain massive amounts of data. I'm fascinated by the fact that there was a time before the written word, and I'm even more fascinated by the fact that there is written word. And why I have five fingers, and how five plus five equals ten. And how ten is a two digit number. How petroleum was used to make this textured, black plastic that makes up my keyboard. How your mind is looking at these oddly shaped lines and taking meaning from them. And how you interpret this meaning.

Text is difficult. Metaphors and similes, personification, simple wordplay. There is no "tone" or "pitch" to be analyzed in text. No facial expressions to accompany the "hey, wazzup"s and the "I love you"s. This is what makes text so difficult. To convey the meaning you intend, it takes extra effort not to confuse. But, always, there is means for misinterpretation. A critical failing point of the written word.

So why keep typing? With so many flaws, why does text exist?

Written word is easy to preserve. And although words may not be the most sincere, surefire way to communicate, it can be shared, kept, copied, created, modified, and analyzed as long as people know how to read and write. It's economical. It's intellectual. It's the past, present, and future.

I'm waving back at the past while zooming into the future. And in my mind I wonder how I've come so far, and how far I'll go. How far I'll keep typing.

An unfortunate thing it would be to have my hands destroyed. It would be as if I had no mouth anymore.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My 20 hours of "service learning" ended last week. Today, the hours at the volunteer place passed by excruciatingly slowly. Every glance at the various chronographs stationed in the room was painful. I really shouldn't express this pain, as these words I'm typing are mere complaints, after all, this is a volunteer gig. My complaining is pointless and will most likely eliminate the little goodwill I have with you. That's very unfortunate. Because I figured out goodwill is a very powerful thing.

I biked around my neighborhood to get to my pool job a few days ago. I have to bike a very limited distance, but I do encounter at least three people every time I make this trip. Before my discovery, I would never wave or greet another person.

"Don't talk to strangers", everyone told me.

I would just bike, ignoring them, pretending they didn't exist. And usually, they would see me and do the same. No eye contact. We're both blurs to each other, and there was never any human connection. Two seperate entities, and not a trace of friendlyness or common humanity.

But, on the bike trip a few days ago, I decided to perform a few hand waves, maybe a smile or two directed toward these random people. And, surprisingly, people did the same. It sure did make me feel better, and I hope I did the same to them. I don't know what it was about it. Hand motions and smiling seem simple enough. But, the meaning behind the motions were what carried the most importance. For once, I was acknowledging these other people's existences. I was admitting them into my circle of very, very faint aquaintances. They weren't blurs of color anymore. At that moment, I realized how "Don't talk to strangers" is a relic of the dangerous past. I'm not an easily manipulated kid anymore. I'm allowed to be happy in public now.

I was stupid to think for so long that an unhappy sentiment would repel danger. If anything, it perpetuates it. New orders: Smile, smile, smile. Yet again, false positivity and optimism solves all.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I'm wearing a solar watch which won't run if it's left in the dark. It helped me realize that even the most constant source of energy, the sun, can fail. Indoor lights can power the solar cell decently, but the electricity for those lights come from power plants that burn compressed bio-material. The compressed bio-material got its energy from the sun.

Sometimes, the greatest things fail. We all look up at the sky and feel the sunshine on our peachy cheeks, form armistace agreements, vow to disarm ourselves, promise to work toward peace and not war. But, in the sky there is no sunshine, and hope is often shot down by the raindrops of conflict. Brutal fighting, random killings. And ordinary people, as well as people somehow "justified" in dying, are targetted for reasons that can't stand up without a crutch and a wooden leg. It's hard not to grow disillusioned, and see that history is a window to the future.

I hit myself in the head. It's stupid to just think about one side. There can't be bad without good. And there are plenty of people who go beyond their obligation to help other people. The only self-interest they have are other peoples' interests. The greater good, a movement towards a perfect world without suffering.

That can't exist. What am I doing here in my happy little world? I don't deserve this.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Reality is harsh. Or rather, waking up to reality is harsh. Tired. I've been very tired recently, but I can't convince myself to stop functioning, lay down, and sleep. I can only sleep when I know there isn't anything better to do, which is very late at night. Somehow, my twisted mind thinks that sleeping isn't as important as pointless meandering around the anthro section DeviantArt looking for good opportunities to leave a comment. I see myself during these times, and am disturbed at how pathetic my actions are.

The physical fatigue outweighed my mental urges to stay up when I sat down on the couch and fell asleep at approximately 8PM. Someone was in the shower, so I couldn't further progress my "get ready for sleep" process. That is why I was on the couch. Almost spontaneously, I started dreaming about giant birds eating my legs. Although the dream was very graphic, the feeling experienced was very relaxed and comfortable. Finally, I was getting some much needed rest.

Thirty minutes and a few dreams later, my sister is telling me that the shower is open. Half-asleep, I sit up, mutter some gutteral throat noises, and fall back asleep. It was so comfotable to be asleep, I didn't want to wake up and go back to reality, go back to being awake and tired. I wanted to be asleep and relaxed.

Fifteen minutes pass. I'm still dozed off on the couch. I wake up for a moment, startled from something in the dream. My return landing into reality is rough. The bright light from a nearby lamp irritates my eyes. Everything around me starts to shift around in all directions as I scan my eyes around me room. I try to stand up, but my motor control is still well under normal levels. I stagger to the shower and turn on the water.

Hot water doesn't help. I start feeling thirsty and accidentally drop the green bar of soap on my foot. I spend two minutes trying to pick it up from the floor of the shower. Each attempt to grab the soap fails, and the precise movemements needed to obtain the soap are in short supply. As I try to get a grip on the idiotic soap, my mind is trying to get a grip on being conscious.

The antics continue until I drink a cup of water in the kitchen. The world returns to its previous sane state. Upon which I question whether I was really tired at all, or just dehydrated.

Next time I'll save myself the hassle and just drink more water.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I'm not facing the computer. Maybe if I don't face the computer, I'll think better. Looking at the small 800x600 screen is so very restricting. It's so restricting in fact, that sometimes I have great difficulty in finding topics to expand upon, words to throw out into the fray. I turn around to look at the computer screen for typographic errors. None so far, but I shouldn't look back. All I have to do is trust myself. Trust myself to do the right thing, and to type the right words. I really enjoy the lighting of my room. I've come to appreciate darkness, as well as light. I have one fluorescent lamp that casts a grayish light throughout my room. The glaring brightness of my studio light is too gaudy for the current mood. I guess it's only appealing during the winter, when I need the light to make up for the sunlight that never seems to reach me through the dreary winter clouds.

I got paid today. It's quite a feeling to finally be reimbursed for the hours I spent risking my skin to the sun, and the rest of my body to the muriatic acid I put in the pool. The payment came in the form of a little beige check. I suppose I'll cash it tomorrow, to exchange it for cash money. But, when the bank worker hands me the money from the register, what is it worth it to her? Hundreds of thousands of bills pass through her hands, and how does my measly hundred or two affect her? They're just green rags with numbers on them. A modern quantification of the time and energy spent working.

And these slips of paper do nothing but sit in front of me, taunting me. They urge me to spend them, but I know I cannot. My post-purchase guilt is hard to bear. And the money does not bring me happiness, or even self-satisfaction. When I make a 10-second club animation, it brings me satisfaction. When I draw another picture, it brings me satisfaction. When I type an entry, it brings be satisfaction. Green rags don't bring me satisfaction. They are so important though. But, why? I hope to someday live a simpler life and make a lesser role of these decrepit slips.

I plan to wake up an hour earlier tomorrow. My hypothesis is that if I wake up earlier, I'll be less groggy during summer school. I hope to prove myself right in a little more than seven hours.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: I awoke from a nap an hour ago and didn't believe that it really happened. I'm glad it did.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I knew Yo could do it! Congratulations! YEEEESSSSSSSSSSS!

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I was at the pool for eleven hours today. The sun will do things to dyou. It'll even make you start to type "you"s with a "d". My screen is black, and the text I type is green. These words slowly build and make the green swath longer. I aim to fill the screen two times over with the green. I know I can't though. I hate nights like this.

Working at the pool today, I talked with Ryan about how a certain family seems not to talk to us, as pool attendants. The family usually nonchalantly walks up to the "sign-in" table with a smile on their face (whether the smiles are genuine or not are beyond me). Ryan and I both cheerfully greet them. They ignore us, do not make eye contact, quickly sign the sheet, and walk away. They have consistently been doing this ever since I started working. It bothers, and mystifies, both of us. The questions that remain unanswered:

Why do they constantly avoid eye contact?

Do they have something to hide from us pool attendants?

Are they really top secret Russian spies?

Although these questions may never be answered, I hope that someday they overcome whatever is holding them back from being friendly, and look into our eyes and smile at us, instead of the sign-in sheet.

The act of avoiding eye contact (which I am guilty of) bothers me, because it's a sign of many negative things. A signal of superiority, concealment, anxiety, anger, fear, or a combination of any or all of the above. The world should make more eye contact.

On a random note, I put up a sign a few weeks ago on the water fountain that said, "Out of Order: very hard water". At the time, I knew that something was wrong with the water fountain, and after a lady filled up her water bottle with greenish-brown water, I decided to stick up a sign warning people of the doomsday water. David, an old man who is really nice, and keeps things running around the pool, came by and commented on the sign.

He said, "Whoever wrote that sign had no idea what the hell they were talking about".

He said that because the compressor has nothing to do with the water quality, and because the compressor was working, the water fountain was still "in order'.

I felt stupid.

But, of course, I didn't tell him that I wrote the sign.

I may not be safe though. My handwriting is very different than that of any of the other pool attendants. I think I have very scratchy handwriting. Being the sly old/senile fox that he his, he probably already figured out that I wrote the sign.

Oh well, I'm not going to be bothered over it. I made a mistake, and I'll admit it.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Don't let what someone else says bother you.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: Monday, monday, monday. I want it to be monday. I feel like a little kid at the supermarket wanting to buy that shiny, new etch-a-sketch. Except, I'm wanting it to be monday, and I can't pay to have time move faster. End! End now, cruel weekend. The minutes continue to pass, but why so slowly?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
It's really late at night and it's bothering me that I'm having trouble sleeping to more of an extent due to events and/or ideologies which may or may not be mentioned here in the future.

There girl at my volunteer work that couldn't understand equations of lines. She kept asking for help, and I just couldn't stand it. It's one thing to not understand something and try to work toward understanding it, but it's another to depend on other people to do your work for you by "explaining" how a certain problem works. She said, "I'm thinking of quitting soon, so does it really matter?" I just wanted to throw her out of the room, because what she was essentially saying to me was, "There is no purpose in this program, and it's worthless to me if I learn anything or not, so give me the goddamn answers you mother fucker, the answer book is right next to you."

I just gave up and stopped helping her. Of course, she got up and leeched answers from another assistant, but at least I kept my moral obligation to not help the arrogantly naive.

The rest of the day was wonderful though. Took all of the muck from volunteering and threw it all out of the window. I'm grateful that I have nothing going on tomorrow. I'll take it as a day of rest, perhaps.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My Internet connection is not working, and it is bothersome. Or rather, my network adapter is giving me wonky indications that there is some sort of interference between myself and the router. For information to get to me, I must caress my network adapter. Yes, I must physically be in contact with the hardware to get it to receive information. Like when the radio reception gets better when you touch the antenna. Maybe, there is interference in the air, or the router is damaged in some way. Until the madness of the network stops, I'll have to have one hand attached to the panel antenna while the other surfs the web.

Today was a completely free day for me, so I took advantage of this and slept for a long time. Hopefully, this deposit of sleep tokens in my resting bank will stave off the fatigue creditors for a few days. I can't expect the weekends to generate any sleep income anymore. I think there's more time during the weekend, but I always end up doing more during those two days than any other weekday.

I went out to Wal-Mart and bought a $40 fire chest. It'll supposedly keep the things inside of it intact if a fire happens to ravage my house. I figure that it's a good price to pay for something that is unlikely to fluctuate in price. Years from now, it'll still be functional, its value will be the same. If I were to buy, say, a computer game with those $40, then I would have gotten bored with it in a few months, and it would be worthless after a year. The fireproof, waterproof, sisterproof box is going to retain its distinct boxiness for future boxification of valuables. And in the unlikely event of nuclear war, I can put things in it, bury it, and die with a false hope that future civilizations will somehow discover the $40 thing.

There isn't much to think about during these slow, sleepy days, ok?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
The network problems could be caused by something else on the frequency you are using.. Log into your router's admin panel and change channels. (There are 12 channels.. Use them wisely.)

Fire resistant safes use a chemical reaction to lower the temperature inside when the outside gets warm. After a while, even if sitting at room temperature, the chemicals in the safe get used up. To test this, put the safe in the sunlight for a couple hours and then open the safe. It will be slightly cooler than the room. It should last several good years though before being just a very heavy box.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I worked until 9PM today, which was unpleasant, but tolerable due to the fact that Ryan was able to keep me sane. Because of the lateness of work, typing this sentence has become hard. My eyes water from lack of sleep, and the harshness of the lamp light. In my random cyber surfing, I found a neat thing that I feel should be shared.

Name Voyager [LINK]

I used the java application for a little bit. Apparently, people stopped naming their babies "Pink" after the 1900s, and names such as "Jesus" and "Mohammed" have been on a sharp rise since the 1980s. I typed in "Blue" as a name, and it said that it had no results for babies named "Blue". Why can't humans be named after colors? If people can name their babies "Pink", then why not "Blue", or even "Red"?

"Roscoe" was a big hit in the 1890s. Now it's not even in the top 1000 names. I think "Roscoe" is a decent name. I would prefer the name "Roscoe" to "Jesus" any day. But, my personal view on names differs form that of everyone else.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Aren't surprise robotics competitions fun? It's sort of like surprise sex. Except being on the receiving side. What I'm actually trying to say here is that finding out that you will be attending a robotics competition tomorrow morning at 6:45AM is comparable to being raped.

But, all nonsense aside, it's my fault entirely for pushing the IRI competition to the back of my mind while I caroused through my July. I'm just glad that it happened to fall on a date in which I do not work or volunteer. Now that I think about it, I don't think it'll be too bad. Familiar people, familiar bus ride, familiar robots. Being part of a small team is nice. It makes me feel purposeful and wanted (except when the small team rejects you, and then you just feel suicidal).

There are negatives though that come with a whole day's plan being nullified. Ryan will be unhappy for me not showing up to the pool to keep him sane (I owe him a favor(s) now). I'll be parted from my beloved summer school class, and I'll have to make up worksheets and maybe a test when I get back on Monday. That and the whole waking up early thing. I'm decent at doing that though, so I shouldn't be complaining.

I must now hurriedly print out a form for Mr. Florence (the leader of the West Lafayette robotics team) and forge my mother's signature on it. I bid thee farewell.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
bah.. robotics.

At least today is supposed to rain.

Have a nice competition. See you Sunday.

This is Ryan, by the way.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
There is grit in my hair from riding in the back of a truck. I was riding in the back of the truck on the way home from the robotics competition. As I sat in the truck and as the green blades of grass zipped past me, the sand sitting on the floor of the truck was pulled up to the sky, the dynamics of air and sand being demonstrated by nature. The sand flies up, pelts my face, and the wind dies down. The graveyards, old motel billboards, and shiny new minivans with anxious little children in them, all zip around me like a blur. A giant blur. The truck ride is a painfully fun tradition. I will be doing it again early tomorrow morning.

The giant blur of my life.

It sort of makes you think of one's perception of speed, and the speed of time. It doesn't make sense to say "speed of time", but everyone knows the feeling. The feeling that something passed by too quickly, or a period of time feels much too slow for comfort. This afternoon felt slow. I'm not a very integral part of the robotics team, so I was there for the sake of being there. Something good did come out of the competition though. I got to meet a very good character animator from another team. He's older than me, so I don't have to feel too envious (although, he is much more knowledgeable in the subject that I am, and so I do feel envious at times). I should feel lucky, from him I'm sure I can learn plenty.

But, other than that, the day was pretty sleepy. I have to work the morning shift tomorrow, so I need rest. Something that has changed thanks to the magic or robotics.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
As I type this, I know I am biased in my telling of this story. How could these blasphemous words be true?
Well, this is an anger post. These are my skewed views of reality. Take nothing as fact. Although, I may see it as such.



He looks at me. Almost as if I am expected to obey his every command. To him, I am the ultimate subordinate. I park my bike and enter the pool area trying not to make eye contact with Mr. Stevenson. Here is some background information. Mr. Stevenson is the father of Stacy Stevenson, another pool attendant who is a year younger than I am. Mr. Stevenson occasionally volunteers to do things at the pool. However, today he is in the hot tub with other Stevensons. Them being his two daughters and his wife. I get to my chair and look up again to survey the pool. My eye catches Mr. Stevensons eye. He smiles. It's not a friendly smile. It is a smile the man flashes to show the world how much happier he is than everyone else. I did not know any of this, did now know his intentions, did not know his thoughts. Did not know the future, the simple association and relationship we happen to have in this chaotic and giant world.

The weather is spectacular, although that adjective may be a little overly enthusiastic. I think I'll add an adverb and call the weather moderately spectacular. The clouds fluff overhead, the air is warm, the two pools are clean, and my shift is about to begin. The clock strikes two, and Stacy Stevenson is officially off the hook for being pool attendant. From her position inside the hot tub, it seems that she hasn't been working hard. This is to be expected though, attending pools isn't a very demanding job. Watching the pool, cleaning the pool, collecting money for the pool. Pool, pool, pool, yada, yada, yada.

Seeing that the baby pool is a little low, I open the cover to the valve that controls the flow of water into the baby pool. I turn the lever, put the cover back on, go to the pump room, turn the water input on, and I sit back in my chair. MInutes pass as I watch the people in the pool swim, as I watch the Stevensons chat away in the hot tub. No one can see where I look because I am wearing mirrored sunglasses. The children play their little games in the pool, the sun inconveniently heats up my previously cold water bottle, and the baby pool fills. Fills and fills and fills.

There is an "8" painted on the side of the baby pool to designate that the water is eight inches high. I usually fill the pool so the water level reaches the middle of the painted "8". It's still at the bottom of the eight. I stare at the baby pool. By now, Ryan has arrived, and we chat a little as time slowly passes from my shift.

I'm surprised when Mr. Stevenson walks up to me and asks me if I have my watch programmed to alert me when the baby pool is full. I think to myself, "What an absurd question", but outwardly I attempt to show no signs of admittance of the absurdity of the question. Of course, I say that I don't have my watch programmed to do such a thing. I say that I'll stop the valve when the baby pool is full, I jokingly tell him that I'll surely notice if it overflows. He says something to the effect of,

"Nobody wants it to overflow."

"But, I need to fill up the baby pool."

"I think the baby pool is high enough."

"I want to fill it high because evaporation will lower the water level."

"There won't be any evaporation."

"I apologize, I will turn the valve off now."

"Ok."

Then, his wife juts in and says something supporting her husband. I don't even remember what she said.

But, I remember thinking, "Now they're ganging up on me? I guess they both enjoy bossing people around..."

Just slightly annoyed by the fact that this man has ordered me to do something against my will, and better judgement, I turn off the valve and submit to his wishes, always remembering to smile. I start to wonder when the Stevensons will leave the pool and let me be.

Again, minutes pass. I see that the unwatered bushes are starting to wilt. I convince myself to water them. If I was a plant, I would want to be watered. I pull out the hose, and Ryan helps me keep the hose from falling into the pool and getting tangled on random pool furniture. I water the first one. Splashes of water bead up on the yellow leaves of the infant sapling. After thirty seconds of hosing, I move onto the next plant. The same process ensues. Then the next plant.

I'm surprised again when Mr. Stevenson walks up to me and asks me what I am doing.

"I'm watering the plants."

"There are no plants to water."

"A woman approached me a while ago and told me that she had planted little bushes to fill up the empty spaces between the more mature bushes."

"I don't see any new plants."


I point out each little plant. It is obvious the the casual observer that these little plants were planted here with purpose. They are symmetrically spaced out between each larger bush.

"So, when did this woman tell you that?"

"About a week ago."

"Well, I sprayed the whole grounds with weed killer a little bit ago. I thought those were weeds."

His wife quips from across the pool, "Yup, he sprayed the whole grounds." As if I couldn't hear what the large man standing a few feet from me was saying.

"Well, they aren't weeds, sir. I have to water them."

"They're practically dead anyways. Stop watering them."

"I apologize for watering the plants. I'll put away the hose now."

With a gracious smile, I put the hose away. Inside, I'm burning. By now, I'm starting to jump to a higher level of annoyance. A level on par with anger. Not to rage yet though. I walk to the food area with Ryan and we eat cookies while mulling over Mr. Stevenson. I vent my anger by talking to Ryan. It helps me.

I look at the baby pool and see that the water in it has indeed evaporated. I open the lid to open the water valve again to raise the water level of the baby pool. No more than thirty seconds pass after I put the lid back on before Mr. Stevenson walks up to me and asks me,

"What are you doing now?"

"I'm filling up the baby pool again. The water is too low."

"The water isn't too low."

"Well, it's lower than it was before. Sir, the water is about a half an inch below where it was thirty minutes ago, thanks to evaporation."

"Go get a measuring tape, why doncha'? There isn't any evaporation."

At this point, I'm angry. I keep it inside and say it with a smile,

"If you insist. I apologize for the misunderstanding. I'll turn the water off right away"

I go back to the eating area with Ryan for some more talking. He leaves to go get a bag of chips from his nearby house. In the meantime, Mr. Stevenson & Company decide to all get in the hot tub. With all of them in, they displace too much water. Ryan comes back with the chips and we both laugh about the whole situation. Laughing is a good way to hide negative emotions. When Mr. Stevenson & Company decide to get out of the hot tub, water gets in the pump because there is much less water left in the tub. Mr. Stevenson informs me of this, and I hurriedly shut off the pump. I bring the hose out to replace the water when he decides to walk up on the deck. He says,

"I didn't know you could shut off the whole thing."

"Yeah, there's a switch in the back. I figure it'll take at least five minutes to fill this tub back up to the previous level."

"Don't fill it too high."

"I'll try not to, sir."

"You can go eat your food with your little buddy now."

I remember thinking to myself after his last sentence, "Who the fuck does he think he is? Ryan's a 'little buddy' now? And he can tell me when I can and cannot eat my goddamn food? I'll fucking tear is ass-clown face off if he decides to shove another bogus order on me."

I smiled and walked to the food area. Ryan informs me that he called me "a dog" earlier as he was ordering me to stop the valve on the baby pool. I'm still smiling on the outside, but on the inside I'm ready to brutally rip his testicles out and put them in an anthill for him to desperately fish out. I control myself by talking to Ryan some more.

Finally, the Stevensons leave.

"Good riddance.", I think to myself.

I open back up the valve on the baby pool and water the baby plants again.

I really do hope the plants survive.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I duct-taped the AM radio antenna to my wall, and now I get solid reception for my favorite jazz station(AM920). This is just another reason to break out the over-priced imitation-alcohol beverages. After these tedious months of listening to classical music on 101.3FM, jazz seems so fresh.

It's really late at night. Past midnight. And I'm not tired at all. It's a very stupid-sounding thing to say, but those health textbooks are wrong. Wrong, wrong, wrong. I'm getting along just fine on very few hours of sleep. The future holds great potential for the vast reduction of sleep hours. Until "the future" rolls around, I'll keep sleeping my luxurious 5 hours a night.

I want a potted plant in my room, but I don't like the insects that are attracted by the mini-flora. The decision will be made eventually to either give up my fantasies of having a potted plant in my room, or to splurge and go buy a small rubber tree. I used to have a rubber tree in my room in Alabama. When I moved into the house, I the plant was three feet high. Four years later, I had to get rid of it because I was moving. The plant had grown into a true tree. When it didn't fit through the front door, I had to cut it into small pieces. I still remember the streams of rubber that flowed from the dying plant. Such a waste of life. But, if I was given the chance to nurture botanical life again at such a personal level (you must understand, I said 'good night' to this rubber tree every night), I would definitely do it. I'm sure there's a small rubber tree that needs a home somewhere out there. I've just got to find it.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The last day of my volunteer work was supposed to be significant. I guess it wasn't meant to be so. As I walked out of the Kumon center today, the day couldn't be any more ordinary. And to think, the only thing I have to show for all of that volunteerism is a signature and half a rum-raisin cake in my refrigerator. But, what am I talking about? Volunteering is about getting nothing out of doing something. I'm grateful that I had the opportunity to contribute to the future tyrants of the world local community.

I almost hit a passing car when I was backing out of the parking lot and stepped on the accel pedal instead of the brake. Luckily, the car was moving fast enough to miss my van by inches. That used up most of my good karma (that I've been building up for awhile now), so I have to be extra careful. There won't be any more good karma to bail me out of dire situations. Vigilance! And the need to do good deeds.

All this superstitious babble, and I thought I was a skeptic. This whole karma thing is fun though. It's a great way to justify going out of the way to do simple, selfless things. And the false security isn't bad either.

*slaps self across face*

What am saying? In this egocentric society of faithful redemption and lack of individual responsibility, I am clearly delusional.

My eyes hurt.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The world seems different every time the social situation around me changes. Being at point "X" with family is completely apart with being at the same point "X" with a friend. And things are even more different if I'm alone. I'm being very vague when I say "being... is different". Suppose I look at a painting in an art gallery with a good friend. To me, the painting will separate into different points of interest, and I'll pick out a point to bring up in conversation. The point will differ to accommodate for a given scenario. If we (the friend and I) are being humorous, then I'll pick out a funny point of interest. If we're both in a serious mood, then I'll comment on the symbolic nature of the painting.

People always say, "Just be yourself."
I ask, "How can you not be yourself?"
One could counter my question by saying, "You can act different when around certain people, or when in a particular environment."

But, isn't "acting" as a behavior an indicator of who one really is? One can pull many personality traits from the act of pretending artificial emotions and thoughts. Dishonesty, Malice, Creativity, Shyness, Insecurity. All are possible sources of the false "mask" that people often wear. So, for some people, "being themselves" would essentially be not being one's self. From this, one begins to question the assumed simplicity of personality. We label people in our minds, if only to make it easier for our brains to retain the information.

He's annoying. She's friendly. They're dangerous.

It's inevitable that someone (or maybe everyone) will be misunderstood.

During an outing with some friends two days ago, something insignificant happened that may or may not tie into this mindless rant. After eating diner, we all went to Purdue to hang out. (Part of the reason we went to Purdue was to show Ryan the clapping-squeak circles, and the rest of the reason being our need to get drenched in the fountain.) As we were walking around the campus, I saw a concrete pillar and decided to use my arm to elongate a jump beside it. Sounds like a random action, right? Well, it's not random. There must have been a reason behind it. And these past two days, I've been trying to think of all the possible reasons why I did such a thing. Maybe it was because I wanted attention. Maybe it was because I needed to release a lot of stress and energy.

We can only theorize as to the underlying causes of my action. But, surely it was for some reason.

The sum of my parts is my whole. So, the many individual personalities I exhibit are, yes, a good bit of "who" I really am, but they are only partial units. I don't see how I could ever consolidate them all into one. I don't see how I could ever be "myself" in all of my entirety. Am I misunderstood or am I misunderstanding everyone else? Or both? Why am I so concerned?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Thousands of micro entities that make up one. Every emotion for every situation. That is the key.

Self-realization is something we will seek all our lives.

You can never actually be your entire self at once. To do so is a paradox. And not an easy one at that. Don't try to be everyone in yourself, be yourself for that moment.

Tell me if that makes any sense in the slightest.
I don't remember you doing the jump thingy, but if I had to guess, you did it because you were happy.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I took a long nap today, and it has helped significantly in my ability to stay up late and fry my eyes out with the wonders of late-night Internet surfing.

Wonders, pft. Rather, the most malignant, vile tumor on the internal organs of humanity.

Currently surfing:

  • www.digg.com

  • www.cnet.com

  • www.deviantart.com

  • www.lifehacker.com

  • www.boingboing.net

  • www.allofmp3.com

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The wonderful world of slang is upon us. Popular culture is spitting out new and innovative words in a rate like no other. Slang is often forgotten as time passes, but for a time it becomes the language of the people. The very lifeblood of street communication. Fresh, new words spread through the land in waves. The recent expansion in technology has led to an equal, if not higher, expansion in the development of this proletariat vocabulary.

But, all positive events have negative side effects. Slang is no exception. Take my last name for example.

According to urbandictionary.com, "Chiba" is:

  1. how retarded fucks spell the word cheeba. It is one of the better terms used to describe marijuana.


  2. a portable mp3 player made by rio audio


  3. short for "cheap bastard," especially one who flaunts his own wealth while keeping your wages low


  4. an abbreviation for "Creating a Harmless Environment to Enjoy Buds Appropriately"


  5. a prefecture in Japan, across the Tokyo bay from the capital


  6. an ugly girl...one not worth fucking


Who would have known that my last name would be so... colorful? There was never really a large amount of teasing within my group of friends (because my friends aren't insensitive bastards), but when I meet younger, less educated children, the reaction is predictable. I don't mind too much though. It's a great conversation starter, sort of.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: Surprise storms are not very lovely when they hit at work. The sky above the pool seemed ordinary enough, until a large black splotch started to race toward me. Under it was a large grey curtain that blocked the sun. I underestimated the incoming rain, and was unprepared when the storm hit. In a frantic rush to get things out of the rain, I forgot Ryan's cell phone on the table. Hurriedly, I picked the battery out of the cell phone. I hope that when he tries to turn it on it'll work. I'll feel guilty for a long time if it doesn't.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I worked the morning shift today. I woke up at six for a few seconds. I opened my eyes and turned my head just enough to be able to recognize the numbers on my watch. I had a split-second mental debate on if I should wake up this early, or invest in the sleep. I ended up sleeping more. Until eight. Ate breakfast, checked my email, biked to the pool. 9am-11am is pure manual labor. There's always something to push around, carry out, clean, or empty.

One of the more memorable moments this morning was when I tried to refill the soap dispenser in the men's bathroom. Earlier, Ryan told me about how he had to do something about the soap dispenser, and I just sort of nodded along. I discovered that listening is important when I poured a big helping of antibacterial handsoap into the dispenser. Immediately after the soap started filling up, the plastic bottom fell apart, spilling the soap. Soap on the sink, on the floor, on the wastebasket, on my hands, and on my clothes. Needless to say, soap isn't a cure-all for uncleanliness when it's covering everything within arm's reach.

I work the morning shift tomorrow. Hoorah.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The "Baby Bunny Massacre of 2006" has officially been prevented.

This very true story involves a lawn mower and five baby bunnies in a hole.

Like most other sundays, I was mowing the lawn. Grass grows, and needs to be cut. I like to type "cut". When suicidal people google "cut", I might show up. Cut, cut, cutting. I'm still cutting. Grass, of course. I finish up my cutting by mowing the edges of the lawn. This means grazing the barbed wire fence at the back of the yard, grazing the walls of the house, and occasionally panic-swerving to avoid water spouts.

I approach a clump of grass. Nothing new. I've been rolling over clumps of grass since I was born. But, as I get closer, the clump starts to move. This gets my attention. Then, a little brown animal jumped out of the clump. That further got my attention. What appeared to be a chipmunk or squirrel quickly tries to hide in a concrete crevice in the wall of the house. Too terrified to care, it runs straight into the concrete wall of the crevice. I pull the lever and stop the lawn mower before running over it and its home.

Climbing off of the lawn mower, I see more little brown animals inside of the clump of grass. I stick my head near it, and four more brown things jump out. They're a little bigger than the size of my fist. Further inspection reveals that they are baby rabbits. I turn to see if the impact-prone rabbit is injured. It isn't, but now it's trying to shove its head into a crack above it. Behind me, one of the baby rabbits runs into the woods. I grab the rabbit in the crevice and put it in my hat, its little body trying to squirm away.

I go inside with my hat and rabbit to show my parents. My mother is horrified. She had a friend whose finger was bitten off by a squirrel, or so she tells me. Baby rabbit, squirrel, same thing to her. My dad is fascinated, he comes with me to release it back to its nest.

I carefully walk to the clump of grass where it jumped out in the first place. I see two other baby rabbits trying to hide in the same crevice that I pulled the hatted rabbit out of. It must be some sort of communal emergency shelter. Not a very smart one, as it's in a concrete cave with no escape. It reminds me of cold war bomb shelters.

I open my hat and let the rabbit back in the clump. Hopefully, the mother will return tonight to feed them. I start the engine on the lawn mower and put it in reverse. I'll ignore that patch of grass for awhile.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I filled my blue cup with ice. Walked over to the faucet and pulled the lever up. Down comes the water. The sloshing continues until the glass is full. Ice water is so important in my hot room. But, by the time I trudge up the stairs and glance down at my wet cup, the ice is all gone. All that is left is slightly cool water. Accepting defeat, I take a swig of that good stuff and enter my room. Hot, humid, bordering on steamy.

Almost as hot as work today. A severe heat advisory for the local area was being broadcasted on the radio just before I went to the pool to work for seven hours. Heat is unpleasant when not felt in moderation.

Tonight is the night I study for my US History II class final exam. I know very little at the moment. I'm so late in studying because I had to work an hour of overtime, making my work last until nine. Now I'm in my room, trying to convince myself to study, trying to convince myself that I'm not tired, hot, or sleepy. Funny thing that the only thing on our exam will be three essays. One on Watergate, one on the Iran hostage crisis, and the last one on the Persian Gulf War.

So, I'll stop typing and get to studying. It's the best for both of us.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: Tired and studying French. Go away.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The 10 Second Club is up and running for this month again. Now I can resume humiliating myself online by making poorly done animations make a new animation for this month. A big deal for me, but the resurrection of this event comes at an inconvenient time. WIth all of the "have-to's" and "want-to's", it'll just be another thing added to my large list of tasks. I like this month's sound clip though. It'll be fun if I can get myself to finish it before the month ends. With the beginning of school coming speeding toward the present, that'll be a difficult thing to do, I'm willing to sacrifice sleep for the humiliation. It's the false hope that I'll get better at animating if I keep practicing.

In other news, it's midnight and I haven't gotten past chapter 6 in Grapes of Wrath, which must be read in the coming week. Time to hit the books, again.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Chapter 6 is unforgivingly long.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Desk: $49.95

Step one: Open box.



Step two: Read instructions.



Step three: Assemble desk.



Step four: Assemble cabinet.



Step five: Enjoy finished desk. Go get a glass of ice water.



The whole project took two and a half hours and a blister on my middle finger. And now I don't have to write on a flimsy cardboard rectangle on my lap.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I ate too much.

After eating a very small brunch and working six hours in the sun, I was on the verge of starvation very hungry as I biked home at around 9:00pm. I get home and there's a table full of leftover food. Since everyone else in my family has already eaten, I don't have to worry about consuming in moderation.

So, I eat. And eat. And eat. I get tired of eating, but I eat some more anyways because I have nothing better to do. Then, I start to walk away from the table, but I come back within five minutes to eat more. Food dances around the table. I have a psychedelic hallucination and the floor turns to green orbular grapes and flying latex gloves. I fall into the floor and spin around for awhile. I wake up from the nonsense that I write with a gut feeling. But this is no instinctive sensation.

Like I said, I ate too much.

And, even in my room, I'm having urges to chew things.

For example, my bottle of "all-purpose" glue:

-No, I'm not a pathetic, depressed paste-sniffing ruffian. The lighting just makes it look like I am. Yes, I speak the truth.

I remember chewing things as a little kid. Sometimes it would be the collar of my shirt. I used to have a baggy navy blue shirt that I wore all the time. Got it from a garage sale. Months and months of chewing the collar ruined the thing. I even admit to chewing window sills. Little did I know that paint was not kid-intestine-friendly. The getting deadly paint chips in my mouth was worth it for the wonderful experience of gnawing the window sill. Ruined a few of those as well. Parents weren't so happy. Although, I can always blame them for never buying me gum at the local K-Mart. I would always ask for gum in the checkout lane, but never would they say yes.

A traumatized child with a bad habit, or a mysterious glue bottle-biting phantom menace? You tell me.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: You never cease to amaze me. I'm buying you gum.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I finally realized that my buttons sucked, so I changed them to simple text links. I figured I was missing something, so I added a "badge" of my 5 most recent flickr pictures. I have plans to maybe add a list of frequently used applications to a chunk of the sidebar. I got rid of the "suscribe to this blog" button since it was a constant and depressing reminder that no one actually takes the time to push one button to suscribe to this blog. Moved the archives down a notch, since I figured that the people who come here are at least up to date within the 20 post buffer. People like pictures. My apologies go to those minority of dial-up users who are forced to look at pathetic pictures of myself assembling a desk.

Tomorrow I go to an anime convention in Chicago. Some people at school believe that I'm really into Japanese animation. Not as "into" it as one would expect. Sure, I think it's enjoyable to watch, but I'm not interested in the genre of entertainment nearly enough to remember names of directors or voice actors. Sometimes not even characters. I'm just going to the convention to see something new. Maybe take a few pictures. Make a few mental notes. Gain valuable "con" experience. The works. Everything except buy overpriced anime merchandise.

I heard a radio commercial while working at the pool a few days ago. It was advertising for "Faith Christian School" or something of that sort. A woman's voice says,

"I want them to grow up with wholesome principles..."

Later in the commercial, "respect to authority" is mentioned as a chief of these wholesome principles.

I find humor in the fact that good, "Godly children" are trained to respect authority so adamantly.

I think that an important part of becoming an adult is to learn how to question and challenge authority. I agree wholeheartedly that respecting authority is well and dandy in many situations, but the act of challenging authority has brought about many positive changes in the past. I'm sure there'll be many positive changes in the future as well.

I guess if we all went to this fancy religious school, then we would truly become Godly children, and in the end would become completely and utterly obedient to those who claim to be above us.

Could we ever incite something to the scale of the American Revolution? Never, but we could always go to church and pray that our oppressors will be more benevolent tomorrow. Could we ever incite something to the scale of the Civil Rights Movement? Of course not, but we could always go to church and pray the prejudice and injustice away.

We could then all become genuinely Godly children. And wouldn't that be just swell.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The line is short. Two people long. And there are two of them. Behind a desk are two artists. The large poster behind them informs me that they produce artwork for Neopets. The pretty pictures of make-believe animals entice me to get in line. The poster also tells me that the artists will draw me a free sketch of my favorite neopet.

Years ago I was obsessed with neopets, neopets art, neopets McDonalds toys, I even had a few neopets trading cards. In time, this obsession faded away. I was no longer chained to the giant, capitalistic venture meant to capture and brainwash the minds of children. But, the fond memories of playing flash mini-games to get more neopoints, buying magical potions and foods to feed to my neopet, trying to find rare items to sell, these memories never disappeared completely.

The person in the front of the line has walked away with his completed sketch. I take a quick glance at it and see the beauty and cuteness of his neopet. Only one person in front of me. At the front of the other line is Ryan. For his picture, he's getting a Krawk, done in red colored pencil. I figure he'll be finished before the artist even gets to me. I start hoping for the man in front of me to get done quickly.

A few minutes fast, and simultaneously, Ryan's Krawk and the man in front of me is finished. I step up to the desk, and the lady looks up at me. The poster says her name is "Story". So, I tell her what I've wanted to tell her for the past fifteen minutes.

"I'd like a Pteri, please. Done in red. Thank you so much."

She starts drawing. Her smooth hands draw equally smooth curves that slowly meld together to form a circular body. Then, a circular head is drawn. The tip of the red colored pencil zips around the page, making quick nicks and long broad strokes. A head is drawn. Then a tail, then the wings. Minutes pass, and the details, the feathers on the wings and the reflection in the eyes, slowly come to shape. Finally, a finished Pteri is drawn. She signs her name in the corner of the paper and asks,

"Would you like your name on it?"

"Nope. Thank you so much though. I really appreciate it."

I walk away in awe and amazement at the art. Real life neopets art. In my hand. On a real sheet of paper, drawn by a real neopets artist, with a real red colored pencil.

Ryan and I carefully secure our sketches in our bags. To the next booth, forward to new excitement.

I went to a comic/anime/video games/dungeons & dragons convention in Chicago today. It was called Wizard World. Lots of excitement, lots of walking, lots of tiredness, lots of pseudo-valuable Marvel and DC merchandise, lots of adult hobbyists trying to barter for pseudo-valuable Marvel and DC merchandise. I'll post photos soon. I got my picture taken with Pikachu, and with the Red Power Ranger too.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Freshman Orientation. All the newbies to high school come together in the wonderful educational establishment that I sometimes call, "home". This year, they all got orange shirts, for free. Yes, for free. They look like nice shirts too. There are paper shortages during the school in the spring, but the school can afford to give away shirts to all of the incoming freshman? Absurd.

But, don't listen to me. I'm just complaining because there was no such thing as "Freshman Orientation" when I first came to high school. What a boring time period I must have lived in. No free shirts, no cheesy inspirational speeches about high school life, no obnoxious forms to fill out.

My job today was to help the robotics team recruit people. Four people showed up today to help promote the team, and if you look to your right (I've ridden way too many trolley tours) you'll see pictures of the team's attempt to capture the hearts and minds of the newbies. We drove the robot a little bit. Ran into a few kids, just slight bumps. Picked up a few foam balls. Impressed a select few, interested just as many.

I put on a bandana on my head and over my mouth and ran through the cafeteria screaming, "JOIN ROBOTICS! YOU'RE CRAZY IF YOU DON'T!" That turned a few heads.

All in the name of trying to recruit new people. This year's robotics team is so very short on people, and if we don't get more people to jump on our boat, I'll have uncomfortable amounts of robotics work. If we don't get more people, I'll have to animate my brains out and jump around building things at the same time. So many things. I'll be so tired. I'll be so depressed. I don't care because I'm the animator and I've got to do my job.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I didn't know I was so shy.

Before today, I figured that I wasn't as shy as I was a few years ago. I've had many, many social events take place over the course of this summer, and last school year as well. I started to relax, get to know people better. Still talking with an occasional stutter, but talking nonetheless. The memories that pop out in my mind are of me and my QuizBowl friends playing cards in a hotel room between my house and Washington DC. I did a few things that I ordinarily wouldn't do. Not stupid things. But, little, subtle things. Talking a little louder, being more dynamic in my expressions, exhibiting a looser body language, being more open to talking about certain topics. My conversations and random outings with Ryan also pop out in my head. I can talk to him and actually not care about what I say and how I say it.

I went to register at school today. An annual pilgrimage for all enrolling students. This year's wasn't all that fantastic. The line for registering was long, but the line for getting a parking pass was even longer. By chance, I got parking spot 460. I like even numbers. Perhaps my parking spot is lucky. Don't tell me otherwise, because you'll break my paranormal hopes and dreams.

Locker was in the Technology hallway. Not so fantastic locker real estate. I'll be sharing lockers with people most likely. I have the top locker though. So I won't have to crouch to get things anymore. My back will thank me when the school year starts up.

But, again, back on topic. I walked into registration and I felt really afraid. My eyes are slowly getting worse, so I'm starting to have trouble making out faces. So, I would glance at people and not be sure if I should save or say hello. When I got within range to recognize faces, I would usually be too afraid to say anything or even wave. Lots of awkward glances. I just stared down at my shoes and kept shuffling forward in the line. Just wanting to get out of the place. Just wanting to escape.

After over an hour, the paperwork was finally done. On my way out, I forgot to hold the door open for someone, and so felt bad for a few hours at my house. Just sulking around from room to room, that's what I did for awhile.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I talked to my girlfriend for a long time on the Internet. Now it's late and I still have to take a shower.

Have I mentioned that Tiffany is my girlfriend in this blog before? I don't think I have. A link to her blog is in my sidebar if anyone's interested.

We've been "officially" dating since July 14th. Yup. It's the truth.

I'm going to hit the "Post & Publish" button now, and not regret it. Because what is there to hide? Absolutely nothing. I love her a lot, and there's no shame in that. I have been taking steps to hide it, as if it's some bad thing to be in a relationship with someone. Well, I'm convinced now that it's not a bad thing.

I want to yell at myself myself, "What's so embarassing about it?", and, "Why can't I tell my parents?"

They'll find out eventually. And if this post helps speed up the process, all the better. There's no point in holding it in. I love her. I love everything about her. I've come to love her over the past two years. Now I know that she loves me too.

I'm so very lucky.

More will be posted later.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Yeah, I'm gonna say it...

Awwwwww

Can I say awwwww too? Even though it's about me?

Anyways, you remember that whole tomatoey thing? Yeah, well, job accomplished......Love you too.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Here are deposited three significant things that happened today:

  • A mosquito bit me under my watch. A very inconvenient location it is. This morning, I washed my face and felt an itch come from my wrist. I figured it was just irritation from my watch, but the feeling got stronger and stronger. After a few minutes of subconsciously itching under my watch, I took it off and saw a small red bump. Put antihistamine cream on it, it never helps stop the itch, but it never makes it worse, so I wear it to put my mind to ease. I hate mosquitos, and am lucky that I haven't been bitten more than I five times this whole year. The mosquitos usually have no mercy on me. But, I'm not through the warm season yet, I shouldn't count my chickens before they hatch.


  • I'm officially a permanent resident of the USA. I got home from schmoozing with Ryan at the pool late this afternoon. My mother handed me a card with my face on it. In the back was on a green background, white text that gives me rights that I should have had fifteen years ago when we applied. All of these years. I can work, I can get scholarships, I can travel. I don't have to wait in the giant "visitors" line at the O'Hare Airport the next time I come home from a foreign country, and I don't have to go to Japan every two years to renew my visa, I don't have to be labeled an "illegal" by those certain people at school who think that visa is only a credit card.


  • I told my mother about Tiffany. She didn't make a big deal out of it, and the reaction was positive. She's holding off on telling my father though. She says that if he finds out, he'll make fun of me every day for a long time. I'll trust her discretion and hold off on letting my dad know. He was never much of a social person. He wouldn't understand. Then again, I was never much of a social person. Maybe it's hereditary.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Congrats on telling your mom :)

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Life has become very confusing.

I don't know what to write in each item I write every night. I wrote a detailed description of what happened at the movie theater with Tiffany, Heather, and DJ in my personal journal.
