I wrote an email to Tiffany about how I feel sad right now. Only so many things happen in one day, so figuring out what to put in each text pipeline is a challenge.

My eyes hurt. I'm afraid of sleeping, but I'm getting more tired every day.

I had a nightmare about school last night, that's why I'm afraid of sleeping. These nightmares are common during nights before the start of school. I'm expecting to have one tonight. They're horrible. Always, there is death, anxiety, depression, confusion. In these dreams, I can hardly describe in words how terrifying they are. I wake up just as a giant concrete slab is crushing me, just as a bomb tears me to shreds, just as a knife cuts into me, just as I die. And all I think when I wake up is, "I don't want to die."

I'm all wound up. I hate these nights before school. Nausea. Stress. Frustration. It's either one or the others. I don't know what to do to help me cope. Typing helps. Sleeping would, if I wouldn't get these nightmares.

I was intrigued when I read the entry under the "Cognitive Aspects" of the article on "Social Anxiety" on Wikipedia. [LINK]

Cognitive Aspects
"In cognitive models of social anxiety, social phobics experience dread over how they will be presented to others. They may be overly self-conscious, pay high self-attention after the activity, or have high performance standards for themselves. According to the social psychology theory, self-presentation, a sufferer attempts to create a well-mannered impression on others but believes he or she is unable to do so. Many times, prior to the potentially anxiety-provoking social situation, sufferers may deliberate over what could go wrong and how to deal with each unexpected case. After the event, they may have the perception they performed unsatisfactorily. Consequently, they will review anything that may have possibly been abnormal or embarrassing. These thoughts do not just terminate soon after the encounter, but may extend for weeks or longer. Those with social phobia tend to interpret neutral or ambiguous conversations with a negative outlook and although still inconclusive, some studies suggest that socially anxious individuals remember more negative memories than those less distressed."

I can relate.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I had a school dream last night...

I forgot to read Grapes of Wrath so I borrowed notes and was trying to memorize them really quick....
I've never had nightmares about school.... I feel left out...

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My Starfox Adventures video game came in the mail today. I played it for an hour or so, but stopped when I realized that I had to mow the lawn. The rest of the day, I did mundane chores to fill up time. I never got back to the game. And now I'm here, awake an hour later than I planned to be. My newly bought video game brings into question how I use my time for entertainment.

I've been meaning to study for the past week, it just hasn't happened. It's all my fault that things have turned out the way they have, but I can't change the past, and I'm too weak to change the present.

At the moment, I'm typing words to be displayed on my blog, not pouring over lists of French verbs or reading Grapes of Wrath. This isn't productivity. Productivity would be putting into long-term memory important information. My parents commented on how hard school is in Japan. What kind of lazy, stupid slob am I to be doing so little when I have the opportunity to do so much?

It's getting closer, closer, so closer to 11PM, and it makes me angry.

But, I might be doing something with Tiffany tomorrow, so that takes my anger away and turns it into bubbly nothingness.

Going to sleep now. Seems like the most productive thing I can do right now.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I'm typing this post early to adjust my sleep schedule. If I don't type it now, I would probably start typing at 10, get distracted by the wonders of Internet surfing, and finish a smallish post at around 11. I'm hoping to be asleep by 10 or so, and wake up at around 5am. It gives me a good seven hours of sleep. And enough time in the morning to wake up and wipe off the mental grime that accumulates during sleep.

When I was in middle school, I always wondered what high school was like. Older people told me that things actually mattered in high school. I never really understood them, because I was an ignorant, idealistic kid who thought that things in middle school actually mattered too. Now I know that I could have gone through middle school with sub-par grades and gotten away with it without penalty. How I see high school, things do matter. But, just high school itself is too easy. To turn this basic education into a more fulfilling experience, you have to join a few extracurricular activities, juggle a social crisis or two, and throw in an attempt to record all of this in text and images.

You always have to throw in something new every year, to spice things up. During freshman year, it was joining the diving team. During sophomore year, it was joining robotics. This year will feature the addition of managing a fledgling relationship. I really don't know what "managing a fledgling relationship" means yet, but I'll find out in a few days. The addition of a few more social events in my life means less time spent moping around in my room. I'd say that's a very good change.

I looked back to what I posted exactly a year ago and was pleasantly surprised that I wasn't nervously posting about the upcoming school year. So, I guess I wasn't born an anxious wreck after all.

In other news, if you are of Arab descent, drive a minivan, and have a bunch of cell phones in said minivan, then you're a terrorist. [LINK] I guess the charges by the FBI against these men would make sense if you didn't remember that thousands of other people are buying and selling prepaid phones merely for profit. We should be concerned because discriminatory arrests like these have been happening here for a long time. A few decades back the government was arresting communists, before then it was the Japanese, before then it was the Irish. Before long, they'll be arresting anyone wearing polka dots.

item.title: Last Day of Summer Post '06
item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The events in this entry happened on July 14, 2006. [LINK]

The sky is speckled. Blue, a brilliant blue, with white clouds floating along whimsically. Temperature: hot. I drive down US Highway 52, and my mind is buzzing, my fingers tapping. My breath is quickening and my heart is pounding. As I type this, my heart still is. The oldies music streaming from the radio speaks wantonly of love. Billy Joel, The Beatles, The Jackson Five. I wonder if they're missing something, or if I am. I've been listening to these songs for my whole life. The notes, shrill twitters, and the booming thuds, they have never had any particular meaning to me. But, now they're different. Can't quite grasp what is different about them. The speedometer reads 45mph. The sign says 55.

"Better hurry up. No point in dragging it out.", I tell myself.

I'm excited. I approach the last stoplight from your house. As I make a hasty left turn, I ask myself,

"What am I doing here?"

I'm i front of your house five minutes later. I can only think,

"Is this really happening?"

The answer to my own pointless question is answered when you walk out of your door. Your purse jingles at your side. The black fabric and faded red emblem are washed out by the sun as you step into my car.

Instantly, I attempt to justify and quell my jitters by fussing over fictional odd noises in the trunk of the car. Before leaving, we both walk to the back of the silver Honda Accord, the rocky gravel crunching under our feet. The simple sounds of arguing birds fills the air.

I open the trunk to find a large bin of spilled tennis balls. We both laugh a little. But, while our nervous chuckles continue, I'm thinking and trying desperately to figure out if you suspect anything.

We put the tennis balls back into the red and white plastic bin. With a klunk and a rattle, the trunk is closed and the engine is started. The sharp, orange needles spin to life in the dashboard. The radio kicks on. I pull out of your neighborhood and look back up to the majestic sky, admiring the towering supercell miles away. Rain. It'll come soon. I bring my eyes back to the road and try to focus on driving. It's to hard to do this. My heart choked with something, the air choked with your sweet smell, your wonderful voice talking, all these things set in motion both the parallel secret and unsecret plan. The mood is established.

We chat over gas prices while the radio continues to provide background noise. Sometimes static, sometimes song. In the car, it really doesn't matter. We manage to navigate the winding streets between your house and our destination. I try to show my safety by actually stopping at lights when they turn yellow. It doesn't impress you much, and justifiably so. Then, we start talking about your driving skills.

Sparkling flies, as the world always seems in these moments, bash onto the side-view mirrors of the car, releasing their organs from the oppressive shell that held them. The wind pushes the lifeless carcasses up and away from the car. Only the penny-sized brown splatters remain. Flies are simple creatures. I imagine what the fly would have thought about the loss of its future. Its crushed hopes and dreams, its energetic past, from the egg to the hard plastic of the car, its ambitions. What would the fly have done if it lived?

In my nervousness, I take a right, going the wrong way on a one-way street. We are downtown. There are loads of cars and the streets are very tight. Visibility is limited. I'm driving into oncoming traffic. The odds are against me.

A few tense seconds pass after I see that the line on the road is white and that the cars parked to the side are pointed toward me. With luck, I find an alleyway to the right. It leads to another road across the block. Constricting the alley are large brick walls, leaving barely enough room to squeeze a car through. Inside the car, we're having a great, loud fuss over the incident. Laughing, yelling. My smile is genuine.

We eventually end up parking in front of the library. We open the car doors and step out. I love the sound of closing car doors. Thunk. I tell you of the various disguises I have in my bag to be used in case my parents walk in on our meeting. Each block feels like a minefield. So many things that could go wrong, can't let this opportunity fall apart because of a stupid mistake, or a stupid accident. The concrete rectangles guide me along. Slowly, surely, and nervously, we make our way toward the coffee shop.

Nearing our destination, I see a bunch of smoking teens, each with their intimidating stance and equally intimidating clothing accessory. Wind filters through my fingers as I try to rush past them. Gotta' keep myself from making eye contact. But, you trail behind me. Looking back at this, I have to ask myself,

"What am I so afraid of?"

We walk into the building that can be described only by a long string of adjectives. It's a humble, dark, empty, fragrant, relaxed, mellow, brown establishment.You get a small Sprite, and I get small iced tea. The lady at the counter gives us our beverages in large styrofoam cups, and we pay our two dollars. I feel a little guilty for not paying for you, but I figure I'll have plenty of opportunities to be chivalrous later.

The stairs lead us to the second floor, to the chess tables. I remind myself that I don't know if you suspect anything or not. As I set up the chess tables, I move the chess board around. My reasons?

"I'm getting bad vibes from this one", I say.

I mean, the table I pick is going to be significant. The table I choose is the table where I confess two years of stored up feelings. This is going to be the table. But, I end up choosing the one with the working lamp. A choice made from practicality.

We start playing chess, and it's a good game. We sip our drinks, and I ponder as to when the most advantageous time to tell you would be. I figure that if I tell you when I'm losing, I can disrupt your playing, and judge your reaction from looking at how you move your pieces. Unfortunately, I win the game without this opportune moment.

Desperate to tell you, I ask you for another game, and consequently another chance to let my secret out.

You glance down at your watch and I start to feel nervous. What if you have to get home soon? What if I'm not able to tell you?

Every Friday night, the coffee shop has a live band come in to play for a few hours. It happens to be a Friday night, and the band walks through the door. They plug their worn instruments into the jumbled stack of amps and other sound equipment. "Check, check, check", one says as the others tune their guitars.

You look up from your watch and, somehow sensing the direction of my plot, accept my request to play another game. A little bit of relief sets in, but it's not enough to keep me from showing signs of nervousness. I set up the board with my shaking hands, some of the pieces fall over. My mind is racing for words. I find them at the end of the game.

As I sweep my remaining arm off of the monochrome battlefield, I say,

"To tell you the truth, a big reason why I invited you here today was so that I could tell you that I love you."

Your eyes start to water and become reflective in the yellow lamplight. Uneasily and anxiously, not really knowing what to fill the dead airspace with, I bluntly state,

"Now I guess I have to judge your reaction."

Your eyes lock onto mine for a second or two. They search as if they are probing within me. They search, trying to see into what I'm really feeling. Your eyes, do they see my feelings?

You smile. I feel like fainting. You say, "I like you too."

And so it ends there. For the next few seconds after your reply, I feel dizzy, euphoric, but more dizzy. I can't believe it really happened. Just as planned. We talk about petty things afterwards. I go to the bathroom and as I walk out and greet you, I feel something new between us. It was in your eyes, must've been in mine too. Something, something was there to make me feel cared about.

Our walk to the car is filled with an awkward sort of conversation. We're both not used to this. I stutter and mutter, kicking around my words trying to get them out of my mouth intact. You laugh and talk fast.

We make it to the car, sitting in the seats as a closer pair than as we left. On the way back to your house, we both talk about our relationship status. Right then and there, we decide that it's time to label ourselves as a couple, and that we should lay down some preliminary guidelines. No kissing, yet. We should take it slow, yes. We're exclusive to each other now, no cheating. Absolutely, yes.

My hopes, dreams, the very system I have lived for. These things are affirmed now that we are a pair. The world comes together and my love becomes a justified affair. I drop you off and we are slightly changed people.

As you walk into your door, you turn around and wave goodbye to me. My head rushes with emotion. I get the urge to hold you in my arms and kiss you. But, I know there's a time for that, and we're both not ready for that time to be. It's an odd thing, it's a raw thing. Powerless I am in this complicated emotion, yet it somehow empowers me.

The sun goes down, and the sky is no longer speckled. Purple clouds meld together in a broth of darkness. Another great day ends.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I admit it. I read the whole thing. Is that weird?

-Ryan
A little bit. It's one of my longer posts.

Longer posts...? Heck, it could've been a book. ;-)

-Alex

So that makes 3 currently (besides the author) who are now added to the "creepy people who read long blog posts" lists.

-Josh

ps. Who knew Ryo was such a romantic. You're rivaling Shakespeare.

Yeah, I know, I'm not resisting this one.

Awwwwww.

-Josh

I'm gonna say Awwwwwwwwww just because it seems to be a fad.

As for that, that was an amazing piece of real-life turned into lit. I never knew your life was that capable of being turned into a non-boring read. (not that any of your posts are boring).

I think you might be able to rival Shakespeare, but don't start thinking you're gonna hold a candle to Dante or (have to incorporate music) Bach.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I was complaining to Ryan at the pool today. Complaining about how I have to go to the State Fair tomorrow with the Robotics team, thus missing a day of school.

When I do anything, I must visualize myself doing it first. Without visualizing it enough, I get frustrated, confused, and disoriented. I'm someone who likes for everything to follow a script. Even when I show even a hint of spontaneity, it's simulated. They are planned out somewhere in advance, in my head somewhere, even if I don't know it. I have to do familiar things.

So, when Logan called me up and told me that I would be missing the school day tomorrow, I got a little frustrated. For me to get comfortably adjusted with missing a whole day of school would have taken a few days of visualization. A few days to accept the fact that I'll be doing something uncomfortable and unpleasant, making a sacrifice for something I am involved in. I mean, a whole day is a lot to me. Seven classes of work to make up when I get back. Seven individual classes, each with seven different families of possible handouts, projects, essays, tests, labs, you name it. And to have to familiarize myself with that in a matter of hours.

It is, how do you say... difficult.

People have been talking about challenges all day. How these classes will be challenging, how it isn't going to be like last year. Well, I guess juggling Robotics into my life will be one of those big challenges. I must like suffering. That's it.

But, it's a program that I don't want to die. I feel like I'm sort of a big part of it now, and I don't want to contribute to its failure. I spent too much time last year on this thing for it to all fall apart this year. It's life changing. I'll take the responsibility and take the unpleasantness of missing a day of school, if only to help contribute to the secure future of Robotics at William Henry Harrison High School. And if it does end up falling apart, then so be it. I'll walk away with no guilt knowing that I tried my best.

I'll be waking up nice and early tomorrow to go to Indianapolis. I'll be coming home nice and late tomorrow as well, at around sunset. It's a full day occasion, I'm assuming.

And I guess it's a great way to start up a challenging school year.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I rediscovered the wonders of compressing files today. I'm so glad there is free software that gets the job done. Thank you 7-zip! [LINK]

Anyways, the State Fair was all fine and dandy, and from what everyone tells me, I'll be able to catch up easily. I've got lots of photos (one of the main reasons I went), and I happened to be elected (unofficially) as the IT Captain of the team. I don't know how that'll play out, but it isn't much of an accomplishment since we have so few people on the team itself (there were three captain positions and four willing candidates). Whatever happens, I'll probably end up doing the newsletter and a big part of the animation this year. I would like to re-emphasize the importance of recruiting more members this year.

My computer is humming and making loud noises due to how CPU-intensive ultra compressing a file is.

I'm not going to write more because my computer may crash any second now.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Today was the fated day of make-up work.

I wasn't given too much work, but here I am, the clock is ticking closer to my sleep deadline. I've still got a few pages of things to do. I'm so slow at doing work because I'm just not fast in doing anything.

I'm not fast at math, I'm not fast at housework, I'm not fast at reading, I'm not even fast at driving. I've gone through this charade before, and I've explained many times why it's so frustrating to always be in last place, but I can't let myself become concerned with those things anymore. I'm slow at writing too. It takes me thirty minutes to type out a medium-sized email. This poorly-written, small post will end up taking up half an hour to type as well. I just keep typing, keep deleting. Nothing is ever good enough. And it doesn't matter in the end, because nothing good ever comes out of my writing. I'm beginning to heavily regret joining the newspaper team at school. I have no idea why the journalism teacher thinks I'm a good writer. I hate it. I hate being thought of as someone who I'm not. I'm sick of it.

I felt sick all day.

The weekend is going to come, and everything will be better. That's it. I'll just wait for the weekend to come and rescue me. If it doesn't, I don't know what I'll do.

It's my eleventh year of school and I'm still so confused.

The programming teacher was talking about how Japanese students are conditioned to perform at a higher standard. When she said that, Devin said something about me and how I prove stereotypes right, or something like that.

I just wanted to strangle everybody and tell them that I'm not any fucking better at math than anyone else. I just wanted to do all these horrible things to myself and the people around me. My anger, this passionate emotion that I thought was gone. What was I thinking, it's never gone. But, I just want to forget about it now. It'll all go away eventually.

There are so many great things in my life to balance these negative points out. I'm very grateful for knowing all of the people I know. I just prefer writing about the bad things, so they'll end up on here and not in my head.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Refreshing my email over and over...

It's like seeing if it's Christmas Day yet. Glancing at the alarm clock beside the bed over and over...

I don't know why I'm up so late. I've got to get to sleep and stop dashing my sleep schedule to pieces. It'll take me through Tuesday to reset now. I'm not too enthusiastic about that. Good night.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I am on The Eagle, and we have landed on the moon! The cost is clear. BLAST! A space man or a alian left a mesege in a frame. An alian just blue a crater! Hey armstrong armstrong armmmstrooong were are you. Are you tricking me. Help me armstrong! Uh hey hey someone spray panted me! Hleo erth-ling pleas come with me. Hear is the menew. We have goop worms and dust fimgers our best! If you want any thing tell me erth-ling. Ew I hate goop worms! Well I gess I coud try goop worms and dust fingers. Ummm yumm goop worms are good and dust fingers are good too. To day is spring. Lets go out side. Do you nowe a person called arm strong. What is a person? A person is a erth-ling you dumb alian! No! I don't nowe any erth-ling but you! But I have an erth-ling that is hyper slyping. I found him split on the ground! You want to see him. Yes! When did see him last spring. Can you free him. Yes! Then free him! here is your Erth-ling! Lets get out of here. Blast! We are returning to mother ship! Yay! We made it!-journal entry dated 10/7/98 by Ryo

I found an old composition book sitting on the back of my bookshelf. In elementary school, I was prompted by my teachers to write various things to help me with my reading and writing skills. Every week, there would be some sort of theme. The passage above was from a "write your own story" themed writing day. Reading these words from back then opens little niches of memory in my mind. There are entries about building a backyard pool at my old house, dreams of flying, science experiments done in class, and about my self image. Many entries are just absurd stories that I made up, stories where I mixed up everything I saw in television shows (commercials too) and regurgitated all of it into one big, nonsensical mess of text. That's how a lot of kids do "creative writing", I suppose.

But, half of the old comp notebook is empty. That bothers me. Pages are worthless without writing.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: Emergency. Studying hard for test tomorrow with a book I don't have. Not good. It's late. I don't think school ever rewarded a single student for sleeping. I'll take that notion to heart tonight. I feel a little sick from knowing that I'm in a tight situation that I put myself in. I feel a little sicker because I've lost a book and need to find it soon.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Finished by 9PM, and that's something worth celebrating. Things move fast and slow. The plastic fan turns fast, but when I collapsed on the floor in my room, nothing, not even the fan, seemed to move fast. In my room the air is hot and humid.

All day, all I've been able to think about is myself. Selfish thoughts. But, I kept them in. I'm glad I kept them in.

Because you know what? It's one thing to complain about something. And it's another to change one's self to accomplish something.

The situations I put myself in today are difficult to navigate through for me. I have lost three school books in the past couple of days. My inability to keep track of things has cost me money, time, stress. It's cost me minutes of talking to my friends, hours of paying attention in class, and days of mental integrity. The worst part of losing things is the feeling of helplessness. The books are somewhere. They exist in this world, they are a specific distance away from me. If I knew where they were, my problems would end there.

But, I don't know. I don't know where they are.

I can't reach out and find them. I can't work hard and plead to some higher power and find them. There isn't a thing I can do to solve this problem. And it's a frustrating and irritating thing to be so helpless.

Math class.

Things snowballed. My mind took a gripe and attached it to another one. I miss a question on the homework. I don't know why, but it seemed like a very important event. A very bad event. More gripes started latching on. A big ball of anger, resentment, rage, denial, gloomy depression. "Go away, stop it all", I think to myself, and with the suicidal thoughts the desk gets smaller and I see less and less of what's going on in front of my own eyes.

What are you thinking? Stop it.

Can't. Really can't stop... More and more. These stupid things. They don't go away. And the more you think about them the more they bite back. I keep writing on my paper...

"Please calm down. Please calm down. It's all stupid, you are too. Deal with it."

And it gets worse and worse. I look at the board. The numbers, oh. Numbers can't help me now, they're my enemy. A bad grade here and there becomes a bad grade everywhere. It becomes a giant bad grade that follows me around all day. It pushes me toward the wall. Scream. I want to scream at it. Or tell someone about the giant thing that keeps making me feel unhappy.

But, I can't. I don't. I will. I did. Is it wrong for me to?

To keep it inside is the best thing for everyone. Because it's stupid to say something like that. It wouldn't make any sense to a rational person. How could I put such importance on these insignificant things? Tell me. See, you are rational. You have no answer. There is no answer.

I ask myself these questions. I can't answer them. I want these questions to not be asked. I want to cure it all. Be normal again. And it'll take awhile. A few hours, maybe. And I'll be back being zippy.

And why? I don't understand.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Newspaper class is an adventure. Journalism is the art of retelling a story using as few words as possible. To be concise, accurate, and easy to read. It makes sense. With all the millions of individual sheets of newspaper being printed on every day, every extra word is amplified to a problem. No one likes to waste ink. Dumb readers will get confused, newspaper businessmen lose money, and the editor has to work a little more. But, it's hard for me to think this way.

There are things that must be explained, but the laws of journalism won't let them be. Concepts and ideas must be simplified to the bare roots, and then some more. Quotes have to get thrown away and details are lost in the constant battle to ballast another word or two. Right now, the idea of adhering to these restrictions is overwhelming. Sure, I type here every day, but that doesn't mean I'm a journalist. My sentences drag on, they're awkward. I focus on the details and lose the big picture sometimes. I screw up the sentence structures, put commas in inappropriate places, try to add emotion to what I write.

But, journalism isn't about that. It's about strangling the emotion from a story until all that's left is a pale, unmoving carcass to paste on another bland newspaper layout. It's about collecting and compiling information from the environment. It's about para-para-paraphrasing.

I can't see how I'll enjoy writing for the newspaper and I don't see how I was naive and stupid enough to ever believe that I would see newspaper class in a positive light.

I guess it's just another challenge to take to the bank.

The sun is setting and I'm done with my homework, so I'm happy with the progress. I don't want to admit it, but when I got stuck in something in my homework, I turned on my radio and started hitting my pillow with a book. I hit my head on my desk a few times, then went back to work. I'd have to say that it didn't help.

I've got to find a way to disperse my stress. Who knows if it's eustress or distress? Really, where is the distinction made?! Whatever the case, it's keeping me from doing things efficiently. Keeping me from living how I want to live. Sometimes writing just isn't enough.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My mind is hazy. A thick fog, so thick that if you swished your hand through it, on your hand would be little droplets of water. It's not a light haze. Tired. I felt sick this morning. That usually happens when I don't get enough sleep. The duration and severity of my illness is directly related to how little I slept the night before.

I walked into school with an uncomfortable stomach. I have so many memories of feeling like this in French class. I've had French class in the morning too many times for my liking. The class is like a light switch. It's either really taxing, or "story time". On or off. Opening the door and collapsing into class, I hoped that I would get better soon.

Luckily, I did. By second period, fifty minutes later, I felt better. Apparently, my sleep debt isn't too big. I might be able to catch up this coming weekend.

Why do I say that? I know that I sleep less on the weekend by default. False hope, anybody?

I should stop thinking about my newspaper articles. I have this anxiety. My journalism teacher makes me nervous. Just like I described the articles, she's overwhelming.

Or maybe it's the topics I'm writing about. For the first three newspaper articles due next week, I'm doing two on gaming. I was never much of a gamer. I just put the article ideas on the brainstorming board, and they never came down, so my name got slapped on them and now they're my problem. I stopped being up to date on games a month or two after the last generation of consoles (GC, Xbox, PS2) came out. Maybe a few months earlier or later. If you're really curious, why don't you check out my archives?

Tiffany got frustrated on her Physics homework, and I walked away from her to get information for a possible interview for one of my articles. I realized my mistake when a few people from the table brought the matter to my attention.

I felt guilty the whole rest of the day. Couldn't stop thinking,

"I don't deserve her. Can't understand. Why does she like stupid, pathetic me? They're so many people better than me. I just don't deserve her."

I couldn't even express my genuine apology to her. I'm just... everything that touches me, every word that comes out of my mouth, every sentence I write, every vocabulary term I learn, seems to just wither and die. The person who I wanted to interview gave me a fake phone number. I guess I can't even interview people for my fucking articles. I made a mistake, and then a mistake within the mistake, and then a few mistakes trying to correct the first mistake.

Everything is so hazy. Just have to make it to tomorrow, then to Friday.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It's fine. Really. You deserve me. You more than deserve me.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I don't like mood swings. I don't like myself.

I'm not going to rant on about how or why I felt bad after school. You don't want to hear it, I don't want to hear it. It's stupid. I'm over it.

But, what happened was I was walking out of school, walking to my van. Andrew and Rachel notice that I'm distressed. They try to help me. I throw my keys in the air and sulk away. They try to help me. I get in my van and turn the ignition. The engine starts to hum. Rachel refuses to shut the door. She's trying to help me. I floor it. Rachel hangs on to the door. She's trying to help me. I'm hitting 35mph in the parking lot, heading toward a chainlink fence. Too fast. I'm being irrational. I slow down and Rachel finally gets off. She was trying to help me. I drive away angry, sad, then ashamed.

And they were just trying to help me. They're great people, great friends, people who actually care, people I admire and want to someday live up to. And what do I do in return? I'm angry, sad, stupid, and irrational. I do something very dangerous, putting her at risk because of my feelings that have nothing to do with her. I hate myself for it.

I've got to look back on this and change. I'll never get anywhere if I don't.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I don't like my keyboard. I don't think it types too well. The keyboards at school feel more responsive. Softer and more refined. The one I'm using is an old keyboard that came from a budget '02 Dell system. It feels like I'm hacking away words with rough and sticky clicks.

Anyways, there are horrible days, decent days, and very good days. Today was a very good day. It's one of those days I always wish for, I dream for. I'm so grateful that as I think back on my day, I don't remember a single thing that went wrong. Classes trotted by at a pleasurable speed. Not too fast, not too slow. I was in a positive mood, didn't have any social crises. Interviewed two people, which was great. I finally have material to build from. I don't feel helpless anymore. I also found four of the books I've been missing. This is a very amazing thing.

After school, Ryan and I were finishing our French homework when his dad suggested that we go to the football game. Not being much of a sports person, I brushed the idea off. But, after a few minutes I realized something. By six, we were off to pick Tiffany up.

Her eyes, her voice, her smile. As Ryan was driving Tiffany and me to the football game, I felt much too lucky to be relaxed. It took us all a while to get around town. She lives on the other side of town, but was it worth it. When she holds my hand and looks at me that way, I want to flash freeze that moment and keep it forever. They have no price, these are the moments that I will treasure in the future as memories. Going to the football game was worth it. I think I'm almost fully adjusted to being completely open to the status of our relationship. At first, it was awkward to talk about how we're dating. Now, I've come to know that embracing the fact is easier than it seems. It's how it happened. I can't control love. I sure am glad how everything turned out though.

I look in my backpack and realize that I'm missing two books. The loss don't seem so unpleasant after all the positive things that happened today. I'm worried yes, but I'll solve my own problems. After all, what are books but dead trees?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I'll conform. I'll jump across the fence to the mad hell that I've been a staunch opponent of for years and years. The fence that has held me safe from the efficiency-sucking, evil powers. Yup, I've gone and done it.

I've dived into the giant social networking pool, Myspace. Please don't vomit.

After a few hours, I realized how stupid it is to scroll through an eight page list of "friends" to find people whom I want to designate as my friends. I think the whole "label people as your friends" concept just devalues the meaning of friendship. I mean, on the Internet, there is no such designation as "acquaintance" or "friendly classmate", or "what's his face", so usually all of these are clumped together with one's close friends to make a mega-super-ultra listing of all of the people who you are even remotely associated with. Even that old Jewish lady who was in front of you at the self-checkout lane last saturday.

Some of the "profiles" end up being giant billboards where my peers flaunt their popularity, coolness, or unconformity. Actually, most of the profiles end up being giant, gaudy billboards. The place is a big melting pot of inflated egos, emotionally unstable people, and technologically challenged ass clowns.

So, why did I join?

That's a good question. It was a combination of "I want to be a somebody", "My girlfriend uses it", and "Maybe if I make one, then a few more people might discover this blog."

Whatever the case, I'm now officially "in".

I wasted about four hours roaming around the myspace hellhole, so now I'm not justified in complaining about how busy I am. So shut me up if I do. I hate it when I'm a liar.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Teehee....this is so funny.

I think I mentioned that.

On your MySpace.

Teehee.....still funny.
You are right. Word "friends" and false feeling of a unity annoy.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The evenings are slowly getting darker, and I'm enjoying it.

I actually feel like I can go to sleep at 9pm now. The dark blue sky is reassuring. Telling me that tomorrow's Monday won't be as bad as last Monday. Poking through the window panel to inform me that it's time to be in bed. It's time to be asleep. In a few minutes, the purple clouds will look spectacularly dull. So simple, but fantastic all at the same time. They are puffs of sleepy colors.

The air is colder and fall is closer. It's around the end of August, and so soon the trees will morph into vessels of playful, brightly-painted leaves. The colors will reach a climax, then quickly die down, falling to the ground to turn gray with the coming winter. Winter shall be the same. Snow, ice.

Cold, cold nights with the electric heater sputtering what heat it can muster. The lamps will feel better then. Finally, spring will arrive and with spring will come insects and green life. Spring will be a happy time, a sad time, an angry time. No season is ever one thing for an instant. Then the heat of summer.

By the time I'll know it, I will be sitting here, writing the same words, one year later. I might be typing about something that happened at school. Maybe about what I was thinking about. An event, or an idea. Many complaints. And I'll be sitting in front of the same wooden desk, looking at the same worn computer screen, and listening to the same static-plagued radio station.

Things will change in time. I don't know how they will, but I can't have my room forever. There's a world out there that I haven't even touched. I'll get there eventually.

And when it's all over, I don't know what I'll think to myself. I don't know what I'll think about all of these seasons, all of these words. Rows and rows of people I have and haven't met. Strings of choices, good and bad. Objects that will have survived the wear of time, relics from a past that was my present. And a familiar tune that plays from my stereo as I type this sentence.

Sundays are thought provoking.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I'm amazed at how much time I spend in my room now.

I remember when I debated selling everything in my room because I never went into it, except to sleep. Now I get home, drag by backpack to my room, close the door, and do homework and non-homework until about 8:30pm when I come out to eat food and take a shower. After the shower, I'm back in my room. The power of my room is that it's located on the second floor, which my family rarely ventures up to. Thus, no distractions. There's silence when I want there to be silence, loud music when I want there to be loud music. I control my room.

I get really confused about what people say sometimes. I was talking to Andrew about the events surrounding the football game and what he said confused me. But, I guess he transcends normal action. Goes beyond what I can even imagine. Don't get him occasionally, but he can talk to me with his eyes. A valuable tool in times of dire need.

Red dots all over my hand. Presumably from a covert insect that has been harassing me. There must be one in my room, but I've never seen any. It bothers me. Because when I start thinking about it, I start to think of spiders in my bed, and when I start to think of spiders in my bed, I don't want to get near my bed anymore.

Tomorrow, I get to go to the movies with Ryan and Tiffany. It's something I'm looking forward to. Greatly.

It'll offset the negative feelings going through my head after I take my French test first thing in the morning.

I never study enough for those things. They are very difficult tests for me.

Well, I'm off to venture out of my room to eat food. To escape this dungeon of homework and writing and studying and more homework.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I've got this nervous habit of pulling out my hair when I get frustrated or anxious. I'm afraid that my bald spot is growing. Although I cannot see it, I'm sure that the stresses of school have resulted in more hair loss than I care for. It's me. I see things differently every day. I always say that there are bad days, and that there are good days. The same event can seem like a catastrophe on one day, and a minor inconvenience on another.

That's the issue with my sense of reality. My physics teacher gave the class the "life assignment" of talking "real". But, what is real? Reality changes from person to person, and it's virtually impossible to obtain and analyze correctly a given scenario. If you're going to tell someone the truth, then you have to be sure what the truth is. The world is one where everyone's reality is different, where conflicts arise from many conflicting "truths". So, what does it mean to "be real"?

To tell the truth about my deepest feelings wouldn't do much use, but it's the only "truth" I've got besides math. Everything else I can think of is biased in one way or another. I don't know how other people feel, I don't know how other people think. And what is reality but how our simple minds interpret five simple senses? Maybe he's telling us to not talk at all, because silence is awfully truthful sometimes.

But, it's none of my business to rant on about something abstract like that.

Less hair will be pulled out in the coming days though, hopefully. This week seems like it's rolling pretty well. The movies went great, I won't elaborate on my feelings, but as always they were there. It's amazing, and I feel very lucky and content for the events and people who surround my life.

I'll end it here for today. I've got composition books to write in. Good night.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
What is success?

Is it self-worth? Or power and respect? Perhaps it's money and material wealth?

It's a lot of things to different people, but I don't know what it means for me. I would enjoy many of these things that I mentioned above, but I could go without them too. And if I never got any of these things, I wouldn't kill myself over it. I don't know what I'm working for, why I'm doing the homework, to get the grades, to put on paper, to send to college, to study for exams, to get an education, to apply for a job, to enter a career, to make money, to retire from, to spend in my later, to have a leisurely elderly life, to live happily ever after, to die.

To die.

To die.

To die is what I'm working for?

No, no. That can't be it. Then, what am I aiming towards? What's my net goal? And when I get there, what do I do? These sequence of events, they're what life is, and it bothers me.

Doesn't it bother you that your existence, my existence, our existences are so simple? That we are so insignificant by ourselves? That pain we go through every day is for an individual goal that will probably never be accomplished and a common goal that every single person is attached to?

And the objects that I hold in my hand. A pencil, a keyboard, a telephone. They're made by people thousands of miles away and across an ocean. They are so far away, but they're people too, right? And what about their goals? Is their goal to make pencils so foreign people in a faraway land can sharpen them? Do they make our computers so we can throw them away in a few years? Thousands of them, they're all the same. An enormous mass of generic individuals, ready to sacrifice many years of their lives. They are the same. Yet, each one is different. Each is a brother, sister, uncle, father, mother. Each has individual passions, talents, and philosophies. But, do they make a difference individually? If one disappeared one day, would the world stop for one life?

We sit here and complaisantly read each others blog posts while buildings fall. While warm, lively, healthy human bodies are shredded by little metal spheres. They die because they were born in an unfortunate land. When they die, do they make a difference? Do their lives really matter?

If I die and you die too, who will remember us in twenty years? A hundred years? A thousand?

If I die and you die too, what would we have done to make us worth our time alive?

If I die and you die too, will these questions be answered?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Research Jean-Paul Sartre. He has the answers.
yo killin me!

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I need to get to sleep now, so when I don't sleep this weekend the shock on 
Tuesday won't be as difficult to get through. Good night.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My physics teacher does "life challenges", and I think they're neat. I don't care much for the extra credit as much as I do about what new topic he'll cover each week. Today, he said that for the next week we have to figure out ten things we're grateful for. It'll be easy, I'm grateful for a lot of things, some more than others. I'm curious to see what would happen if I seached my blog for "grateful". Hmm...

But besides that, I went to Buffalo Wild Wings with all the QuizBowl people. It was a nice gathering, and Andrew and I got to talk some.

What was most striking to me about the whole trip was that I was driving three younger kids home. As I weaved through the dashed lines that crissed and crossed the midnight pavement, a wave of emotion came over me.

I'm old.

Instead of mooching rides off of other people, now I'm giving rides to those who need them. And I felt proud and a little fearful. For what if I crashed? It's a responsibility not to be taken lightly. Proud because finally I was able to serve others for the better. I felt exclusive, experienced, important. Those three younger friends of mine depended on me to get home. And I was directly related to their ability to get home. And to think, someone depending on me?

It's a change.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I wasn't able to post last night because I fell asleep at 6pm and didn't wake up until the next morning. I wasn't able to write in any of my journals either, and for that I am in regret.

What are my words worth anyway? For how many people read them, they're worthless. Some are worth more than others, yes. But, on average they are worth nothing. It's a matter of time-put-in vs. time-spent-read. It takes me fractions of a second to type each word, and some of them aren't read anyway. It makes me want to clean up this mess of text and do something worthwhile with my time. But, hey, I have to remind myself often. I have to remind myself now. I'm doing this only for myself. It helps me get rid of stress. That's all.

And so I'm making animation CD's for my robotics team. They're filled up to the brim (687MB out of 700MB) with animation .exe files, .blend files, .avi files, and .html files. Lots and lots of files to help the budding animator. The people on the team think I know so much. Truthfully, I've barely scratched the surface in my attempt to learn animation. I haven't mastered nodes, am still a very poor character animator, and should really learn 3ds Max. I don't like it when people think that I'm more than who I am. It makes me feel fake and plastic. I want to be a living, breathing, real person.

Spent this morning making video tutorials. After listening to them, I realized how different sounding I am than what I hear in my head. The voice coming to the computer was familiar, but I couldn't see how it was me. I had Ryan come over and listen to the sound clip and he told me that it was a very accurate recording. It's odd to me how this foreign voice is the voice that I send to my friends and other people through my mouth.

I had fun at Best Buy pretending to not know English. My nationality makes it especially easy to do this. I got a few weird glances, but otherwise, I found out that most Americans are polite to their foreign neighbors.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I love it when there's so many things to do.

Everything swirls around and comes together in the end as a coherent framework. A list of tasks becomes a mesh of activity, a long sequence of work and play. And it doesn't matter what it pertains to. Robotics, school, personal income. It's all good, it's all productive. Keeping me from vegetating in front of digg.com or CNN Headline News. It's a good thing to be active. Keeps my mind distracted and happy.

Today was my last day of working at the pool. The last day was a cheery one. A cloudy sky resulted in an empty pool. I like it when nobody comes to the pool, I feel free to act like myself, instead of some mindless pool-droid intent on collecting guest fees and keeping kids under 14 out of the spa. And when it's cloudy, the air is cool. Perfect weather to sit in the hot tub and wantonly flick water into the air. It's the best when it rains.

But, here I am. Pool job is over. Another sign that the seasons are changing. I like fall though. I like the lowering of the temperature. It makes my life much more comfortable. In the fall, my room is no longer an oven.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I do not want to get a cold. Please, cold, listen to me.

Especially now. Please don't get worse, cold. I talk to you because I know that if you hear me out, you'll understand why it's a reasonable request for you to infect someone else. You see, I thought I was going to have a good week until now, my friend. If you get worse inside of me, I'll have to worry about carrying so much more. Tissues, cough drops, medicine, etc. If you get worse, then I'll have to worry about contacting other human beings. I have to be careful about what I touch. And if you get worse, then I don't know what I'll do besides cough and snivel and wait a week or two until you go away.

I can't do homework quickly with your headaches in my head. I can't write those essay questions at school, or effectively participate in lively discussions about the role of chinese literature in the modern automobile industry. I can't do a lot of things with you, cold. So I think right now would be a good time for you and I to part. Maybe forever.

I know you like to be with me, you've been with me since the beginning. But, can't you see it in your heart to let me be as I am for the time being? In a month or two maybe, when it's winter and everyone's sick. But, not now. I've got articles to write and pictures to take and skits to prepare and prelabs to write. You've got to see that it's in both of our best interests if you just jump ship and use someone else as a host. I'm not that great of a host anyways. I don't really get out much, I have little skin-to-skin human contact, I like to use antibacterial soap. So, I'm definitely a sub-par choice for sickening.

It's only the beginning, I'm feeling your presence, but I'm not sick enough to have any obvious symptoms. You'll be here tomorrow, unless these words convince you to die.

And in reality, I'm not telling you to just go away.

I'll be blunt then. I'm telling you to die. Die inside of my body right now. Feel the wrath of my immune system, bitch. Fuck viruses and fuck common colds. You're going to hell, cold virus. There just isn't a place for you up here, you know that, don't you? So there, those are your orders. Submit to my commands.

Please?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My head is all crooked and fuzzy.

And I don't know what to do anymore, and I don't know what to do anymore.

My nose is running and the world is spinning.

And I don't know what to do anymore, and I don't know what to do anymore.

And I ask myself, "How am I going to get myself out of this illness?"

The answer is to wait. Wait for it to die on its own, to live out its lifespan, to wait and hope that there will be a day in the future when I'm not sick, when I do feel enthusiastic about waking up in the morning. Hoping, with a simple kind of hope that is like an old pair of shoes. The same hope that I've been using for years and years. The hope that resides in my mind. It pushes, it moves mountains. An ethereal being that lives on through repeated beatings. Repeated failures. Repeated circumstances, and repeated self-hate. It is a gem that refuses to be cut, to conform to my feelings. This hope resides safely, protected by itself, by its very nature to be present in all mankind. Hope.

And waiting. Lots of waiting for the cold to die away and leave me be. To let me live the rest of my life without a headache. Let the pressures in my head come from other things, not a trivial physical malady. To push on with the hope, and to wait patiently with the power to overcome stronger than the urge to give up.

Moving forward. Sick. Physics tests. Glass doors. Blue plastic lunch tray. Got to get through. Got to get through. Chemistry book. A wrong answer. Embarrassment. Got to persist. Must move forward. Test. Minutes pass. Questions unanswered. Failure. Must get through. Push, push, push. No looking back, there is no past that can be rewritten. Move now, comply to the standards of time and existence.

I got home. And that's all I needed to do for today. One foot in front of the other.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Always, with the talk about the time. What time is it? And I really don't know because it's always changing. In my eyes, it's speeding by too quickly to talk about. In someone else's, it may be plodding along. And our interpretation of time can be so different. But, yesterday night seems like a few minutes ago. I find it hard to believe that it's already Thursday, the day before Friday.

Friday

The day I've been waiting for for the past five days. Because you start swerving if you don't look far enough on the road. Goals. My QuizBowl coach posed the question, "What is your goal for this year?" on a paper notecard (to be filled out for information purposes). I really couldn't come up with a singular goal for this year. I don't even know where I'm heading. There are tasks, sure, but my only goals at the moment are getting through these tasks. One step at a time. Goals like :"Getting to Friday." come into mind.

But, on the card I wrote, "None. Philosophy: Go with the flow".

I'm still not sure if that's true or not, but that was the only statement I could think of that would satisfy the prompt.

I can't think right now. My pencil is yellow and black. I can feel the little grooves between my teeth with my tongue. Blah. I really can't think about my thoughts today. Memory. It's just. It's going away. Sleepless nights lead to fatigue. Does it come from an ordinary schoolweek? No, it comes from me. It's my fault. Gah! I'm pulling my hair out thinking about how stupified I am right now. STUPID STUPID STUPID. I can't think. Work, tasks, just too many.... things. They're all there, all at once. And I can't see any of them clearly. Blurry. Primitive. I'm seriously not able to comprehend these things that are being asked of me. My senses. All not coming thoroshgoadn fofofoofoooo

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Didn't write yesterday in any of my journals. After arriving home just before midnight, I had barely enough energy to climb the stairs to my room. After struggling up the stairs, I wrote an email to Tiffany and promptly fell asleep. The weekend is a much needed shelter from the hurries and stress of school. Just a time to sit in front of a fan and listen to light jazz while reading a magazine, or watching the sky.

There's a time in any illness where one comes to accept the symptoms. I've already forgotten what it feels like to be without this these annoying headaches and other things that have plagued me all this week. I'm in the mid-to-latter stage of being sick, so I expect to be cured by the end of this week. That is if I keep my fatigue in check.

The football game on friday was very fun. Lots of friends, peers, a few teachers. Most were amicable. Those hours were, again, what I was looking forward to all week. Being with Tiffany without the constricting atmosphere of school felt absolutely great. Although, as all school-related events are, there was still a hint of awkwardness floating around the field.

I think I'm doing well in terms of reducing this awkwardness in myself. I'm always trying to stop being so self-conscious about expressing the existence of the relationship. It's easier to do now, I mean, I held her hand in front of teachers (unthinkable just a few months ago). Is it proof that I'm getting better?

At the football game, I realized how many people I know. It's a social event, so of course there are going to be loads of people. But, why do they all know me? Why would they want to? Tiffany commented on being known from association now that we're together and it made me think about my social situation. Think about all the pros and cons of this social status.

Well, it's late, and the weekend is for sleep. So, I'm off to sleep.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: Watching 40 Year Old Virgin with Ryan helped curb my boredom today. It was all a thoroughly relaxing experience. Thanks to today, my cold is almost gone. To think, a week's worth of recovery with stress can't match the power of one day of recovery with no stress. It all ends in an hour though, when I'll go to sleep early in anticipation for the next five days of push, push, push. I'm fine with that though. There have to be uncomfortable times, lots of them, to make one value comfort.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I go to sleep early. I wake up by myself twenty minutes earlier than I do with my alarm clock. Then the rest of my day turns out to be more comfortable than usual. Work doesn't seem as hard. Problems don't feel so hard to solve. The school just looks plain friendlier. There are still frustrating points, yes, but overall things flowed well today. But, it always seems when I'm having a positive experience, everyone else is angry, hurt, or some other mystifying emotion that I can't seem to understand (yes, the last emotion is a reference to you, Andrew Pfaff).

My way, I took the day and did it my way. Not the way that just happens, but my way. I threshed and molded and seized the day. I didn't get anything significant done, I made a stupid error in math, I forgot E=mc^2, but hey, all those things don't matter. Nothing matters, and that's the kind of day I like. When I look at all the little conflicts in my life and crumple them up. Throw them away. Just to realize that these problems are insignificant... It takes a lot of pressure off. I like it.

Twitched. I twitched when my French teacher mentioned the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Centers. Because I knew that she would start talking about how we felt on that day, and the days afterward. One-by-one, my peers answered with their stories of how they were afraid, how they felt angry, how they locked themselves in their rooms and cried, etc. I didn't say anything. Didn't say anything because I would probably offend someone. People are always angry when others don't think like them. I've accepted that and become quieter when public discussion of such emotionally volatile subjects are discussed.

That week after those towers fell down, then the months afterward, I just wondered, "Why is it still on television, why are still hearing about all of this, and why are those terrorist attack victims suddenly heroes?". They happened to be in a bad place at a bad time. Hundreds of people die from car accidents because they were at the wrong place at the wrong time. None of them are heroes. Circumstance. The people who performed acts of courage in times of dire need were brave, courageous. But, enough to be called a hero? What is a hero anyways? If I die by chance in some one-of-a-kind terrorist extravaganza, then am I a hero?

Before lunch, there was a special announcement on the school televisions to remind us of the WTC attacks. After watching the poorly made slideshow of the buildings exploding, there was a long awkward silence with a sans-serif font message on the television. No sound. Nothing but text on the screen. The whole class is staring up at the television, time seems to drag on. The words on the screen read something like, "Remember September 11, 2001."

Absurd. I was about to explode in laughter from the absurdity of it all. I was biting through my lip, I'm sure I looked very inappropriate in a room full of somber, remorseful students. But, it's so absurd to me. Those who died being "honored" with a cheezy, poorly-made slideshow and awkward silence? I could have made that television presentation in five minutes with Windows Movie Maker. And if I died in those attacks, I sure wouldn't want my name to be honored with a seemingly endless silence. I felt like that was the stupidest, most pathetic excuse for a video memorial.

Just hours earlier, my peers were describing to me how they went to their rooms to cry after those attacks. Look at us now, all we're doing to honor those victims are creating bland slideshows.

Well, I bet there's logic to this. I just haven't got it yet. I don't understand a lot of things.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Apparently regional strife is part of my high school now. Due to a few people displaying various (Mexican, Confederate, Nazi, etc.) flags in or around the school, the showing of flags is banned. Makes sense, after all, what better to get all worked up about than patterns of color? For some reason, we put so much value into these simple rectangles of color. Red, white, and blue we must display up above, while white stars in red stripes against a blue background are taboo? And don't even start about the color green. That's too foreign. People argue and discuss about these "symbols", but who cares? Symbols are symbols, nothing more. So, I figure we should all forget about flags and move on with our lives. Wherever anyone comes from, whatever anyone believes in, we're all the same in the end. Breathing, moving, bleeding human beings.

We get worried and anxious about all sorts of meaningless things.

-Reuters

The President proves my point.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I watched clippings of A Goofy Movie this evening as I was brushing my teeth. I remember crying the first time I saw it. It was a heart-wrenching movie at the time of my viewing. It came out in 1995, and I remember it being new-ish when I saw it. Now, I have this odd sort of connection to the movie. I watch it and everything is the same. The plot, the character. Each frame is a landmark from my past.

Like so many other landmarks from my past.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
An imagined trail winds through the wall, and my desk cannot contain my thoughts. And I hear a voice behind my right ear. It's a whisper, quiet, urgent, saying my name. It repeats. Through the randomness of my thought, I journey. The beige concrete brick, lecturing English teacher, and dysfunctional projector are all powerless to the daydreaming that infests my midday.

She's talking, the lady at the front of the room. The teacher. She's nice, sure. Isn't there something more interesting to look at? The bulletin board is covered with uninteresting little paper people. Yellow construction paper stares back at me. My eyes part with that corner of the room. The image on the projector hasn't changed in the past ten minutes. A worksheet describing literary tools. Tone, word choice, sentence structure. They're just tools. Learning about tools to paint a picture with words. How bland. Picking apart sentences to understand the author's meaning. What a chore. She's talking. I'm not listening. My eyes track her face as she moves around the room. Artificial, purely mechanical movements, my eyes.

A departure begins. To another place far, far away from the classroom. Not visually. My thoughts are elsewhere even though I still stare mindlessly at the teacher, at the yellow cutouts of people. And the random thoughts whirl around, questions are asked, scenarios are posed. Nothing is answered, but thinking and imagining is much more appealing than listening to dreck about stylistic choices in literature. I hear nothing that is said in the classroom, I can am now completely isolated from reality. Dreaming, lusting to be in a perfect world without the complexities of the English language.

"And, Ryo, what do you think the writer does to make this writing effective?"

Core exposed. Rushing, rushing. Pounding, tightening, constricting adrenaline. Worry. Fear. Did she really say my name? The words from her mouth. They are foreign to me. I can not think of a response to her question. As I try to react to my situation, the class turns to look at me. I am instantly rendered useless. I act as if I am a vegetable.

"I, umm." (Silence) "don't. uhh... yeah."

She's not talking, the lady at the front of the room. The teacher. She's nice, sure. But, she sure is sharp. Caught smack-dab in the middle of daydreaming. The class moves on, and concepts are lectured about, notes taken, and papers shuffled.

Notebooks open and my studious peers copy examples off of the white board. I sit there and track my teacher with my eyes. How can she tell?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I don't know...but she did that to me too. Catching me offguard when I hadn't read the story. Luckily, I know enough from being a female that crying can be good for you sometimes.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I haven't updated in the past two days first because of a football game and then because of a trip to Chicago.

At the moment, I feel very stressed out because I've been working on things since 8 in the morning, and I haven't had any time to just sit down and breathe all day. I hate it when things get pushed back to the wall. I could have gotten it all over with on Saturday. I could have done things I wanted to today. Now I feel like the week has started before it had to. I just finished my chemistry homework, which was a pain. I'm angry right now. Want to kick something. Frustrated. I can't even write any stupid idiot things anymore. It all ends up being a mashed-together lump of crap that isn't worth showing to other people. And it's taking up my sleeping time.

Now this malfunctioning program won't post, so I have to take five minutes of my life to open up a web browser and post manually. Stupid. My words, they're all stupid and pointless. Stop reading this shit because I can't stop writing it.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: I feel sick. It comes from the gut. It feels like a "I haven't gotten enough rest" sicknesses. Have two English essays on my task list. I want to go to sleep for a week.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: Unbelievable, but there he was. For six hours he had toiled away in bed. The hot embers of illness burned a patch on his head, and he could no longer see. Breathing was a chore, and the air was either too hot or too cold. Hopeless, tired, the sweat formed beads on his skin, yet the bed felt chilly. Wandering around in his head was the notion that there would come a time when all of these pains and aches would go away. But, the day was hard still. The vague understanding never came to be, and again he was forced to suffer through the whole ordeal. Slowly, as civilizations crumble under the weight of time, darkness came. The nightmares were to continue.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
When I woke up this morning, I wondered what all the nonsense the day before was about. How could I feel so much better in a matter of a few hours?

But, I'm afriad that if I don't get more sleep, then the illness will come back to haunt me. It's already past the time that I agreed with myself that I would go to sleep at. I'm just making last minute preparations for tomorrow's robotics meeting, which will hopefully run smoothly.

I feel very busy!

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I have uncovered an interesting hole.

It all started out when zoomcell.com, a ordinary-looking online retailer with decent customer reviews, sent me a locked cell phone when I ordered an unlocked one. The software lock prevents me from using a cellular carrier other than Cingular. An unlock code (unique for each individual phone) was not sent with the phone.

Upon discovering that the phone was locked (by taking my mother's T-Mobile SIM card for a spin), I sent an email to Zoomcell requesting the unlock code for the new phone. I can't call them because they have no phone number listed on the website. On Friday, they sent me back an email saying:

"We have sent your IMEI to the unlocking DEPT who will respond with your code on monday, I am very very sorry for the mixup with your order!!"

So, the weekend passes and nothing out of the ordinary happens. Monday comes and goes, and my inbox is empty. Zoomcell doesn't send me any emails.

I figure that they may send it tomorrow, but the same thing happens on Tuesday. That night, I sent them an email demanding my unlock code.

Wednesday evening, I check my inbox and find nothing. I send another demanding email to Zoomcell. By this time, I'm getting very suspicious of this retailer. Their business address is Brooklyn, New York. This is where countless fly-by-night online operations are usually based. These sorts of stores net as many people as they can with their pseudo-professional (usually prepackaged) web design, get them to pay up, then run with the money.

Well, Zoomcell did send me my phone, so they are somewhat of a legitimate business, but they have not responded to my demands.

On Thursday, I searched the internet and dug up a phone number. I didn't have time to call it, so I called it a few minutes ago.

After the first ring, the answering machine message said, "We are upgrading our phone services, sorry for the inconvenience. Please contact us by email at info@zoomcell.com"

I don't give up.

So, I press the "0" key.

And lo' and behold, I get the customer service bot, which tells me that I can get ahold of them if I call them within business hours.

Intrigued, I search the internet some more to find an extention number for Zoomcell. A comment in some random forum mentions that the very vague-named "John" is available at extension "885".

I hit the phone and start dialing.

1-800-801-7591-0-885

Lo' and behold, it starts dialing "John", and it even plays the background "on hold" music while it tries to contact this person. Eventually, I even get to "John"'s voice mail.

I'll have fun tomorrow harassing them for not sending me an unlock code, whether they are "upgrading" their phone service or not.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I'd try getting through to them, and if you fail, call your credit card company and have their charge removed. Then, package the phone back up and return it to them. (If they are fly by night, then you'll most likely even get the phone back because it can't be delivered..)

Email your IMEI number to Supervisor@zoomcell.com and you will get your Unlock code promptly, We try to make sure that all items are delivered unlocked as they should be but unfortunatly mistakes do happen ocassionaly and we will work with the buyer to fix it.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Work hard, play hard.

Coming back at around midnight for the past two days has been worth stepping out of my stuffy room and enjoying my life. My after school, weekend life has changed significantly since last year. There's a constant supply of time periods in which it is ok to forget about homework, grades, and tests. And this distinct newness in my way of life, the slow deterioration of a boring routine, is something I treasure. Because, I don't know how long this'll last. When build season rolls around, or if another change comes about, what'll happen to this off-time?

The finishing-homework-on-sunday deal, which is entirely new to me, worries me a little bit. After all this relaxing, it's dangerous to start expecting myself to promptly finish my work.

It's hard to write when there's no story to tell.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I hate reading my English book because I always spend more time reading it than doing any of my other homework. I read the story, think about it a little, then randomly flip through the pages to another eyecatching story. I read it, then move on to another story. It continues until I realize how stupid I am to spend so much time reading fiction, or until I realize that there's still a pile of other homework on my desk.

The most memorable story for today was an excerpt from a book that chronicles the atomic bomb explosion in Hiroshima. I've read it many times before. During reading days at middle school, I would read the whole book over and over. It was the only nonfiction on the book dolly. Cover to cover. I must have read that particular chapter at least fifteen times. And it never stops intriguing me. In the book, the terror and suffering comes across as completely fictional. Like a bad nightmare, or a science fiction novel. But, to think, there are actual people who lived through the vaporization of a whole city. Actual people who breathe and think, who could come up to me and shake my hand, and tell me these stories that are so much more than stories to them.

It's disturbing to think that such a enormously violent has become something to be found in short pieces of old, dry English book. New Orleans wasn't vaporized by a expanding ball of flaming inferno. But, what if it was? How long would we remember before it would happen again?

Tomorrow I get to go on a field trip to Purdue with my AP Chemistry peers. It's a friendly change to my routine.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I get lost.

The weekend is meant for naps.

It's not the weekend yet.

There will be no naps.

I'll get more lost.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I'm very clumsy with my time.

I came home and fell asleep on my couch with the belief that I would wake up a few hours later to have enough time to finish my homework. It's a quarter past 9PM, and I woke up a few minutes ago. I gain some sleep, I lose some sleep. It's such a frustrating balancing act. Now I'm wasting more time by writing this and talking to Ryan (he has a new computer).

And every one of my peers is probably experiencing the same stress right now. Can't complain. I guess my situation could be worse. I could have woken up tomorrow morning. That wouldn't be the greatest way to start a morning.

*birds chirping, wind rustling*

"What a wonderful morni... Oh fuck. I have to do my precalculus, physics, chemistry, english, and programming homework"

And that's how the it would have happened.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
About a month ago, Devin said to me, "What's the point of your blog anyway? I tried writing for a little bit, then I realized how stupid it is to write bunches of meaningless crap."

I nervously laughed a little so I could pretend that I half agreed with him. But, as I walked away, I felt discouraged.

"Am I wasting my time?"

A few weeks later, the school newspaper came out. I uneasily opened the cheap newsprint and flipped through the smudged text to look for my articles. I couldn't find them. So I looked again. Hopeless.

None of my articles were published.

And so I accepted the fact that I'm a mediocre writer. I also tried to accept the fact that I went out of my comfort zone to interview people on my own time, to come up with my questions, to piece together the quotes to write a story, to sit in my room and erase and erase and rewrite and rewrite, the fact that all of those things were now worthless because the articles were thrown away.

Evan wrote his articles the day they were due, he wrote them sitting next to me, in thirty minutes of free time. He got all of his articles published.

The event discouraged me greatly.

I understand that not everyone wins, that maybe the majority of the school has different taste in reading than I do. But, why couldn't they stick me in the corner of a page somewhere? Instead of putting a medium-sized picture of Evan Rebar in the center of "Evan's Corner", maybe they could have shrunk my story and pasted it there.

It didn't happen that way though. So, I'll walk away and try again. There isn't much to life than that. Lose, lose, lose, win.

It's hard to find the motivation to write now. It's disheartening to spend time and effort doing something you know will be discarded and forgotten. Whatever writing it may be. An English essay, a blog post, an email to an acquaintance, they get written very slowly, as if I'm trying to worsen my issues with time management.

I haven't written here in a long time. I haven't written in a number of things in a long time. To click that briefcase open, to load up w.bloggar, to grab my pen with the same passion I did weeks, months, years ago is impossible to imagine now. It's not the same anymore. The noise my keyboard makes is sad, the keys are pushed slowly, carefully, and I have to ask myself, "Where are my ideas? Where is my bravado? Where is my inspiration? Did I even have any before? What could I have done with all of that wasted time?" I can't look at these utensils for creation without feeling pathetic.

Andrew once told me, "I hate the weekends, they give you too much time to think."

I couldn't have agreed with him more.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I hate it go away go away go away.

Everything. At this time of night.

A post it note, a yellow one. On my wall, it tells me what I haven't done. So much, four, six, ten things. They have to get done, they are jobs.
