They are essential, essential to my education, I tell myself this. They aren't getting done. And there are only so many hours in a day, and so many hours in a week. So many seconds in a day, each one, many wasted.

These aren't trivial mind you, they have to get done. The black ink from my pen, it can only write things for someone else. Obligations and deadlines, due dates and tests and quizzes and failed grades and that post it note on my wall. It won't go away. Just like everything else, it's all flooding into this tiny space of me that isn't tiny and isn't space. It's just hopeless.

I sit here and can't think of where to start, where to take the knife and cut what is out of my mind and tape it to the paper, my thoughts are so messed up, can't think of these sentences that are supposed to make up my analysis, my composition, this blog post, my newspaper articles. Can't stop. To many failures to do that. I can't say it's hard. I'm sure there are a thousand, a million people who are doing harder things than me.

There is a series of events that have to happen, I have to make them happen. I can't call it work. I put this upon myself. I'll call it recreation and blindly flail around in the dark, never getting anything done. False hope. Purposeless. Better things to do than sit around and wait to push a button to questions you'll never be sophisticated enough to understand. Better things to do than sit in a room with people who are just as "swamped" as you are. Better things to do than stress over articles that'll be discarded or ridiculed. Better things to do than feel stupid, and idiotic, and frustrated, for hurting someone's grade with your incompetence. And better things to do than glare at the post it note. Curse, point, and gawk at it. It stares back at me.

I'm not swamped. The buck stops here.

But, it'll end up not stopping here, and I'll feels guilty for telling you that. The buck will shoot me in the head and I'll be forgotten, and all of this will be for nothing. I've got better things to do than write this post and feel sorry for myself. Nothing ever gets done in this world.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: Free time isn't so free when you have the burden of having to do work soon after the free time is done and over with. It's late and I'm a stupid procrastinator.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Listening to light piano music, I always conjure up the urge to jump in front of a piano and start playing. I greatly enjoy listening to the mellow blends of tones, rhythmic tapping, quarreling higher-pitched notes, flittering and twittering and doing all sorts of flexible things that I didn't know music could do. And so for those moments, I yearn again how to produce music.

That day is over in my life, but occasionally I satisfy my pathetic urge by reaching into my desk cabinet and pulling out a light blue, plastic pianica. Piano-harmonica. Sort of like a bagpipe-accordion combination really. Carefully blowing faint puffs of air into the mouthpiece, careful not to let my parents hear, I create my random notes. They ring unpleasantly, the harsh texture of the noise coming out of the end with each press of a key. Not music, but noise. But, I pretend that I'm a musician, and my lusting is temporarily satiated.

Really, I've always wanted to learn how to play accordion. Not a clarinet, no saxophone for me. Trumpets are so mainstream. Accordions, they are crude, but somehow romantic, sometimes peaceful, other times intense. It's a dynamic instrument. Like dynamic people.

Dynamic people can manage their time and look suave at the same time. Stress is no problem for their flexibility. Mental capability, emotional capability, physical capability. They can earn a million dollars of trust in five minutes, can entertain a crowd for hours, can manage relationships for years. Dynamic people...

There are dynamic people all around me. Sometimes they're in clumps, and sometimes they talk about what sorts of amazing, super-human things they've accomplished in the past few days. Things that I haven't done, couldn't do. These people are above me, and it isn't a glass ceiling I'm under persay, I see it as more of a multi-layer, bulletproof, fire-resistant, plexiglass shield.

I still get bothered when I look through it. I've tried not looking up, but it's hard not to when there's so much going on up there. It's hard not to gaze up and wonder why you are so stupid as to have fallen through the trap door. I've tried accepting the facts, but sometimes I struggle.

I apologize.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
"Being a good writer is 3% writing skill and 97% not getting distracted by the Internet."

Ironically, I found this quote in a forum user's signature. Since looking at it, all I've done is realize more and more how true it is. Already, I've surfed Boingboing.net and Digg.com a few times. They're staples of late night post-homework vegetation, sure, but it's just as stupid as watching TV. No offense to television watchers.

I'll have to keep working on restraining myself. It's hard though. Wikipedia could keep me up all night. I get curious about a topic and go to its site, then just go in circles by clicking the links inside the article to other related articles. The links within articles is a helpful feature, but a very distracting one. A few minutes ago, the chain went a little like this:

Snow Crash -> Metaverse -> Avatar -> Anonymity -> Con Artist -> Australia -> Australian-Rules Football

The time spent reading these articles slowly starts to replace sleep time and work time and all sorts of time. Maybe I'm learning something, but I don't think I am. Sort of like reading a tabloid, I guess, my data retention is very poor.

And even as I write this, I'm getting the urge to hit my Windows key to get out of the program and open up the big box of Internet my computer is connected to. So very tempting... To check an inbox that rarely has any new messages in it, or to wiki some random topic, or to browse poorly-drawn anthro on DeviantArt.

Friday and Saturday were filled with enough content to shove all my writing aside. This sort of content usually contains certain crucial elements. New elements. Female elements.

Being in a relationship is splendid, but changing my priorities so abruptly is a little weird-feeling. Every day, I look forward to those moments when we're together, and writing, sleeping, hobbies, extracirricular activies, and homework all get shoved aside in the name of love. It never used to be like this, but then again, I've never had a girlfriend before. I'm still learning, and my time management skills will improve with practice (I hope).

Now, I'm off to be distracted by the Internet.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I got myself a 900L$ Luskwood fennec fox avatar. Rawr, I'm sexy.



Considering the thing cost me eighteen weeks to save up for, I'm liking it very much. Customizable facial expressions, tail movements, eye color changer, and automatic "away" expression. I love it lots. Too bad it's much too late for me to stay up any longer to play around with my new fennec-self. The next few days will be spent accessorizing!

I'm not gay, I swear.

The dinner jacket I'm in cost about 150L$ at some fancy formalware store. Bought the clothes about a half year ago, the glasses I got a year or more ago. I've got matching pistols for the jacket (but I don't carry them around furry-ish places because of the stigma they carry with them. Recent griefing attacks by random spammers/gunmen/hackers have turned the general public wary of avs with weapons)

Is it pathetic when you genuinely get excited about being a new kind of fox in a virtual world? Because I am right now.

I spent the other half of my day obsessing over nothing at Ryan's house. Fretting and fretting over homework that I imagine up, over tests that won't come for days. Getting angry and isolationist, trying to stay away from social situations because sometimes I think it's just too much. I don't know how people deal with all of the talking and all of the people. I need alone time as well as people time.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Ryo, what is this Lusk? $? Fox? Avatar? Dollars? Month? Week? Foxdollar? Luskavatar? Dollarmonth? Something like that thing? My brain is heavy with confusion. Please, elighten me.

p.s. Oh god, the verification word is a blob of color.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
This keyboard is an instrument I don't play well.

The warning bell rings and nothing is different. The same English class at the same time of day. The teacher hasn't gotten up to start the class yet, students are roaming the room, searching for social contact. Andrew stumbles upon me.

Just like every other day. He comes up to me and says his hello. And I always wonder, day after day, why does he come up to little 'ol me? His relaxed, pale green shirts, I can't forget them.

But, why me? I'm not important, I'm not a witty conversationalist. My entertainment value is limited before lunch. Sprouting out of my ears are not valuable insights, just stupid little things that he shouldn't, wouldn't concern himself with. Petty, petty thoughts. I just don't understand, because I don't deserve to be near him. Does he feel sorry for me?

And on his wrist is something he hasn't really explained to me, a red band.

I lost a lot of confidence in my level of trust between us when he didn't tell me of its significance.

I never should have thought that trust would be something so easy to attain.

A boring tone rings through speakers, flowing into the room and quieting the children down. Class begins.

In my uncomfortable seat, I'm feeling tired, hectic, and sad. You see, one class period earlier, I was fighting a math worksheet, or rather, fighting myself to finish a math worksheet. One math problem on the worksheet I couldn't finish. I got so worked up over it.

But, math time is over. English time has started.

After much chaos and disobedience, Mrs. VanHyfte begins reading example essays from classmates.

One by one, the doves in my head holding up strings tied to my self-esteem, one by one, they are shot down. Heads ripped from necks, wings torn from bodies, crimson orifices squirting streams of steaming fluid. Fired on not by enemies, but by friends.

The example essays are good, great! Wonderful strings of words, they flow, they mold, they are something of an art. Such great examples they use, their thesis statements are crystalline clear, and the transition couldn't be any smoother, and the knowledge! Such vast banks!

I just don't have it.

I just don't have it anymore.

My essay. It didn't have it. It's obvious from the stark contrast between the grandeur of my peers' essays and my pathetic shitstorm of words.

I look at all of my writing since the very first elementary school book report. Maybe I never had anything in the first place.

These words that spew forth on this page, and the archives, and the journals and essays and articles written and copied and forgotten. These words.

They just don't have it.

Maybe there was never any passion, I was never really a person. My feelings never strong, dialogue never engaging. Vocabulary equivalent to a mentally-handicapped squirrel with one leg. And I can never really make myself happy to try, try, try to transfer my thoughts into words. Because, simply, I'm not enough. I don't deserve the things I have.

So why does Andrew walk up to me in English class every day?

Why do people want me to come to social events? And why does someone else love me?

How do I deserve these things?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Because you aren't stupid and you deserved to be loved.

Besides...my essay didn't have IT either.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: I've wasted today away. The past hour I tried to make a "random post" button. It doesn't work. So I'm left to accept defeat and wake up tired and sicker tomorrow. I should have made the better choice and done my homework and slept early. I made the wrong decision. I stayed up late doing stupid things and getting on Second Life. These are the hours in which I hate myself the most.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Equally hazardous to park visitors is the PeopleMover. Hurtling through the sterile corporate future of Tomorrowland at a speed of two miles per hour, it is plainly a menace to the life and limb of every guest. Less than two months after its opening, it mutilated and killed its first victim. In August of 1967, Rick Yuma, a 15-year old boy from Hawthorne, innocently attempted to change cars as the PeopleMover passed through a tunnel. Unfortunately, he slipped and, as the papers reported, was "found wedged between two cars with his head and the upper part of his body crushed". And "wedged" was the word for it; Disney "Imagineers" negligently hadn't forseen this possibility and made allowances for it in their design. Workers had to dismantle the train in order to extricate the boy's mangled remains...

...Park guests aren't the only ones seduced to their deaths by the park's attractions. Consider the late, lamented "America Sings". It was seemingly designed strictly as a hazard to employees. Converted from the old General Electric Carousel of Progress, it featured six theaters revolving around a four part fixed stage of Disney audioanimatronic animal figures performing well-loved American songs. Even before its official 1974 opening, there was something sinister about this android musical spectacular. The tragedy to come was foreshadowed at the press preview party, when one of the attraction's designers fell into a pit and sustained slight injuries.

Disneyland ignored this omen, and opened "America Sings" to the public at the end of June. This decision would cost them the life of an innocent young hostess, the first Disneyland employee killed in the line of duty.

Deborah Stone had just graduated from nearby Santa Ana High. In many ways, she epitomized the crisp, clean all-American image encouraged among park employees. She edited her high school year book, belonged to the honor society and capped her high school career by winning the principal's award for "outstanding service to her school and community". Undoubtedly, she breezed through her coursework at the Disneyland University.

Yes, she had nothing but a bright future full of promise to look forward to on that tragic July night. There were no witnesses to her agonizing end, no spectacular fall or dramatic search. Around 11 PM, fellow employees noticed her missing from her post greeting guests. After a brief search, they found her crushed remains. As the theaters rotated about the fixed inner stage, she had been caught between a stationary wall and a moving wall. The attraction smashed her like a steamroller running over one of Disney's beloved characters in a hilarious act of animated mayhem. Except this was no cartoon, and there would be no animated sleight of hand to "uncrush" her. America Sings was closed for three days until a system of warning lights could be installed. But for one young hostess, it was a little too late. [LINK]

What a horrible way to die.

Life seems so valuable, but after seeing people die in such an absurd place, I'm sure it changes perspectives.

On the topic of depressing things, I'm glad I didn't go to Challenge Day this week. Truthfully, I would have cried. Better to force the bad things out of memory. For the good of yourself and others.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
"They're shooting them like dogs!", said a foreigner as he looked across the snowy mountains. Across the valley, he saw a line of people slowly walking up the mountain, no farther than three kilometers away. Only, a few weren't walking, instead sprawled on the snow. On his side of the mountain, a lone soldier, dressed in regulation green and grey dress, held a rifle. The lone soldier fired another round. With a sharp crack, another dot on the other side of the valley stops moving. On the other side of the Earth, I sit here and drink my cup of water, looking through a window to a land faraway, where another man shoots, another man dies.[LINK]

Today was a lonely day. The overcast sky makes everything look dead and artificial. It gets darker as I type this, the thing illuminating my keyboard is an old fluorescent lamp. Nothing seems human. I don't think I've smiled today.

But, today wasn't meant to be a smiling day anyway. It was a day where I sat down on my bed and read The Scarlet Letter and The Celestial Railroad, both by an author obsessed with writing long, long sentences of dreary, difficult text. It must have been the language of the day, so he is pardoned. These boring stories match this boring day of what was supposed to be rest, but quickly became anxiety.

For enjoyment, I close my textbooks up and read a little bit of Maus. It's a graphic novel, so it helps a simple mind like mine. I read of lice, pus, burning flesh, and other such things associated with the Holocaust. I also read about love, risk, and the luck of a man, or mouse, insistent on surviving.

Going to a robotics meeting today, I felt isolated. Always have, I couldn't have expected any better. The meeting felt so... constraining. All talk and no action. What action was there to take anyway? Planning. I'm not a fantastic planner. Meetings are always full of grand plans of success and ideal dates to strive for. In reality, things end up being a matter of passing the buck until it gets done. Sometimes, the buck never stops, so we just shoot the buck and hang it up over the fireplace. Shooting is not preferred.

Not even an email from another person. No phone calls. No chatting. No confiding of personal secrets, or exchanges of curious gossip. No voice to respond to. It's quiet. It's lonely. I miss my friends. I miss the sun. Time passes, nothing changes. The sky will be getting darker all winter.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I sent you an email!!

(before I read this post, too)

Reply, damnit! I'm as bored as you are!

See you tomorrow :-) (hopefully hear back from you before then)

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I've opened and closed this program a few times now, trying to convince myself that there isn't anything to type. That today was a day worth forgetting, that there was nothing of note in these past 20-some hours.

And to tell you the truth, I can't think of anything that made me feel. I was entirely content.

Although, I snapped this afternoon and started to type grouchy and frustrating words to my friends. That was right before I ate dinner, and I was hungry. After eating, I stopped typing angry things and got to work on my various affairs. Go figure.

When I'm about to die, I'll look back to days like this and feel stupid and remorseful for taking this grand life for granted.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: "Preach! Write! Act! Do anything, save to lie down and die!" (pg 153, Ch 18, The Scarlet Letter)

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
>After an hour of reading my chemistry textbook, I momentarily forgot what life was like before the rigors of high school drama, standardized testing, and weeks of limited sleep.

Alabama. Elementary school. The sky wasn't always blue, but it was blue enough for me. Afternoons were spent doing stunts in my pool or eating snacks while watching cartoons. My next-door-neighbor friend would ring the doorbell. I'd mosey along and open it, and we'd play racing games on the computer for hours. Side by side on the keyboard, we traded off on who got the arrow keys and who got the a, s, d, and w. Windy days yielded much kite flying, and much disappointment as the kites often attached themselves to the nearby pines. I got that kite at a convenience store across the street from the beach. My dog was a puppy then. She would be walked around the neighborhood and she'd be as crazy as the rest of the dogs. Evenings were cool, always they were the right conditions to admire a very generous and inviting atmosphere. It was different being a kid. Of course it was different.

So, back to the real world. I'm feeling nostalgic after digging through the many costumes in a rarely explored closet. Who would have known that closet would have had that old train set that's missing a few pieces, or a scrapbook I made in third grade, or my black ballet slippers? So I passed a quick glance through the inventory to find usable material. I forgot how fun "dress-up" is. With all the sorts of suits and capes and hats, the possibilities are aplenty. I shouldn't be spending a wednesday night doing this though. There are better times for reminiscing.

Good night.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Envy is shallow. It's a strong, passionate feeling though, primal as it is. A very basic tier of emotion.

So, I'll tell you the truth and tell you that I was in a state of envy today. Envious, because from my blurry eyes, the world is lashing out at me. So I lash out at the world. Stages, there are stages of compensation. A setback, then another. They add up. I help Nik with his math and he gets a higher grade than me. I volunteer after school to help fundraise and the profit goes to the other person. I take a two hour nap and I stay up three hours later.

Please don't listen to me. Everybody has everyday problems. How do I justify my complaints? I can't. I'll do it here and call myself a bad person.

But, things happen to me still. My stages:

  • First comes the grief. Complaining. Annoying friends. Hating myself, but I can't stop. I know it's pointless, but it makes me feel better. A sinking feeling of selfishness sets in. Then guilt.

  • Second comes the skin-deep acceptance. I tell myself that it's alright, I know it's not. I know I'm not deep enough to overcome my obstacles through sheer willpower. I'm only whispering sweet nothings to myself so I'll get over it. Soon, the structure crumbles and my faux-optimism falls through.

  • Third comes fear. Pacing mindlessly around the empty newspaper room, throwing my hands up and deliriously hitting myself against heavy objects, explaining to myself the consequences of my mistakes. Cursing under my breath. The heart races, I look for an escape. When I realize there is none, I feel helpless.

  • Fourth comes the envy. It's someone else's fault. Other people are against me. I was born this way. Excuses, excuses, excuses.
  • Fifth comes the weekend. When monday rolls around, start the cycle back up


So what if Andrew is deep? Huh? Why can't I be deep? I must be deformed, incapable, something's wrong with me to make it so that I can't be deep. And Josh can write stories. Yay. I can't do that either.

These malicious thoughts pull me down further.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Stop being an idiot. You are a perfectly fine human being. You achieve so much that you don't even see.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Always things to do on the weekend now.

Second Life is always a threatening diversion to real work, which includes a paper I have to write by next week. I have to get that done within the next few days (I should have gotten part of it done today.) Tomorrow then, I guess. And articles to write. Newspaper will once again force me to write articles of garbage. So, that's a few more page of text to write. Tests. A lot of those to remember. A physics test tomorrow that I'd prefer to study for (but, obviously didn't prefer enough).

At the lecture on Thursday, Amy Tan spoke about how she took so many classes in college that she had to read and write a paper on a book once a day. Thinking about how other people can do these amazing feats of concentrated effort is both disheartening and inspiring.

Here I am, struggling to write a paper in two weeks. Pathetic.

And other things continue to harass me, chiefly being the Lego League program at the nearby elementary school. Our robotics team is not to a level where we can competently lead elementary school children in a technical setting. They yell, fight, cry, distract, play, all sorts of things that children are supposed to do. It makes building a robot... difficult. The "research project" that they need to do is very much lacking as well. I don't even think a distinct topic has even been chosen yet. It's a very stressful situation.

Tomorrow brings surprises.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Every night, I spent fifteen minutes combing my hair so it looks just right. I stare into the mirror and make sure all the hairs are pointed in the right direction, with the right intensity sheen, in just the perfect asymmetric way. Picking up the cheap fifty cent comb, I make little adjustments on the left, then on the top. Sometimes it just takes a little twitch of a finger on that one stubborn strand to get everything right. Minutes pass, minutes in which I could be doing something more productive, and finally I reach a conclusion to my journey. My hair is perfect. With a sigh of satisfaction, I walk out of the bathroom, up the stairs, and into my room.

Doesn't it seem absurd to you that I do this? I wake up in the morning with hair that's frazzled and odd, and at that hour in the morning I'm too tired to care.

So, I'd have to say that I comb my hair at night to relieve stress. To doze off mentally, take a tool, and set out to complete an objective. It's image-building stuff here. So it helps me build my self-image as well. The rationale being that perhaps my hair can make up for my self-implied mental inadequacy. Although, I do know that somewhere in my head there is the knowledge that I'm not stupid. Maybe Tiffany is right, and I'm just fishing for complements all the time. Or maybe I look down on myself to appear humble. Maybe Andrew is right, and I get sad like everyone else, and getting sad isn't a bad thing.

But, there are other things to concern myself with than my own motives in acting the way I do.

A service man from Sears came to my house to uncover why the riding mower wasn't starting up. Apparently, four years of neglect and a strict regimen of non-maintenance led to a series of unfortunate mechanical problems. A crack in the plastic gas tank being one of them. Because of the wonderfully clever design of the mower, gas was leaking right into the engine, as the gas tank sits on top of the engine. Also, the battery was fried, and a clogged air filter was leading to major issues under the hood.

The service man mentioned that the whole thing could have caught fire if I tried to run the thing with a running battery.

Last week, when I noticed that the engine area was oddly coated with residue, I tried to start up the mower anyway. I am grateful that the battery did not kick on. Burnt to a crisp I do not want to be.

Off to Canada tomorrow to look at certain canadian colleges. Thinking of higher education scares me. I feel so incapable in this sea of talent.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: I'm off for Canada, bye all. If I die in travel, y'all can have my stereo and my National Geographic collection. By using both at the same time, you'll have the capability of wasting hundreds of your free (or working) hours.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Well, I don't have a post-it with your name on it. So I'd say that you're safe for now. You will indeed die another day.

-Death

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I'm back.

Coming back from a frigid Canadian city, I have realized how warm Indiana is. My stay in Montreal was cold, wet, and very French.

I'm tired. You know the feeling. The "I just got home from a hours long drive and cramped airplane seat travel, and now I've got to study for chemistry, hoorah (with snappy sarcasm)" tiredness.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I spent halloween staying up and doing nothing in particular. So, there goes my saved up sleep. Wasted. Wasted thinking about tomorrow's events. Wasted thinking about how my life has become a series of deadlines and entries in my schedule and lists of tasks to be done.

There wasn't anything to enjoy from the vacation I took for fall break. Social isoation, physical isolation. Getting nothing done, it was so frustrating. I can't relax when there's so much work piling up. And so how does this work pile up during vacation? I make it up sometimes, or imagine homework due when it's not, or expect myself to meet irrational due dates. I plan, I lay everything down and arrange, I read and read and read.

Then, when I fail the summary test, everything seems like a waste. The effort, the successive tries. A waste of effort when the outcome is inevitably failure. And I start to realize what's going through the minds of the people who pass through school with D's and C's in regular classes.

Can they see something I can't, or is it the other way around?

Or am I ranting so I can fill up space for today's entry? For the sake of filling it up, so I can get back on the rythm of writing regularly? Because, I'm getting the feeling that that is what I am doing. Because it's late at night and I can't think of anything important, deep, or witty to discuss with myself.

I almost cried at school today. Why am I so weak? So fucking weak...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Koh thinks this happens when one is too inwardly focused? Suggested medication: Watch people, watch the Big Lebowski, eat animals.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
If today was a name of a book, it would be entitled: Murder and Intrigue in the Case of Missing Robotics Computers.

As the failure of the "IT Captain" I am, I tried to do a seemingly simple thing. Find out where the robotics team's computers are. I asked, and I still have not found. All of the people I talked to were peers, so there was much finger pointing at the administration and other adults. I must remember to question them tomorrow. Another thing that cropped up a few times was the discontent and miscommunication among members. Some speculate that the team's existence is at stake.

Robotics is an odd beast. It'll wick away your time, drive your head to madness, and get you angry at your peers, frustrated at the issues at hand. At the same time, it continues, as there is always (even if it is a trace) of hope, of residual confidence and resolve to do the things needed to get tasks accomplished. As the season continues, this residual emotion is fluctuating, with more depressions than peaks, and I sometimes fear that everything will fall apart and all the effort invested in robotics will be nullified.

I see no future for a group with such resentment and ill will. I hope that there will be a future for the team, and as the older members graduate, this ill will will die away. I want things to work. But, is simply wanting enough?

Because robotics has changed me from a nobody to a somebody. When I talk to people on the team, I feel like I'm a person. Like I have the ability to create things, just like everybody else. And when people ask me to do things, I do them, and when I ask other people to do things, they do them as well. It's a very different dynamic than quizbowl, where I'm constantly alienated and confused, sometimes uncomfortably.

Now that I think about it, quizbowl is an odd beast too. As I mentioned above, I feel alienated, but only within myself. A few people I know from quizbowl I have a deeper connection to than the people I know from robotics. Hm...

NaNoWriMo has begun. I'm not participating. I wish best of luck to those who do.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The robotics meeting today was a personal failure for me. It was like always.

The inefficient, unproductive meeting involved the sociable stupid people dragging everyone else down, software problems (which resulted in a total of 2 training-usable computers, and drab powerpoints. I was disappointed to find this meeting unimportant. I should have seen it coming.

Or perhaps it was efficient and productive. It's just that I chose to stay out and model objects with my peers.

I hate it when it's late, late at night. There are things to do, things that aren't really due, but personal affairs that need to be taken care of. No, not those personal affairs. Personal affairs like drawing a quick sketch of that beautiful cartoon panel, or writing a paragraph or two here and there. And it adds up, it eats up time.

I should be getting to sleep. Fridays are always significant, right?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I hate it, and I can't admit it to myself. I played Sim City 4 for over two hours today. It's a powerful addiction. So now, if you hear me complain about homework, think bad thoughts of me. Hate me. Be really pissed off at me and don't feel shy about being vocal about how you want to take a brick to my head.

On a positive note, I'll be building bridges tomorrow at Tiffany's house. I found some Gorilla Glue at my house and used it to make vermicelli triangles. What surprised me the most was the fact that Gorilla Glue needs water to function, and that it foams up to three or four times its size while bonding. Who knew that something you see in SkyMall magazine would be so useful?

As for bridge design, I'm leaning toward some sort of simple truss bridge. Tif and I will have to agree on one together, but in the mean time I'll tell you that I find the Pratt Truss my favorite for its visual appeal. OMG BRIDGES r FUNzorz![LINK]

Walking into the Barber Shop, I felt anxious on the inside. I put on a smile and tried not to show what was going through my mind. This is a half a years worth of hair man, what are you doing? These old, but lively barbers have a tendency to take as much as they can off of my head. I've known from three years of their service. Half an hour and two chapters of Moby Dick later, I'm gazing into a mirror looking at my hair. It's different.

It's a bad thing to be a vain person, but wouldn't you feel like staring into a mirror after taking off what feels like whole kilograms of hair?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I enjoyed today. Or, I'm telling myself I enjoyed today so I won't regret this weekend.

Even doing my physics homework was entertaining (to some extent).

So now I'll go enjoy my life some more. I'll wake up tomorrow and enjoy my life. I'll do that for years and years until I die. And I'll die satisfied. Because, I got through it.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
To some extent? Telling yourself you enjoyed it? Loser....I didn't know I was that boring.

Jk.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I feel attacked.

By who? I can't see.

I sat there in the hallway after school, waiting to interview someone. Waiting for swimming practice to start so I could interview the swimming coach. In the wide, open hallway my books are sprawled out on the floor. I rest against some wooden trophy case. Remembering diving freshman year, remembering the ice cream machine that isn't there, remembering how much has changed in the past year, I cried. I pushed myself against that trophy case, and I pushed hard, thinking that maybe it would fall on me, or maybe pushing would somehow relieve my stress. Maybe it would solve my problems. Quickly, I realized it was for no reason, this pushing. The trophy case wouldn't fall on me.

And it's sick. I'm sick. Because, what am I doing? Am I waiting for someone else to come up and feel sorry for me? Am I waiting for everything to go away? Nothing is going to go away, and I never feel better when people feel sorry for me. But, why am I doing it? Why can't I just hold it in like everyone else, why do I have to be some weak prick that has to arrogantly flout his uncomfortableness to the world?

And right before swimming practice started, I moved to the extra room behind the pool that the swimmers store their snacks in. Rachel and I talked. But, I felt so pathetic. The only thing I could do was shove my hat down lower and try to keep my eyes focused on a worthless book in my hand. I had to ignore everything, ignore her, ignore the moon pies in the cardboard box next to me, ignore all the happy, friendly, efficient, proper, well-to-do, exciting people outside of the door waiting to valiantly sacrifice their physical comfort, I had to at least try to ignore these things. If only to keep from dwelling on my thoughts. I cracked a little, and Rachel left the room. I didn't feel any better after the interview. I didn't feel any better after going home and eating. I didn't feel better.

I would like to tie it down to one thing. Like Robotics. Like Newspaper. Like School. Like Myself. That would just be blaming something. Pointing my insignificant finger at something, anything, to get the attention of people who have no reasonable intention or need to care. There's no problem to solve. There isn't anyone to blame. It is just how it is. I feel how I do. The world was just build like that.

And if someone feels sorry for me, I feel worse. And if someone doesn't feel sorry for me, I feel worse. And I just don't know when this cycle ends. On Friday? But, then it starts on Sunday. Can one day really be called the end of a cycle?

Like banging on a wall, I am tense and explosive. And my problems are still there. A Thursday deadline. A Tuesday interview. A Precalc, Physics, AP Chemistry test. Paying for a t-shirt for a lego league team whose members I despise. None of these things cuts deep, so why do I feel so bloody mangled?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I was thinking, it would be a really nice thing to have an egg timer on my desk. That way I could keep myself from spilling time all over the floor and having to mop it all up. That's what it feels like sometimes, this mess of inefficiency.

There's a thumb-sized chunk of Moby Dick to be read, and I need to start chomping down on it. Now. But, before I do, let me share some...

Embarassing Quizbowl Talk
Background: Tiffany and Zach are shouting out proverbs to me because we picked a proverbs category and I was somehow charged with being captain. I screw up a few proverbs while they shout them out to me and repeat them to Mrs. S so we can continue to the next question. Mrs. S then feels sorry for me and tries to get Zach off of my back.

Mrs. S (to Zach):Now, imagine, English is Ryo's second language, what is he supposed to...

Me:Actually, it's my first language. I'm just really bad with the talking thing.

Mrs. S (To Zach):Well, but still...

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I suspect it bothers you too when you walk into your room and find your things in all the wrong places. From that one misplaced cd case, or overturned book, you know that someone has been in your room, looking through your items.

And so goes my life. My radio's graphic equalizer was not in the right position, and my locked briefcase had mysteriously turned its numbers to the secret code. Something is wrong in my room. I don't want it disturbed.

I've been getting too angry in the past few days. I have to calm myself down and realize that problems are solved through work, not aggravated drivel. For example, I've been getting particularly frustrated in my thoughts toward the Lego League children at Burnett Creek. Some of them are arrogant, some refuse to work, some are loud and stupid, some have no social skills.

See! I'm doing it again. It's just that when the kid who signed up for the "research" part of the project is downright refusing to write anything, one gets to wondering why they are part of a robotics team. Or why such a team even exists.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Tonight was full of free time.

Thus, copious amounts of SimCity 4, ArtRage, and web reading have hopefully restored me to full hp.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The dance came. The dance went. It was over and a flash. I don't know what to say. It was great. Wasn't perfect, but it was great. I feel guilty for not revealing more of my thoughts in this post.

Now I'm in an engineering building at Purdue. It's absurd how these computers I drive 20 minutes to use fail to open up my 3d files I worked on at home. It's frustrating. Frustrating. Nothing ever gets done in these computer labs because the computers are too slow and the people are too talkative.

I should have stayed home and done my homework so I could have gotten sleep before 10pm tonight.

Being disappointed from robotics is a recurring theme in my life.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I look down at my watch, and all I can think to myself is,
"It's still monday!?"

I agree. I shouldn't expect time to move so fast, nor should I want time to move so fast. But, I can't help feeling rushed to jump through these hoops. Each day, there's some test, or other stressful item I'd rather get over with. During the day, most of my thoughts are directed toward the item in question. I focus and focus on this event that is insignificant in the whole scheme of things, and when I finally take the test, or turn in the paper, I'm presented with another project to think about. It's this complacent, obsessively objective lifestyle I'm living right now that is bothering me.

It's as if I'm not alive, I'm just going through the motions so I can get through the day and move on to the next. I'll be doing that tomorrow because of the physics test, and the next day about my English paper, and then the next day a Chemistry lab. But, I don't want my life to be so chain-like. What can I do?

It's my outlook. That's it. It's how I'm viewing my assignments. I have to tell myself that I have to relax and be spontaneous. I must take the uncalculated risk, learn to accept failure, and figure out that it's alright to quit sometimes. Be smooth, stop hitting yourself against the wall. Be smooth.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Due to my utter lazyness, I will now post my english essay. Please, before reading this, understand that the ideas expressed below may not be the same ideas I hold now. Understand that I'm fine, and that a lot of what I wrote below was for creative effect. Understand.

We sit at a table made of particleboard. Holding greasy, plastic rods with little red buttons on the end, the team gets ready. With a fierce rapidity, questions are asked and answered. Red and yellow, the lights flash. Both witty quips and candies are passed around as tumultuous laughter enlightens the room. So begins the Tuesday afternoon Quizbowl practice. My watch reads two-fifty.

Each and every Tuesday, I come to this "practice" through brute willpower to fulfill a false obligation. One may not understand the magnitude of the weight situated on my conscience. If only my peers would understand how blatantly uncultured I am. My cognitive contribution to the team sums to nothing. Shakespeare, chemistry, middle eastern rivers, and others are topics of great confusion for me. Truly, this is information that violently cuts the line between mentally fashionable and unfashionable. I sit in an unfavorable spot.

The writhing angst and inner backlash shred into morsels of my confidence won from a victorious clash against a recent physics test. We sit at a table made of particleboard, but still I sit alone. A pen and a rectangle of paper meant for math calculations are my only exit. I draw, scribble, and write spiteful messages to myself. I do anything to control my anxiety. The teacher reads, but I do not hear. I clench the buzzer, but do not feel. My only objective is to control my emotions, to keep from outright crying. The future becomes present, trivia questions are asked, and I see no spring of hope. Not even a trickle to be found.

Simply, the activity was not meant for me. I, a naturally simple-minded and dull person, should not be participating. Defying good reason, I have continued, and a problem has become of it. One should note that a problem of this nature does not plateau. No, this gnawing guilt has matured through these high school years. It has matured into a dangerous beast.

I often question my role on the team. Why must I force myself to continue? Always, I hurriedly hide the truth from myself. Through false hope and hallucinated idealism, I convince my mind to bear with the torment. I deceive myself into believing that trudging through such thickened mud will make a stronger person out of me.

The lights stop flashing, the buzzers stop ringing. Team members file out of the door as practice ends. I sit in a dark, empty room. My eyes drift from hand to hand as I take a deep breath and ask, "When will I reach the truth?"

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Ding!

I walk to the sink and spit out my toothpaste foam. Someone's at the door. Hurriedly hiding my toothbrush in my pocket, I peek out of the corner of the wall to see a dark figure. The figure shuffles from left to right, idly waiting for his call to be answered. I nervously turn on the front lights and open the door. Outside is chilly. I close the door to keep the warm air inside.

In front of me stands a long haired male with an orange and grey hiking jacket and faded jeans. He looks like a college kid. Under his arm is a clipboard with a few sheets of gridded paper and a laminated map of the city. He shows it to me.

"I'm assuming your parents are the head of the household?"
"Yeah."
"Could you get them for me?"

I walk to the master bedroom. My mother is busy drying her hair in front of a mirror.

"There's some petition guy at the door. He wanted to see you, but I'll deal with him."

I walk back to the door to see the man glancing at the doorbell. No doubt he was just settling his eyes in a neutral area so he could think without distraction.

"My parents are busy and they told me I had to deal with it, so..."
"Well, I'm part of the Citizen Action committee and we're promoting the inclusion of more renewable energy in Indiana. Trying to change legislature, informing the public, stuff like that, you know?"
"Neat."
"It's something that you can support, and I'm collecting signatures for a letter, so could you...?"
"Sure thing."

I sign the letter. He seems calm throughout it all. I'm reminded how nervous I would be if I were in his shoes. Going up to people and convincing them to do something was never one of my strengths. This guy can do it, and in a cold, dark, yuppie neighborhood nonetheless!

"So, how many signatures have you collected so far? It's a big neighborhood."
"Actually, I've just got ten. Just started on this area. I think I'll get a lot more as I go along though."
"Yeah, I've done this before, and it's hard. Walking around in the dark and stuff."
"This door-to-door thing keeps our overhead low and so,..."
"I can imagine, especially in these sorts of neighborhoods"
"Oh yeah, you're a student right? Do you have a spare ten dollars laying around? For that you could be part of our organization."
"No thanks, but do you have a website or something I could check out?"
"Sure thing."

He hands me a sheet of paper and circles a block of text with a blue marker. I put it in my pocket with my toothbrush.

"You can donate through the website too, and there's neat stuff there."
"Thanks for the info, man. Sounds interesting."

We shake hands. His grip is on the weaker side. I feel powerful being the one with the firmer grip. He starts walking away, I start closing my door, but I turn around when he gets to the road.

"Hey, and good luck with your signatures!"
"Thanks! Have a good night."

I walk into my house and pull out the paper he handed me. Standing over the trash bin, I tear the paper rectangle into a shower of white flakes. Satisfied, I mutter to myself, "Everyone's happy."

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I feel enlightened.

Many of my peers did not feel so enlightened today. Just my luck that right when I can relax and be happy, people around me get irritable. Other people's actions are other people's actions. Not my place to meddle.

Here, I'd like to type my opinion about how other people act, but I've learned that these ideas may seem developed to me at the time, but soon turn out to be flim-flam nonsense.

I learned how to texture things today. So I'll mark that down as one of my miniature accomplishments. Gotta' start tallying these things up.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Behind the counter, in a tidy arrangement, they sit. Something that has been five years in the making. Twelve of them, neatly stacked in the corner. Boxes of white printed with grey, sans-serif text, the Mac-esque marketing campaign that just oozes with hipness. The man in the store outfit leans over and puts one of them in a plastic bag. A crowd of about twenty pasty college students mingle under cardboard cutouts of green-shirted elven swordsmen, exploding cars, and British spies.

The plastic bag reaches the top of the counter. A credit card is scanned, blip. Someone starts counting down, and the rest join. "Ten seconds before midnight!", someone yells.

We stand behind the counter, away from the crowd, staring forlornly at the pile of modular treasures. If only, if only...

"THREE, TWO, ONE, WIIIIIIII!!!"

And with that said, a new era begins. Transactions flood the cashier, and the group of coveted game consoles escape in the arms of eager fanboys and fangirls.

We stand at the door, spending the remainder of our time wishing that we could be them, and they could be us.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: Crisis du jour: I am missing my a red notebook with the majority of my schoolwork in it. Notes, worksheets, calendars, pictures, phone numbers... I need to find it, and fast.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Downright nonsensical, that's what the day has been like.

I have found my red notebook!

At the beginning of the day, I wasn't very stable, emotionally. Maybe it was the knowledge that I did this to myself, and that it was my own fault, and it could have been prevented by being more careful, or maybe it was the feeling of helplessness from a lack of knowledge of where the darned thing was. Whatever the case, my morning could have been better.

I walk into the physics class, seventh period, at the end of the school day. By physics, there isn't any of that gripping and tightening around the throat feeling, that uncontrollable, dark, and overwhelming feeling. None of that. By physics, I've started to accept the fact that a quarter of this year's work and notes have vaporized. Finally, while absentmindedly staring at my physics teacher, I came to terms with the loss.

I turn around and find the notebook sitting on a chair behind me.

The experience was surreal. My long departed friend, resurrected from an untimely death, there it sat. I put the notebook on my desk and let a wave of gratefulness wash over me. How absurd I was to be fretting over a stack of papers that was within my grasp the whole day. I have no sense.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: You found the notebook? Pfft...right.
