Rejoice!

Preparing to sleep... It's time to stop gawking over video reviews of Twilight Princess [LINK], laughing at Sony's incompetence [LINK], and speculating about wild rumors about the Wii's true power [LINK].

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Yahoo. Freedom.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Black Friday post


First stop: Best Buy
  • My morning starts off with a chilling fifteen minute wait outside the doors of the local Best Buy. Above is a picture of dozens of people waiting behind the road just before the stampede starts. In the bottom corner of the photograph, a police car sits. After this morning, I can understand why they needed law enforcement. Pushing, shoving, bumping. The doors are opened and the crowd gushes through in a solid mass. It's shoulder to shoulder, and employees are being dragged here and there. "Where's this? Where's that? Don't you have any more of those left!? MY CHRISTMAS IS RUINED!" I trail behind a muscular looking guy, and I get to where I want to be. My parents want me to pick up a photo printer. Little kids dart between my feet, clawing to get to the $4.99 100-pack of Dynex DVD's. I take a crumpled picture of the printer from my pocket. The model numbers match, so I pick up a box and run for the cash register line. With each passing second, the line grows, snaking through appliances, through furniture, then finally all the way to the back of the store, near home theater. Crazy...




Second Stop: Radio Shack
After stashing the printer, ink, and photo paper in the car, I'm free to do whatever I want. I could have gone home to eat breakfast, but with the mall across the street, I couldn't help peeking in and seeing the mayhem. A lone Radio Shack is crammed with people, the line streches a few stores down. The Radio Shack is just that, a shack. The size of the store compared to the amount of people trying to get in was absurd. I shoved my way into the fray for fun. People yelling, calling their relatives, confusion, confusion, confusion.




Third Stop: GameStop
  • GameStop was a little more rational by limiting the number of customers allowed into the store. I happened to be part of the second group of people to be let in. Thus, I stood witness to many shattered dreams. At least five people came in excited, asked about the Wii, were told about its sellout, and walked out sulking or irate. However, my dreams were in no such condition.

Inside GameStop: The Wii
  • My first thoughts: "THE WII! OH MY FUCKING GOD, IT'S A WII." Noticing that there was no controller in sight, I ask the man behind the counter. He trades me my camera for a Wii-mote. I spend the next fifteen minutes in nintendo nirvana. Curious shoppers gather around me as I embarass myself playing Excite Truck. Finally noticing the sad faces of children around me, I force myself to let go of the plastic rectangle of ecstasy and pass it on to another lucky fanboy.

Fourth Stop: Office Depot
  • On my drive home from the mall, I remember seeing an advertisement for cheap photo paper at Office Depot. By now, two hours of time have passed, so I enter the store with a grim outlook, expecting the line to be excruciatingly long and products to be sold out. I am surprised to find the $3.99 photo paper. I wasn't as lucky about the line. I spend the next half-hour waiting in a line that moved in shuffles, not steps.




I return to my car. The sun begins to scroll above the horizon. My Black Friday bonanza is over. I drive home with the trophies of my effort in the back seat. A cheap, brand-name, compact photo printer.



Who knew it took so much packaging to get a printer from a factory to someone's house?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
According to Wikipedia, Geotagging is "is the process of adding geographical identification metadata to various media such as websites, RSS feeds, or images. This data usually consists of latitude and longitude coordinates, though it can also include altitude and place names."

It's a fun way to enhance your photographic experience. Basically, you're adding extra data to your photographs so they can be traced to pinpoint locations on Earth. Plus, it's a few free downloads (and uploads) away.

First, download Picasa [LINK], and Google Earth [LINK] if you don't have these programs already. I use both programs often. Although, I like Google Earth better because I'm not used to Picasa's interface.


















After installation, Picasa will automatically grab photos from your hard drive and such, then display them in its fancy viewport.

Things are pretty self explanatory. Folders of photos on left, photos in the middle, double click a photo to edit, etc.





















Click on a photo you want to geotag, then hit Tools->Geotag->Geotag With Google Earth
Truly, convenience at its best.
Keep in mind that you can select more than one photo to geotag in bulk.






















Google Earth will then load up. Line the yellow crosshairs up with the place you took the photo. In my case, I'm using an old photo taken when i lived in Alabama. I'm placing the crosshairs where my old house is, off of Manningham Road in Greenville, Alabama. You can see that there is a highway behind my house. It lead to many sleepless nights.

When you're satisfied with your location, just hit "geotag", and the location is saved within your image file somewhere in its EXIF data.














After you've geotagged a bunch of photos, you can upload them to Panoramio [LINK], so other people can see your "map of photos". With Panoramio, you can upload and map your photos for free, then share your map with other people. The site automatically gets the location data Picasa saved onto the photos and places your photos on a map. It's neat. It's free. That's good.

Here is my map of photos: [LINK]

Happy geotagging!

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
In a nutshell, today has been a positive day. Unlike the usual sunday, where I'm sulking around thinking of the approaching schoolday, today I strided with anticipation thinking of the approaching schoolday. School: It's a feel-bad feel-good event. The duality, it's so cliche. Like something you'd read in a book.

When there isn't any school, I feel stagnant, restless. Maybe this is what people feel like when they retire. I feel like I have to compensate, to create things, to just do something, you know? If I don't make or do anything, I see no purpose in the day. At every sun set, I have to be able to say to myself,
"Hey, I took a step forward today."
Time to work on that english essay that has been nagging me since Thursday morning (which actually means, "time to procrastinate until it's late enough for me to put if off for another day").

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I have been informed by my pen-pal Pete (say that fast ten times), an animator friend I met at an off-season robotics competition, that this year's animation competition for robotics is going to be downscaled. Greatly downscaled.
The Autodesk Visualization Award winner will also be announced at the FIRST Championship. There will no longer be regional Autodesk Visualization Awards.
Please note that there will no longer be an Honorable Mention or Rookie winner.
-http://firstbase.autodesk.com/?nd=competition

So, you might ask, "How big is the impact?" Well, picture this: There are exactly 37 regional events around the world each year. In previous years, 3 awards for animation were given at each regional. Do the math: 3*37=111. That's one hundred and eleven awards being consolidated into a single award. Animators around the world just lost 111 chances for recognition, 111 trophies, 111 moments of pride and fame in front of an audience. People work for weeks on these animations. And now they get what? Nothing. The chance of a team winning that single award is virtually zilch. There goes the motivation, there goes the community. Yeah, thanks Autodesk and FIRST. For shitting us out.

Oh well... You can't win everything. And if the powers that be are going to work against me, then well, there's no point in complaining.

In other news, the school's energies have become more harmonious, as evidenced by the sharp nosedive of my French grade and the noticible increase in my math grade. Things are now where they always were, in their natural state of equilibrium.

Homework. Yeah, I've got to do it. But, before I leave, please memorize the everlasting motto: "lol".
Those three letters mean so much, and so little.
So, laugh a little. Please, for the children.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
How's life?

It's a common question.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
My connection to the Internet is sluggish. It's something worth complaining about, I guess.

Recently, I've been listening to harder rock (notice how I use harder) due to certain people. You know it's time to jump a station when you can hum chains of songs on the playlist. New music sounds fresh. Plus, Tif told me that I need to "feel the beat".

But, the thing is, it's not about feeling the beat. It's about my confidence.

In my mind, I'm often faced with the conflict of Arrogance and Confidence vs. Humbleness and Negative Self-worth. I dislike arrogant people, so I try to shy away from that as much as possible. Arrogance is something distasteful, vile, repulsive, yet so plentiful. But, sometimes it feels like you have to be arrogant to feel happy. I look at myself and see nothing of note, and that's good, or at least I used to feel as if it's supposed to be good.

It's not. It makes me weak, dark, and boring. Boring, boring, boring. Ordinary. A stupid potato. I sit around, average, ordinary, a simple creature. And the thing is, I can't call it "humble" anymore. It's more like "screwed up". Something is wrong.

Arrogant people are vibrant and loud, confident in their stride, simply exciting. They get what they want and they're admired.

I look at myself, and I can't help but try to shove the image away. Pathetic.

I look at myself, and I can't help feeling afraid. Afraid that I'll lose things. If I keep sitting in my chair feeling sorry for myself, I'll lose everything. Tif... friends... schoolwork... my will to exist... If I stop believing in myself, they'll stop believing in me. And then things end.

I'll lose them all because of my frail mindset. I feel pointless. And I know I'm making a mistake. Even if it means brainwashing myself into believing in myself, I know I need to change.

In the classroom, I watch students walk in and sit themselves down. I hunch over my books and peer from the corner of the classroom. All of them, they talk to each other powerfully, exchanging loud jokes, hand gestures. On their faces are these bold smiles. Smiles that don't die, can't die. They're indescribably content, they're so confident. I struggle to convince myself that I can pick myself up and save the future I don't believe in..

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
*rolls eyes*

You need to quit feeling sorry for yourself.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
After much summarization, analysis, and quote-finding from chapters of Moby Dick, I have exhausted my time. I better get to sleep, and fast.

Tomorrow is a new day, and I don't expect to get any work done due to certain QuizBowl tournaments (in which I am more of a spectator than a competitor, due to an extreme knowledge deficit).

But, speaking of my Moby Dick assignment, I haven't finished it. It's a time-hogging piece of work. Spent 3+ hours and I have 40% of it done. The combination of personal inefficiency (I read very slowly) and what I'm reading (I read Moby Dick very, very, very slowly)

You see, that's what I hate about assignments that carry over to Sunday. I end up worrying about them all weekend. The task seems so much heavier when it's been lugged around for 24 hours. And it weighs in on you, always on the back of your mind, always fretting over when it'll get done, if it'll get done.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Tests have been on my mind. Chemistry, French, and Math tests. Why do I worry so much?

It isn't that they're going to be particularly difficult. I guess it's just the most convenient thing to think of. Maybe I think about these tests so much because I believe that thinking about them will improve my grade. Or perhaps I'm not thinking about them at all, it's just what I'm thinking about right now, and it just seems like I've been thinking about them all day.

Or maybe I've been wondering about personal displays of affection, and where they belong.

I really fail to hold an opinion on this, it's just that I'm curious as to what other people think. I mean, personally, I've felt as if displaying affection in school might make other people feel bad. Like showing underpriviledged people an item of great value. Who wants to be showy? Of course, there's also the fact that there isn't a need for these things in school. It's school, it's a place for education, not socialization. But, who can resist? We're human. The lunch table culture embraces this.

Or maybe I've been cooped up in my room all day long. Sunday lethargy... Not the greatest for reading Moby Dick.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Walking through the frigid air to my van, on the sun-splashed black asphalt, I realized what we mean by "Happy Birthday." My door opens with a dull clunk, I start the engine, look out the window and wave to Adam.

The message we send is that every day is special. A moment of life should never be taken for granted, and our creation of the "everyday birthday" is a vehicle for this message. We live for only so long. So, take those risky chances, work to your white-knuckle limits, treat others with exceptional care. Simply, live your life like it's your birthday.

Happy Birthday.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I'm glad that post got erased.

I only feel like that half the time anyways.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
James Kim, a senior editor at CNET, has died: [LINK]

Since my first discovery of CNET a few years ago, I've been using their video reviews to help me decide on various electronics purchases. Often, James Kim would be the one on the screen, explaining and demonstrating the various positives and shortfalls of a given product for my benefit. He was the one who wrote reviews I read, the one who was always on top of the bleeding edge in consumer technology. He died of hypothermia from walking in the snow, trying to find help for his family inside of a snow-stranded car.

So, Mr. Kim won't be on the screen anymore. And it's weird imagining such a person dying. Behind the poor-quality, streaming videos, he didn't seem to be very mortal. To me, he was the sheltered, protected being whose mission it was to show off the latest trends in electronics. He was beyond death, and I could have been certain that he would have remained there, like a picture-perfect memory, on the website forevermore. He would be the old book that would never disappear from the shelf, the text no different read one day than the next. For an eternity he would write and speak to me from his desk. Unchanging, as constant as a hunk of rock.

Being reminded that everyone's a person: a living, breathing, thinking, self-motivated, passionate, self-replicating, individual person. Now, that's something I feast my mind on.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I know I should be studying for finals.

But, it's so easy to procrastinate. So, very difficult to break out of this vegetativeness.

You know what? I like it when I don't have anything to write here. Because it means that there isn't any drama in my life. Short paragraphs, meaningless posts, it means that I'm living life like I want to and that I'm feeling fine. It means I have nothing to get angry about, nothing to get sad about. And who wants to write when you're happy? You start to realize all those things you could have been doing while moping around.

I think Mr. Chen, my guidance counselor, still thinks I'm suicidal. English teacher must have sent down some more of my essays or something. He looked genuinely worried.

Too bad I'm not sad. I guess Mr. Chen won't have anything to find in me!

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: I don't really enjoy posting media besides text because I know it takes a toll on how long it takes this place to load. But, I enjoyed this 10 minute film so much that I felt compelled to shove my cinematic taste onto you. It's an illustration of what it would be like if a chatroom online was a chatroom in reality. Just hit the play button already, dammit.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Spent the morning doing my English project.

Cutting out rounded squares of paper and coloring them for a 5" by 3" booklet on Moby Dick doesn't make for the most exciting weekend.

Later, I got on Second Life for a little bit and chatted with a group of "peacekeeping" German militants in my favorite sandbox. I don't think the sandbox is my favorite anymore. It's filled with newbie garbage, and the lag is intense. Boxes with animated .gifs of Beavis, physics-enabled houses that haven't been linkled together (resulting in a pile of physics-enabled rubble), and giant, rotating smiley faces, you get the idea. The place is a dump.

The "German Army" people told me that they fight for the rights of Germans throughout SL. The guy trying to recruit me told me that they are a "peaceful" army and that they are the ones "who always get attacked". It's always fun to meet people full of bullshit, especially online. It's obvious they're finding an excuse to carry around big guns and look cool. I joked around with them for a little bit and left the simulator, wondering what ever happened to the clean, fast sandbox I enjoyed two months ago.

Unfortunately, after logging out of Second Life, I was lured into clicking the Wolfenstien icon on my desktop. A three hour frag fest ensued. 400+ kills. Now my right eye hurts, and my ring finger is sore from hitting the "throw medpack" button so many times. I feel guilty for indulging myself. I should have been studying for finals. I plan to do that tomorrow.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Ok, fine, I splurged on the 64 pack of crayons.

I think it's so odd that I've established these pseudo-relationships with the colors. Like brick red and purple mountain majesty. Colors that I used ten years ago, and colors I use today. I remember grabbing handfuls of crayons just to figure out what kinds of funky names they had stamped on their covers. I never really understood how anyone could tastefully use all 64 of them. And I never understood why they are arranged so randomly in the box. They should organize it by hues, so users can pick out colors with ease. Not hunt and peck for that darned mahogany crayon.

Things are looking positive. I'm rested and ready for school. I believe this has been an excellent weekend. I hope the coming week will be equally wonderful.

Because there's no point in moping around. There isn't.

PS:Who would have known that crayons can color on laptops too?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I got emotionally unstable in English because of some stupid, insignificant essay. You know, it's really screwed up. I know it's not important, that essays are fine and dandy. But, you know, when I made that mistake, and when I spent my weekend summarizing chapters of Moby Dick as punishment, I thought the hell would be over.

That somehow I would be redeemed. That I would escape that mistake. That I would move on.

It appears I cannot move on. That another thing comes up because of my stupid, stupid, stupid misunderstanding.

And, the mistake repeats itself. The misery perpetuates more misery. By the time you know it, the extra essay will fail my test, lower my GPA, I'll have to quit school and live the homeless life, travel the country with a harmonica and a rice cooker, and die quietly, a fat, wrinkley sleazeball in front of a cheap slot machine in a Mississippi casino.

Wouldn't it be so picture perfect then?

I think I felt so bad about it because I was so confident, so confident that I would be redeemed as I was toiling through each chapter summary. With each copied quote, or Melville's commentary surmization, I justified everything by saying that this was my punishment. That this was the path I would take so I could take the guilt away.

And so, when my english teacher joyously announced the "reward" all of the other perfect students would receive, I felt hopeless. Like those hours of patting myself on the back, the hours of justifying my effort, the hours of rereading, rereading, rereading Moby Dick. Just. Gone. Not there. All for nothing. Worthless.

It felt as if Mrs. Vanhyfte tore my tongue out and threw a bucket of tar and a sack of feathers on me.

And it just doesn't make any sense. That I should be feeling stupid, nonsense emotions like this. When this "reward" is a reward. And I'm not being punished. It's just that I didn't make the cut.

I'm supposed to feel "normal" and everyone else is supposed to feel "extra happy". Not me feeling "extra sad" and everyone else feeling "normal".

But, it happened like it happened. I tell myself that I try to control myself. But, I don't. Seriously. Please, stop. It's stupid to go on reading this. And writing this crap. It doesn't even make it better anymore. It used to.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Darn, <strike> is not allowed in comments!

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Everyone is stressed over finals. I'm stressed over finals.

The days just rush on by. And let them. This is an uncomfortable time.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Weird dreams:

I wake up to a brightly lit hallway. Walls are beige, floors linoleum, air recycled. All around me are my friends. They talk and laugh, joke with each other. The hallways are crowded, I see no windows. I start to walk around, and as my vision comes to me, I see other hallways that branch out from the main hallway.

Looking down at the floor, I see hundreds of plastic shopping bags. I suppose they just appeared. Everyone in the hallway simultaneously picks them up. They mput them on their heads, seal the connection between the edge of the bag and their neck.

I panic.

Running, screaming, ripping bags off of heads, yelling at people I care about the most.

But when they notice me, they just laugh and joke around. Their faces show no sign of distress. Do they notice the bags? Mindless drivel comes out of their mouths, I don't understand, they appear happy.

My head spins, I'm hysterical, crying, confused. I start to shove people out of my way, moving my legs as fast as I can, trying to get out this massive group suicide / plastic bag hat celebration.

At the end of one of the hallways is a window. Outside is a senic view of wooded cliffs overlooking a sparkling ocean.

A man takes my hand and leads me to a chair.

"Do I have a disease where I lose my memory every day?"
"No."
"Then what is this?"
"You have a disease where you see words on things that don't exist."


I wake up.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I've found something I've been looking for a long time: A decent open source video editor. [LINK]

It's called Jahshaka. Odd name, I agree, but it seems powerful from the tidbits I've experienced of it. Much more powerful than Windows Movie Maker 2. I tried Avid FreeDV [LINK] months ago, but it wasn't compatible with my soundcard. Plus, it isn't open source.

I'm still puzzled by Jahshaka's user interface. Video editing is very foreign to me, since I've never really delved into "real" video editing programs before. Hotkeys, menus, buttons, etc. They're all there for me to learn, and for me to use as an excuse to walk away from studying.

This year's theme for finals appears to be: "It ain't over until it's over."

I have Precalculus on the last day of finals, so I'm not going to be able to breeze my last day.

Ugh... How much I lust for Thursday afternoon.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Finals, finals, finals!

It's zero hour, and everything is in a frenzied pace. The fated cram time has arrived! Students and teachers pace rooms all the same. Clocks spin, pencils slip, essays are hammered out. Cries of glee and annihilation. Complete annihilation.

Odd that in a matter of days, it'll all be over. I'll be free to sleep without having to remember Eudora-what's-her-face and how to calculate enthalpy of reactions. Oh, won't it be splendid then...

But, the thing is, it's not then yet. It's now. And right now, I've got five finals.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Second day of finals.

And I finally realize that the "stress pain" has just been the soreness from bad posture while taking tests.

Three more to go.
Three more.

No drama, no emotion. Just have to get it over with. Nothing exciting. Fritz.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
It is that day. You know, that day.

Lethargic though. Supposed to be hyper, but I'm just tired.

I guess this is recovery time.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I blame Christmas.

Yes, I'm lacking because I'm in a complacent mood. Things are alright, and you know what? My life is alright enough that it doesn't have to be nagged, written about, attacked, coaxed, described. It's great. No school. Painting in the afternoon, the occasional Need For Speed break, mid-afternoon snack. It's like kindergarten, but without the sticky hands and claustrophobic bathroom.

Presents, yes presents. What have I bagged this year? Nice stuff. I have a new purse/bag/item-holder, two actually, and a comfortable fleece jacket thanks to Tiffany. A tamagotchi from Ryan. Two video games, Need For Speed Underground 2 and Geist (which is damaged and won't play, so I must take it back to JL Records tomorrow. I very much hope their return policies on used games are lenient). The video games I bought for my sister and I.

So that's this year. I love it all. Functional, fun, random. A good mix of my favorite flavors of consumerism.

I'm glad the Wii is on the scene. It means the Gamecube is old news. Ten dollar bargain-basement used games, here I come!

Oh, this winter break is swell. Even if it is rainy.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
"What's your job?" Y.T. asks.
"I'm a harpooneer," he says.
"Like in Moby Dick?" Y.T. likes this idea. She read that book in school. Most of the people in her class, even the power tools, thought that the book was totally entrenched. But she liked all the stuff about harpooning.
"Nah. Compared to me, those Moby Dicksters were faggots."

-Snow Crash, Ch 47

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I'm hitting the ground running.

Just came back from a week long vacation.

Also have just received word that I will be driving a team or Robotics people around town tomorrow to ask businesses to donate money.

To me, this is sudden.

But, to the system, it was planned.

The 1747 Robotics Team has always felt like a freestyle thing. You get a call the day before the assignment. It's a rush.

I don't know if I love it or hate it. I just do it. Can't think about it. Like diving. I just had to do it. And I don't know how I'll feel at the end, if I'll regret it or feel proud of what I did. I imagine that a lot of people in the world feel the same things I'm feeling.

Sleep. Now that's something that you don't plan. But, it's not at all a free-form sort of thing either.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Driving home from the first "real" robotics meeting, all I could think was: "Damn. The radio is already playing jazz."

Jazz means it's past 9pm. Past 9pm means that I better hurry and sleep.

So, the robotics season has started. So will school. It's an overwhelming but justified venture, I think. Working as a team is hard. I feel socially retarded sometimes. With me, talking gets awkward fast.

That's life. It's not Walgreens, that's for sure. But hey, with nothing else to complain about, I'm in good shape.

This feeling. Being busy enough to not be able to stop and think about it all. Bad, good? Like I said, I can't even let myself stop and think about how bad or good it is. Just, let it happen.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: You aren't posting as much...

lol! you're right life isnt walgreens. i think its good that you dont have as much time to mull over it all. from experience the world's problems and even general problems arent solved by just one person, and its much less disparing to not have to think about it all the time. find something to blame. like capitalism(it works for my boyfriend) i wish he had something to keep him from thinking >.> lol. im home sick with strep throat, so i hope you dont mind me reading your archives. ive had you bookmarked forever and i never really read anything, so i felt bad. and then youre all no no i dont want people to read my blog.
Im at odds. and since i assume youre at school i cant ask. soooo........i dont know yet! but ill see you some time at school.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Haven't posted in awhile.

Now that I know people are reading this, the writing has become a lot less personal. That pisses me right off. Nowadays, feel the urge to hide what I say, even at home, staring at this anonymous blank text box. What if I say something that is misinterpretted? What if someone gets angry at me for saying this-or-that? Life isn't all optimistic and full of dainty little elves throwing chocolates. It's full of some bad things. Of course, I reveal them here and then my act's exposed, eh?

When so many people know who I pretend to be, who I am, who I'm not, I just feel so shallow. Deep people are modest, they don't go and flaunt their emotions online. It's sickening. It's absurd. And here I am. I must be the most shallow person on Earth. Always trying to fish for compliments, trying to boost my ego, and finding nothing real. It's like this twisted, selfish, idiotic passion of mine or something.

You know?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Everyone has a different way of expressing their emotions. Yours just so happens to be on an online site as where mine is writing disgustingly-long stories for English.

And the reason some people know you inside and out is because:

a. They've known you for a long time

b. Some people are just good at "reading" emotions

c. There are those who just care about your wellbeing
Sorry. Me won't read no more.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: It's very powerful, talking with other people. When it's not banter or small talk, the level of conversation goes to the level where it can change how you react to the world.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I worked on [hbranimation.com] for a long time today. CSS is easy, but getting everything right isn't. And getting the page to display right on IE, Firefox, and Opera is terribly hard. Especially since I'm very new to the whole layout-by-CSS concept. Right now, the site is just a template. I'll have time to add content next weekend.

At Jefferson, I worked five hours on the actual animation. All scenes are complete-ish. Now, it's just the credits that have to be done. Then rendering. Then compositing (oh, the joy of compressing your dear child into a pixellated pile of poop.) All this work for a mediocre, 30-second animation.

But, I think it's important, this whole being an animator for the robotics team. Certainly, I wouldn't have learned this much CSS in a day if it wasn't for being on the Animation team.

Soon, I will need to come up with newspaper article ideas. The problem is, the things I enjoy reading about aren't what the school wants to read about. It's tough coming up with ideas. I think being busy has eased the pain. You can't feel from a frostbitten hand.

Random tidbit: Today, for the first time in a year, I threw a snowball. The crunch between a sphere of snow and a road sign is so satisfying.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Apparently, I aimed my "Maverick Rev-6" a little too far to the right. Almost lost a nerf dart in my closet. I spent the last five minutes of my life looking for this orange nerf dart.

Recently, I've been working with a partner on the robotics team's website. I don't know any php, but am planning to learn and use it for the website. I guess I fancy myself as a graphic designer, but all of my stuff is really pretty shoddy. Oh well. I'll work with what I have, with who I've got. It's a team effort, man.

Yeah, personal moments have gone away. Do I have a personality? Or am I this shallow, planar object. This emotionless machine, autonomous, idiot who types without reason. Without purpose.

Because really, nothing is on my mind at the moment besides tomorrow's homework and the nerf gun in my lap. Am I that clueless?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I read in a book somewhere that you can improve your level of happiness if you take the time to think of three things that you are grateful for each day. But, I'll wait until I'm desperate. I need to save up my happiness energy. Right now, I'm in that "I don't care, blah, blah, blah" attitude that appears to invade the life of everyone nowadays. Just floating along, not really anchored to a goal or a task or a mission.

I felt jealous today. I felt dark today. I felt worried. But, I also felt lucky. And I felt satisfied.

It's just a mix, you know? And you can really pull anything from it, besides the idea that all of this really doesn't matter. Next week, it'll be the same deal.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Is there a point to mulling over things?

Just sitting there and feeling sorry for yourself. Wanting to pound the desk, and then pound your face into the desk. Wanting to hurt, but not to die. Wanting nothing, the comprehension that you don't deserve what you've got. That some poor kid in a western European country would walk a thousand miles barefoot just to sit in such a classroom. Knowing that it really doesn't mean anything. Your feelings. Your effort. The mess on the floor, the clarity of the sky.

But, still, there is an unthinking core that ignores the facts and pursues the primal instincts to feel.

The cafeteria is filled with people you don't know in colorful outfits, spouting foul language, watching The Price is Right. And you realize that they don't mean anything. They just are. They'll "grow up". Whatever that means.

And the classroom is filled with trendy collared shirts and tidy sweaters. And someone finishes the test before another person. And you think about how much of a failure you are. But, you know, somewhere, that you aren't a failure. And you're just saying this because it makes you feel safe, for some reason beyond comprehension.

item.title: Where have I been? Happy? Sad? In love? Reading, h...
item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Where have I been? Happy? Sad? In love? Reading, hearing, and thinking about comments that personal blogs are horrible wretches of muck? Yes. That's where I've been.



A six day weekend follows an exciting blizzard. It's a coat of white. It penetrates all. Out of the window, your eyes wander. And then, bam! The whiteness of the earth is a poignant reminder of the weakness of ourselves to the faceless entity of nature. We are nearing the end of this lazy span of time.



Lazy... Although this giant snow day has been relaxing, it's easy to lose track of time and piddle it away doing mindless things. A world without deadlines. A nirvana? No, something less ideal. So, here I go, listing what I've accomplished, trying to justify my heavy piddling.





List of 2007 Snow Day Week Accomplishments:







[LINK] I did a little bit of the mTurk thing. Nabbed $1.70. For an hour of work. Minimum wage is for losers.

Downloaded Firefox 2 [LINK] and a number of Firefox plugins. It's been out for ages, and I felt guilty for not touching it. I'm ditching Opera for the moment because it crashes on my computer. Plus, installing mouse gestures on Firefox replaces most of why I used Opera in the past. Call me a traitor.







Worked on the robotics team website [LINK] with Chris. It's not that great. It's been hard work to get it to where it's at, really. Chris and I are probably the most on task people on the team. The problem with the website is that there isn't any content for it. No interesting links, no team picture, no exciting stories, no nothing. Tomorrow is the open house and I don't think they'll be very impressed with the website. Also, it is powerfully depressing to think about how few people will actually visit the website and use it. The rest of the team doesn't seem very appreciative either. Oh well. It's the learning experience, eh? On a positive note, the animation was uploaded in a timely manner.



I had to fudge a bit when I had to come up with the "written consent" for the music I used. Completely justified fudging though. The music I used is under a Creative Commons Public Domain license, so I have the rights to use it in the animation. I'd say that's pretty legit "written consent", don't you think?





Made a valentines present for Tif using origami paper and chocolate. I like the final product, and hope that she likes it as well. On the receiving end of things, I got a sketchbook and a pack of drawing pencils. I've been secretly wanting a new sketchbook, especially after the water damage on my old one (caused by a rainy summer day). She's sharp.









Updated this blog. Yay. Go mindlessly posting images for the sake of showing images.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Showed the robotics team animation at open house today. I was very discouraged when I found out that West Lafayette's animation team didn't improve very much. The Jefferson team didn't even have an animation to show (I shouldn't blame them, I was supposed to help them make one). Ah well... Below is team 1747's animation.



Browsing chiefdelphi.com, a forum for robotics teams (and thus robotics teams' animators), I found a few animations that are miles ahead of ours. I know the mentor from team 1625 personally (Pete Casey), and he's a nice guy. Very impressive stuff these folks strut:
Team 114 (Los Altos, CA) Animation: [LINK]
Team 1625 (Winnebago, IL): [LINK]

This evening was spent drilling holes into the robot. Finally, some quality time to connect with the thing.

 

I love happy endings.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I'm honored by your use of the bassoon solo in your video.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The robot is finally done. In the crate, ready to be driven away. My second build season is finished.

I find it stunning how quickly this mid-winter time period goes. Twirling a pencil around, I wonder if swimmers, or football players, or basketball players get the same feeling when they're playing their sport.

I can tell you that diving felt like an eternal bucket of pain. Or rather, it was an eternal bucket of pain.

Time to rest? Is it really that time again?

I feel anxious when I'm around the tech team now. I can tell that I'm not part of "them" anymore. I guess the Fetted Inner Core has abandoned me. I don't blame them. I haven't been to any of their all-night sessions, I haven't put a single bolt into the bot. Doing all the computer work is fun, but now I feel distant, pointless, stupid. It's easy to get depressed about not having a real role on the team. It's why people quit day jobs to become beggars, or start up communes in the forest. It's why people jump off of buildings, and it's why people dedicate themselves to other people. Everybody must have a role.

Do I have a role?

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes I think about how stupid I am,
And how there isn't a way to fix my mistakes,
And why there is nothing to look forward to,
And what I could've done, but didn't.
But the realization is sudden.
I'm just like the rest of the world.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Mistakes aren't meant to be fixed; they are there to teach us. If mistakes didn't exist how would life teach us to learn? The only way you are like the rest of the world is in thinking that you are like them, even so I am part of the rest of the world and you aren't like me.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I don't know how things go. I'll talk about strife and dark emotions. Grief.

You know, it takes a lot of power to box things up. To tie the knots tight enough to not let a single strand creep out. Pull, pull, pulling still. Strands that take hold of rational thinking, rational actions. To box those up, shove them aside for another day. It takes a lot of power. I don't know how people have this incredible grip on their emotions.

This afternoon, I walked into a gas station.

It was after Quizbowl. Couldn't think of anything except how inferior I was to the world. How incredibly silly it was for me to seem smart.

Drove the minivan into the dingy, oily parking lot. Turned the key. Engine murmured and died. Sky was overcast. Nothing very attractive to look at. Propane tanks stared back at me from their cage. They had nothing to say, the blue rhino has nothing to say either.

Gas was too expensive. Didn't buy any of that. Couldn't. Not with three dollars. Went in and looked for something to distract me.

As I was walking through the aisles, I wondered if anyone would come in to rob the cashier. Wondered if they'd shoot me. Wondered about the girl in the paper a few months ago. They shot her. Why wouldn't they shoot me? With a gun to my head, some random, ultra-violent rubbish of society would take me out. Click, bang. A spectacular bang. Wouldn't it be great?

And so I tried to find something. Maybe a cheap drink. To keep the mind off of stupid things like that.

Ninety-nine cents. Energy drink. "Lime-tastic" flavor. Perfect.

Bought the thing, walked out. Walked along the cement curb. Soon, the asphalt ended. Tall grass, Wal-Mart plastic bags, trusted metal parts of all sorts. They waved peacefully in the wind. I wish I could be peaceful. I took a sip of Mister Ninety-Nine cents. Cars rumbled on down the gray slab of government-paved goodness. Rust buckets rolling on down. Where?

I trotted back to my own rust bucket. Shiny key clacked into place, lights flashed. All systems were now ready. Ready for me. Ready for my foot to push, hands to steer, mind to calculate, to decide if it was safe to change lanes.

Pulling out of the parking lot, I took another sip of Mister Cheap Energy Drink. He tasted like gummi bears, the white kind.

I didn't care to be killed by anyone anymore.

Distraction. It's how I tie up my box.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
And nothing to look backward to with pride,
And nothing to look forward to with hope,
So now and never any different. - The Death of the Hired Man by Robert Frost

I am a hypocrite.

I wish I didn't care about my GPA. I wish I could really believe that it's just a number. To not lie to myself. To believe that a student's actions are more important than the number the teacher stamps on their forehead. Maybe it has something to do with my identity. It's an identity that manifests itself in everyone I talk to. It's constantly in my thought. It's how I act. It's what I try to be. It's what other people thing I'm supposed to be. It's why I envy. Why I lust for goals I'll never ever reach.

Due to circumstances, I will soon be parting from the wonderful 4.0. The thing I've lied to you about for so long. In reality, I put a lot of value on it. When I lose it, my identity will no longer be as it used to be. Who am I? Am I being arrogant in harboring such feelings?

Is it worth making a scene about? Absolutely not. Or maybe I'm trying to justify my failure. The failure, it's a result of what I did, what I didn't, what I should've, what just wasn't. The loss is my fault. My stupid, arrogant, foolish, fault. I didn't solve the problems I needed to solve. Time was up. Papers collected. Bam. So, that's how it went. And that's how I feel about it. No one cares.

Didn't want to talk all day. Just felt angry and sick. So ashamed. Mad. Wanted to forget, wanted to believe in something. Wanted to be a good at something. A talent? Specialty? Passion? Everyone's special, right? People can create art, people are good at reading, people can sell used cars. Me?

Nothing. I have access to many great things. I'd love to keep them, for them to become part of me. To sketch out an identity for myself.

But, at the end of the day, on the inside, I have nothing to call my own. Everything's been loaned.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
What would I have done?
Closed my eyes?
And it's gone.

What is?

Whatever.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
It all really comes down a simple question: "Why am I here?"

In about 48 hours, I have to hand over a list of classes I'm interested in taking at Purdue. The counselors gave us a website to go to. The website has a list of every class available to all Purdue students. The website's list is incredibly overwhelming for me. Just the large number of career paths.

The website's list is a reminder of my failure.

I have no idea what I'm going to do with my life.

I've said it a million times, but it doesn't solve my problem. I can talk to it with all my friends and it won't solve my problem. I can write about it on this blog. I can keep myself awake thinking about it. Nothing is there to solve my problem but myself.

To imagine, some stupid person who has trouble making a choice like this. I'm that stupid person. The answer should be obvious. I should be who I want to be. Work for something I believe in. After all, something I'll be doing for the rest of my life should be something I'm interested in and passionate about.

But, I have no passion. Or interest. Or any sort of belief. I read stories of scientists, researchers, actors, sports stars, artists, and programmers. The stories describe how young Dr. Doe was passionate about health after his mother and father died from an unknown disease. Or a mathematician that has been solving Rubik's cubes since he was five. I'm not one of those special people who have a passion or heroic incentive. I don't care if cancer kills us all. I don't care if we're stuck in the Digital Age for the next thousand years.

I'm a nobody, an insignificant member of a huge ecosystem. Why should I care? If I died tomorrow, nobody would care. Caring is for the people in the stories. They can save the world. I can't. I won't.

I'm not talented. I have no particular amazing skill. I'm not good at math. Not good at memorizing lists. Not good at reading. Not good at music. Not good at throwing javelins. So, is it now when I accept that my future will be one of obscure worthlessness? Of pointless stupor, a valueless, dark void?

As time passes by, the choice is getting harder. What do I want to do with the rest of my life? I want to be successful, but I don't believe in myself. Fourty Seven hours, and hope's still hard to find. It's horrible that it's me who has the littlest. I feel terrible.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I'm very scared.

After hitting my head against the desk for a little while, I realized that I live an unhappy life. I don't know why. I've got all of these things here to help me. And I'm not being helped. It's sad that all of my friends will be gone in a few years. In two decades I won't be myself. A decade or two after that, my family will be gone. In a few more decades, I'll be gone. It's hard to have hope in these "support" systems, when you know how alone you are in the long run.

While not understanding my physics problems, I feel worthless. What people are finishing in minutes I'm taking hours. And I don't even finish the problems. I just sit there and hurt myself. Hopelessly thinking that somehow, if I punish myself enough, the answer will pop out. They never do. I feel more incompetent afterward.

And deadlines. Just more deadlines. Missing school because of Robotics is killing me. I'm prepared for neither. I'm just dragging down both. We probably lost the last regional because of me. I can't do anything right. I don't want to deal with anything anymore. But, I don't have the courage to let go. And tasks are compounding. If I don't stay up late tonight, then how will I manage tomorrow? Or the next day? I just get tired, tired, more tired. Lose efficiency. Takes hours to do simple assignments. Have to stay up later. What happens when I don't have done what I need done?

If I start falling off now, I may never catch myself.

But, what's the point? I suppose I'm falling already.

My homework is still on my desk.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
The mind would rather wander elsewhere. But, same thoughts. No one wants to read the same thing over again. Especially when it's needlessly emotional or dramatic: "I'm stupid... blah, blah, blah... I can't finish my homework... blah, blah, blah... I have no future... blah, blah, blah"

I read somewhere that you could transform your mindset by doing a few mental chores every day. One of these chores is to name three things that made today worth living.

Maybe this'll work (or not...)

Today was worth living today because:

1. Scouting at the robotics meeting went smoothly. Although Logan and related drive-team members have not expressed appreciation of our efforts, I believe that this has been the best attempt at comprehensive robot-scouting yet. The scouting sheets even feature pictures.

2. I played Jenga, and felt like a somebody for an hour or two.

3. I was finally able to use the green hair paint I bought a few days ago. How often does one have a chance to dye their hair green?

So there's my pathetic attempt at being optimistic. I remember participating in the Optimist Club Speech Contest. I even won a trophy. Where are the old days?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Finally something not so depressing?

By the way Ryo, the scouting in the second half of the day we freaking amazing. With Margarette comming to the pits and writing up descriptions of the robots capabilities and the pictures and everything. That helped us out a lot in some of the matches. It was great knowing exactly what we were up against next, I loved it. If you guys can keep that up, that'll make me incredibly happy. Oh, and team 292's had a really interesting scouting thing that I'll show you, that was really handy also. So don't worry, I most difinantly appreciate it, and it came in good use.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Today, I spent a few hours working on an electrical circuit for a physics project. After many hotglue-to-flesh burns, it was time to test it with batteries. So, I put the batteries in. No lights. Much sadness.

It's due in a week. And I've got chemistry things that I haven't finished that are due this week. Two tests tomorrow. Mother wants me to get tutored in math. It seems like thieves have taken off with my peace. Now, it's war. The whole thing's backwards. Busy, busy. Everyone is busy, but I still feel alone. Personal emails are getting shorter and less personal. I'm nervous. Can't sleep. When I'm happy in front of other people, I feel like I'm lying. To myself and to them. The things I say to myself don't improve the situation.

I hope tomorrow makes it better, not worse.

A summary of today:

Pros
-I'm not dead.

Cons
-I spent a few hours on the first six questions of the Chemistry worksheet. Then, I stared at problem #7 for half an hour. Gave up on the problem. I have over ten more problems left. Due at an unknown (but soon) date.
-Physics project is still unfinished.
-I still don't understand how to calculate resistance, potential difference, current, and capacitance. The test is on Tuesday. I'm very worried.
-Tiffany hasn't replied to my email. I've been checking all day.
-My room is a mess of tangled wire, assorted cutting utensils, paper, markers, cardboard, dried glue, and christmas tree lights. All for nothing.
-I'm frustrated with myself for not having studied earlier for my two tests tomorrow.
-I'm frustrated with myself for not being more diligent about getting my chemistry homework done.
-I'm frustrated with myself for not finishing my physics project.
-I'm frustrated with myself for not understanding schoolwork.
-I'm frustrated with myself for not finishing my SAT essay.

All in all, today was great. Lots of sunshine, light, puffy clouds, and a gentle breeze. So I can't blame the day. I'm the one that's a disappointing failure.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
It's something that has to be accepted.

My quality of life right now is the highest it's going to be in the next decade or so. Everything's downhill. It has to be. Independence? Pssh, what an abstract word. If that's all there is to gain, there will be many dark moments ahead.

Really, it's absurd to think that my life now is stressful. In a year or two, I'll be yearning for today. In four years, I'll be yearning for what life's like in two years. My life is a breeze. I'll just keep telling myself that and I'll believe it, right? Just lie to myself. What a novel idea.

No more mental cursing at myself because it's Thursday night and homework is due on Monday morning, and no more of this being stressed out over nothing. It's crazy. Why do I get so wound up? Holiday? What's that?

Just accept it, stupid, it's going to happen no matter what. The anxiety is purposeless. Listen to reason, for once in your life.

My future is bright? Bright? Oh really? So bright it sears my eyes into painful, white spheres of jelly. It can't get any better than that, nope.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: But hey, in a couple years, you can attend all the cons you want.
That's a good point. Oh, I can't wait.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Looked at my SAT scores.

They're not very good.

No point in getting angry, or sad, or confused.

Won't change. The records. Or anything else.

Might as well try to forget.

Good night.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
It's a battlefield. SAT scores.

Spent the day hassling other people about it. Having myself hassled over it. Found out that my score is lowest of my peers. Don't want to care about it, but on the inside, I still feel a little empty. And it's arrogant to want so badly to be better than everyone else, but who can help it? The whole compare-scores-with-your-friends thing, although essential, does nothing but complicate the situation. The top-scorer tries to console everyone else, everyone else attempts to justify their failure, the lowest-scorer forces everyone else to shove off. Feelings getting hurt, and you can already tell how separate we all are.

Sure, we're all friends today, but in a few years? It's scary to think about being torn away from a comfortable situation. And having to fend for one's self. Away from quality assurance and 100% guarantees. Away from pals that cover your back.

Then, I'm going to realize how alone I am.

Feelings, feelings, feelings.

Why can't there just be a middle ground where I can live? Like a slice of toast. Somewhere simple. Tired of shifting my eyes and feeling ashamed. Tired of having positive moments crushed. Mistakes. Never any right choices, or uplifting, inspiring events. Just myself screwing up.

I don't even know what I'm talking about anymore. I bet I have never known. I should leave it all behind on the weekend. Stop pretending. Straighten out. Stop screwing up.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Okay, that's it. Listen to me, and listen to me GOOD! (However grammatically incorrect that is).

That "I suck at life. Why isn't there a better place" attitude is the same thing that all of us go through.

I'm going to use a little example I call my own personal life. After having either failed or gotten a C on literally every math test this year, I just kept thinking "This bites." And really, it does. But it only hurts in the present. You just have to get up, adapt, and move on with your life. If you don't, you're not going to get anywhere.

Even earlier today, I was shattered to learn that my bassoon duet in Chamber Winds sucked, and badly at that. I knew at that moment that I wasn't cut out for the elites. Throughout the rest of the day I moped around doing no good for anyone. But as I sit here now, typing on my bedroom floor, I realize that I'm just going to have to do better next time.

Your words: "Stop screwing up." are completely illogical. WE ALL MAKE MISTAKES. Here's a hint: you're only human. You're not some god-academic machine. Ryo Chiba, you are flesh and blood like every one of us. You will screw up for the rest of your life. You will make horrible mistakes until the day you die, one of those mistakes might even make it the day you die. To tell yourself to "stop screwing up" is completely illogical and you know it.

You honestly think I'm done yet? Hardly. You're not alone. You have wonderful friends. Me, Amanda, Ryan, Alex, Andrew, Rachael, Keenan. Need I go on? Plus you have a girlfriend who loves you. If you ask me, that's one of the few high school relationships that will actually flourish and become something divine and pure. Coming from me, that's high praise.

I hate to play reality-control, but sometimes we all just need a good slap in the face. You've provided me with one through myself.

Now get up.

College admissions = full-out war

Lying, scheming, random acts of deviousness... sometimes it makes envy those that have gotten past it and well out of their hands.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Asking myself questions like, "Why the fuck? Are you really that fucking retarded?" generally doesn't improve my mood after looking at my any sort of math test.

Luckily, I have lunch with Tif right after the period. It all slowly washes away. Over the dull salads and greasy fries, the talking releases something. But I'm still afraid. Why? I don't know. So, I pull deeper on the rope that's attached to whatever I'm afraid of. I still can't see it. I tug. More rope. Something far, far into the abyss.

The tense atmosphere re-establishes itself in French. I heavily dislike that class now.

Unfinished, but this lack of goal. It gets to your head.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
Top Four Reasons Why I Dislike French Class

1. The teacher quickly and ruthlessly isolates those who perform well and those who don't, and makes sure the rest of the class knows your status. For low-performing students (like me), a look of disgust and a quick flick of the wrist are all you get for that 20pt worksheet. For others, she lifts her hand to her mouth and makes bothersome noises to celebrate that person's achievement. Although this was cute for the first week, now it just makes me feel isolated, alone, hopeless, and stupid. I believe she finds great pleasure in causing pain in those who are not as skilled in languages.

2. She picks favorites. From how she picks certain students to have conversations with, to who she uses as the "ideal student" example, it is obvious that she has a heavy bias for/against certain people in class. Ass-kissers are often showered with bubbles and confetti (I'm not kidding here.) Personally, I have a strong resentment against such ass-kissers. How come the teacher didn't "carelessly forget" to find my mistakes on the test? It's because I don't pretend to live in a happy-fun-bogus-"I love my french teacher" world.

3. The general anxiety and tenseness of the classroom leaves me with an upset stomach and a pacing heart. Even our seating configuration (three rows on each side of the room, students facing the center) contributes to the negative atmosphere. Sitting in class feels like working in a concentration camp. You could be singled out at any second, your grade executed, your dignity burned, and your soul shot. All the while, she sits at her desks and acts benign. If you ask her a question, she may refuse to answer it, on grounds that it would be too much help. I think her explanation is absurd. You're here to teach damn it, and we're never going to learn if you just stick your head into a hole and call yourself helpful.

4. The teacher feels the need to assert her power. This results in frequent harsh (and unjust) disciplinary measures for students who have absentmindedly forgotten to shut up at a given moment, or have forgotten their books, homework, or another material. Such measures are done in front of the entire class. While you're watching the poor student get hammered, you are both relieved, angry, depressed, and hopeful. Relieved because you're not the one about to be killed. Angry because the killing is unwarranted. Depressed because nothing will change until she retires. Hopeful because you didn't sign up for AP French.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Not really that much related, but I thought I'd share this with you.

I don't usually like to judge people, but the general consensus is that our English teacher spouts 100% random irrelevant BS.

Well, they say imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, but she's not exactly impressed with all the BS we turn in.

We recently had to write two letters. The subject was pretty dumb, so a lot of people tried to be funny, satirical, whatever. They all got zeroes. One guy who actually wrote a pretty real letter got a zero obviously because he had a reputation for turning in BS.

Anyway, our teacher scheduled a parent-teacher meeting with one of my friends to discuss his BS. (This is the one that tried to create several Wikipedia articles about said English teacher.) My friend began loading up a big list of everything that she's done poorly or wrong to get ready for battle. Results are forthcoming.

A lot of people treat her class like one big joke, and many of them have found pretty creative ways to get back at her. I can't say she's playing favorites. It's more like she's keeping track of the people who spout BS to counter her.

item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
So I finally got around to making the blog that I've always been meaning to make. Being winter break, I figured this would be a good chance. Here are some things I plan to put on here.
  • Interesting web links. I've been using delicious for awhile, but since it looks like they may be going away, I'll put links here. Being doubly advantageous in that more people will be able to see them, and the data is easily exportable.
  • Thoughts that at the moment seem clever, but upon future review will only trigger nostalgia for a more innocent time.
  • Photos and reflections on those photos. Sometimes there are very pretty things that I find necessary to catalog.
Maybe more. Planning on making a static page at www.ryochiba.com for resume/project data later this week. I've had these illustrations sitting on my drive for ages, waiting to be translated onto the web. Explanation of why the site looks like it does: I was going for something whimsical and clean. I guess it's a take on having one's head "in the clouds". Extra puns for the fact that this blog's purpose is to catalog things "in the cloud". Also wanted to make evening and night versions of the skin too for fun. But, maybe it's not worth it. This will do for now.

item.content:encoded: This is a short expository video on maid cafe's in Japan made by CNN. It's fun to watch because Joe, the man in the video, is convinced that these maid cafe's are about female submission and sexuality, when they are not. I'm not a Japanophile or anything, and I think that most people would mirror Joe's reaction to maid cafe's, but at the same time, I think that it's a little disappointing that CNN's people are closed-minded like the rest of us. Favorite Quote: "They don't have the National Organization for Women over there or something, *laughter*?"

item.title: Compulsion and Fun
item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I read this a couple weeks ago and it changed the way I thought about games.
I usually distinguish between Fun and Compulsion, when talking about gameplay. World of Warcraft and other RPGs have a lot of innate Compulsion mechanisms, but usually also give you some Fun to balance it out. Most games have a mix between Fun and Compulsion, but games that keep you playing for 60 hours and have a strong collection element are usually heavy on the Compulsion side, with varying success on the Fun side.
I personally think that Compulsion taps into some hardwired reptile-brain behavior in people, which came about because covering all the territory or collecting all the [valuable stuff] was beneficial to survival at some point in human history.
You can usually tell if you’ve been the victim of Compulsion without Fun, if you end a game much later than you intended, and promptly feel kind of stupid for not turning it off 3 hours earlier.

And besides video games, the power of compulsion surrounds us in everyday life: Frequent flier miles, retail rewards programs, collecting stamps. Not that it's bad or anything (Although I do admit to enjoying an Adbusters mag every once in awhile). It's just useful to step back every once in awhile and realize that "stuff" is not likely to be what happiness is made of, whether it be virtual or otherwise. [LINK to a Google Document]

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I've felt a response to the many Facebook notes describing my friends' stress, anger, depression, and annoyance.

Oddly, it's a positive response.

Am I sadistic in being positive when I read about my peer's negativity? Do I take some sick pleasure in reading the details of others' woes?

It bothers me that reading over everyone else's misfortune makes me feel better, but I can't seem to change how I react. My sky feels less cloudy when the grass isn't greener on the other side.

Don't tell anybody.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Don't worry, that's pretty normal. Its always comforting to know that the grass is dead and withered everywhere, not just where you're standing.

Don't tell anybody, as if you haven't been pouring out the trials and tribulations of your life into a Google subsidiary for the past four years?

That's OK. I'll take comfort knowing that if I ever get depressed and blog about it, it'll lift somebody's spirit.
Irony.

item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: Grading papers all afternoon seems like a boring job, but every once in awhile, you strike comedic gold. The paper is unedited since it was turned into me to grade. Sadly, today was my last day at work. School starts on Tuesday, and maybe I'll get back to writing on this. School means depression. Depression means violent verbal blog outbursts.

item.title: Red Day
item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: Living in the city for two years makes the space required for comfort much smaller. Seeing the horizon is replaced by seeing across the street. And walking outside becomes an art in navigating man-made canyons. A shallow inset of a gigantic maze. Chaos overlapped on gridded order. And coming back to the city is always accompanied by a reassuring claustrophobia. I'm finally back in Los Angeles. Tomorrow is the first day of class. Links: "A Healthy Diet for the Mind" - blog post about how "you are what you read". Side scrolling websites - a collection of interesting side scrolling websites I found on Smashing Magazine. "Rock Star" developers - I feel arrogant condemning other people, so I hesitate. But, it does bother me when anyone asks for a coding "guru". Why Microsoft is dead - Doesn't have a lot of data, but it's a fun little read.

item.title: Asian Parenting: a contentious issue
item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
A few days ago, I was reading Amy Chua's article on the WSJ about Asian parenting, I was surprised that something like this got published. But I suppose that's what it's meant to do: polarize. We feel strongly about how we were raised, but each family is different. I guess I can't say anything against the strict parenting style, as I've never been raised as such, but at the same time, I feel strongly against it. As if it threatens me, and how I was raised. Amy writes,
Chinese parents believe that they know what is best for their children and therefore override all of their children's own desires and preferences. That's why Chinese daughters can't have boyfriends in high school and why Chinese kids can't go to sleepaway camp. It's also why no Chinese kid would ever dare say to their mother, "I got a part in the school play! I'm Villager Number Six. I'll have to stay after school for rehearsal every day from 3:00 to 7:00, and I'll also need a ride on weekends." God help any Chinese kid who tried that one.
Don't get me wrong: It's not that Chinese parents don't care about their children. Just the opposite. They would give up anything for their children. It's just an entirely different parenting model.
I also enjoyed reading Jean Hsu's response today.
First generation immigrants want the best for their children, as do all parents, but they really are not that qualified to judge what will lead to a successful and fulfilling life in the United States.  Their narrow-minded formula for success (great grades, ivy league, medical school, high paying job) may work for some, but it alienates those who might find success elsewhere.  Many highly successful and happy people have gotten to where they are by leaving a stable job to try to start their own company, pursuing a career in the performing arts, or majoring in something other than science, math or engineering, yet all these would be highly discouraged by most Asian parents.  When I have children of my own, I hope I will be able to stress the importance of education while they are young, but allow them the freedom to make decisions and mistakes for themselves.

item.title: Data Tuesdays
item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded: So, a couple weeks before winter break, I put together a GPS Shield for the Arduino. Below is a picture of the apparatus. Found that a tupperware works great as a container. After a few days, got it to work pretty well. It has issues in buildings, as can be seen in the map. On a side note, I also love how my entire room and desk is white. I live in a giant lightbox. Anyway. it still boggles my mind how invisible and pervasive GPS chips are in our everyday gadgets. It takes your breath away to think about the satellites. I think this animated gif sums up the richness of it all. To think, there are thirty one silent metal machines in the frozen emptiness of space, broadcasting messages through the blue sky down to us animals. And they do it all to help us drive to Starbucks, or Grandma's, or guide missiles to a house in the desert. [Raw Data] So, today I went to class carrying around a little ear that can hear into the sky. Processed the data and got a map. Slowly zooming out on the map gave me some insight as to how little our day-to-day motions are on this little blue planet. Not to use our insignificance to diminish our egos, but to use it to admire the vastness of what has yet to be explored.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Have you seen the Reverse Geocache? http://arduiniana.org/projects/the-reverse-geo-cache-puzzle/

item.title: A decade and five
item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
A social networking site with 100,000 groups, 1.5 million members, eventually acquired by Amazon, with features such as:
when a user entered travel plans into the calendar, the service would cross-reference the destination with the address book, as well as the user's contacts' travel plans; the site would then notify users when they would cross paths with their contacts.
All in 1996? Read the Wikipedia article about PlanetAll.

item.title: Brain Machine Review
item.dc:creator: ryochiba
item.content:encoded:
I made one of these widgets for Ryan a couple months ago, but unfortunately didn't have any time to play with it myself before shipping it off. After a winter break of back-of-the-mind curiosity, I finally caved in and bought a kit for myself. Here are some notes on my experiences with it. What is it? The brain machine consists of two LED's that rapidly flash into your eyes and an apparatus that plays binaural beats through headphones. It claims to
Relax and rejuvenate as your brain synchronizes to a wonderful meditative state, and enjoy as you hallucinate beautiful colors and patterns from your subconscious mind!
 Although the claims bring to mind the days of the snake oil salesman, the machine is actually mildly entertaining. According to the build page, the program in the chip lasts for 14 minutes. Here's a brief narrative of my 14 minute experience: Glasses on. So here I am, typing this out while this thing flashes in my face.The first thing you notice is how annoying the sound is, but it works in keeping out most, if not all, outside noise, which I assume helps you focus. Every minute or so, the tone of the sound and the frequency of flashing changes. What I see is akin to the sensations when you press your fingers gently against your closed eyes, but without the feeling of physical discomfort. The flashing causes red and blue checkerboards that quickly alternate. To focus on the visual sensation is a little fatiguing, so after awhile you notice that you start to zone out so much that you don't even realize that there are colors t all. And I think that's when you start to relax the most. But so far, nothing revelatory. Just feeling a little disconnected from the world, with the only thing tying me here the sensation of the keys against my fingertips.  Turned off the machine. I hear strange artifacts like the sound of a garbled bubbling. This lasts about 10-20 seconds, but then everything's back to normal. Glasses off. Related Links:
  • The Adafruit build page.
  • A commercial version on Amazon.
  • An old Engadget article about original Make kit.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Your right generally reiadng a book is healthier for your eyes. But I am a avid video game fan ever since I was 4 and put a good hour in every day and I never had anything close to a seizure. However if you are extremely tired, sitting to close to the TV, and play in the dark, it is very much possible. You can also ruin your eyes reiadng in the dark, I believe.The general rule of thumb, if you overuse something, our bodies will give out the consequences.
